{"about":"www.javierpastore.com ","awards":"Oscar al Mejor Futbolista Joven de la \"Seria A\" en la Liga Italiana 2010-2011","bio":"Javier Pastore, m\u00e1s conocido como \u201cel Flaco\u201d, naci\u00f3 y se cri\u00f3 en C\u00f3rdoba. All\u00ed inici\u00f3 su carrera futbol\u00edstica jugando en las divisiones inferiores del Club Atl\u00e9tico Talleres. Con apenas 17 a\u00f1os, debut\u00f3 en la Primera Divisi\u00f3n de Talleres el 29 de enero de 2007 y luego de tan solo 4 partidos, se incorpor\u00f3 a Hurac\u00e1n en julio de ese mismo a\u00f1o.\n\nHabiendo superado problemas en el tobillo que le impidieron sumarse al equipo con anterioridad, el 24 de mayo del 2008 hizo su debut oficial en Primera de Hurac\u00e1n. La presentaci\u00f3n fue a lo grande: en el Estadio Monumental ante River Plate, por el Torneo Clausura. Su carrera tom\u00f3 un vuelco cuando el entrenador \u00c1ngel Cappa decidi\u00f3 adoptarlo como titular con tan solo 19 a\u00f1os, en un gesto de reconocimiento al enorme talento de la joven promesa.\n\u201cJavier es un jugador exquisito, de los que no abundan. Desde que lo vi, supe que tendr\u00eda una carrera brillante por delante\u201d, recuerda el director t\u00e9cnico \u00c1ngel Cappa.\n\nHacia fines del 2008 y despu\u00e9s del inolvidable gol en la \u00faltima fecha del Torneo Apertura con V\u00e9lez (3 \u2013 0), los medios comenzaron a hablar del fen\u00f3meno Javier Pastore. R\u00e1pidamente impresion\u00f3 por su gran riqueza t\u00e9cnica adem\u00e1s de combinar una amplia visi\u00f3n de juego con mucha verticalidad. Su habilidad tambi\u00e9n la supo demostrar a trav\u00e9s de la facilidad para gambetear rivales y la velocidad con la pelota en su poder. Su particular estilo - similar por sus caracter\u00edsticas al de los mejores jugadores de las d\u00e9cadas de 1960 y 1970-  lo catapult\u00f3 como uno de los m\u00e1s promisorios exponentes del medio futbol\u00edstico argentino.Con su magia y regularidad contribuy\u00f3 en forma decisiva a la excelente y sorpresiva campa\u00f1a del equipo de Hurac\u00e1n en el Clausura 2009. En ese torneo mostr\u00f3 un gran rendimiento tanto a nivel colectivo como individual, donde convirti\u00f3 goles importantes ante River, Rosario Central, Lan\u00fas, Racing. Eso le permiti\u00f3 al club de Parque Patricios disputar el liderazgo con V\u00e9lez Sarsfield hasta la \u00faltima fecha del campeonato. Su nivel de juego provoc\u00f3 que surgieran ofertas de clubes como Manchester United y Palermo para obtener sus servicios.\n\nFinalmente, en julio del 2009 se concret\u00f3 su pase al Palermo de Italia con un contrato hasta el 2014.\n\nEl \"Flaco\u201d supo adecuarse a una nueva forma t\u00e1ctica y no tard\u00f3 en sentirse c\u00f3modo con el estilo de juego del equipo Siciliano. En la Serie A del Calcio le demostr\u00f3 al p\u00fablico italiano su gran capacidad como volante ofensivo, ganando un lugar en sus corazones. Sus destrezas con la pelota despertaron el inter\u00e9s de otros grandes clubes de Europa: Real Madrid, Manchester City, Inter de Mil\u00e1n, Chelsea FC, AC Milan y Barcelona.\n\nSu primer partido en la Selecci\u00f3n Nacional fue contra el combinado de Catalunya el 15 de diciembre de 2009, en Barcelona. Dentro de la primera convocatoria nacional tambi\u00e9n convirti\u00f3 su primer tanto, con un verdadero golazo desde afuera del \u00e1rea. Pero su debut oficial en el conjunto que por aqu\u00e9l entonces dirig\u00eda Diego Armando Maradona, fue en el Mundial de Sud\u00e1frica 2010. All\u00ed ingres\u00f3 por Sergio Ag\u00fcero en la victoria por 2 a 0 contra Grecia, siendo el \u00faltimo partido de la primera fase del Grupo B. A su vez ingres\u00f3 en el triunfo ante M\u00e9xico por los cuartos de final y tambi\u00e9n en la eliminaci\u00f3n ante Alemania por los cuartos de final.\n\nA pesar de ser calificado entre los mejores jugadores del mundo a sus escasos 21 a\u00f1os y llamar la atenci\u00f3n de las potencias futbol\u00edsticas en Europa, contin\u00fao en el Palermo. Una vez finalizado el Mundial, Javier comenz\u00f3 a ser noticia constantemente por llamar el inter\u00e9s los clubes grandes del Viejo Continente. \n\nEn Palermo fue vital, desempe\u00f1andose como una de las piezas claves para finalizar quintos en la temporada y clasificar a la UEFA Europa League. Entre sus mejores actuaciones se destacan un partidazo ante Juventus, un hat trick contra Catania y un gol ante Bologna (mostrando en el festejo una remera con dedicatoria para las madres argentinas, justamente en su d\u00eda).\n\nEn octubre de 2010 fue seleccionado por la FIFA como uno de los mejores talentos de Italia y un mes despu\u00e9s, Sergio Batista lo convoc\u00f3 para el cl\u00e1sico amistoso de Argentina - Brasil. Luego de ese encuentro, fue tentado por un jeque \u00e1rabe para quedarse a jugar en Qatar. En enero del 2011 recibi\u00f3 el premio \"Oscar del Calcio\" al mejor jugador joven de la temporada, donde adem\u00e1s, lo destacaron como la mejor promesa a futuro.  \n\nUnos meses m\u00e1s tarde, fue citado para enfrentar a Estados Unidos y a Costa Rica en dos partidos amistosos de la Selecci\u00f3n Argentina. Form\u00f3 parte del plantel nacional que disput\u00f3 la Copa Am\u00e9rica 2011 como local, donde recibi\u00f3 muy buenas cr\u00edticas por su papel dentro del plantel que dirig\u00eda Sergio Batista. Fue ovacionado dentro del Estadio Mario Alberto Kempes, donde tuvo su ansiado retorno a C\u00f3rdoba, ingresando en el segundo tiempo en la victoria por 3 a 0 ante Costa Rica.\n\nEn Agosto de 2011, Javier Pastore fue transferido al Paris Saint Germain de Francia. Su pase r\u00e9cord se convirti\u00f3 en el m\u00e1s alto de la historia de la Ligue 1.\n\nR\u00e1pidamente, Javier se acopl\u00f3 al equipo m\u00e1s popular de Par\u00eds. Su debut oficial lo hizo el 18 de agosto de 2011 ante Differdange, por la UEFA Europa League. Luego de sorprender en sus primeras actuaciones, fue elegido como el mejor jugador del mes en PSG. El \"Flaco\" convirti\u00f3 su primer gol en la victoria ante Brest por 1 a 0, el 11 de octubre. Un a\u00f1o m\u00e1s tarde, m\u00e1s precisamente el 18 de septiembre, har\u00eda su presentaci\u00f3n en el certamen m\u00e1s importante de Europa: la UEFA Champions League. En aqu\u00e9l primer choque ante Dynamo Kiev, por la fase de grupos, tambi\u00e9n se dio el lujo de marcar el primer tanto.\n\nEn 2013 finalmente llegaron los t\u00edtulos tan esperados. El 12 de mayo PSG gan\u00f3 su tercera Ligue 1, con Javier Pastore como una de sus principales figuras. Su papel en el equipo de Carlo Ancelotti fue tan importante, que los hinchas lo ubicaron dentro del podio al mejor jugador del torneo. Par\u00eds explot\u00f3 de felicidad y sus fan\u00e1ticos colmaron las calles para festejar, ya que hace 19 a\u00f1os que el club no obten\u00eda la liga francesa. Previo al \u00e9xito en el campeonato local, los parisinos hab\u00edan quedado eliminados a \u00faltimo momento, en los cuartos de final de la Champions ante el Barcelona. Sin embargo, tuvieron una gran actuaci\u00f3n en el certamen y en el plano invidivual Pastore logr\u00f3 un nivel superlativo (incluso marcando un gol en el Camp Nou).\n\nEl cordob\u00e9s comenz\u00f3 la temporada 2013 - 2014 de la mejor manera: El 3 de agosto se consagr\u00f3 campe\u00f3n de la Supercopa de Francia (m\u00e1s conocida como el Trofeo de Campeones) ante el Bourdeaux. En la actualidad, Pastore tendr\u00e1 el desaf\u00edo de pelear como candidato en todas las competiciones que se aproximan y buscar\u00e1 continuar haciendo historia en el PSG.","birthday":"06\/20\/1989","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"","city":"Paris","state":"","country":"France","zip":""},"personal_info":"Nombre completo: Javier Mat\u00edas Pastore.\n\nApodos: \"Flaco\", \"Javi\", \"Il Fantasista\".\n\nLugar de nacimiento: C\u00f3rdoba (Argentina).\n\nNacionalidad: Argentino \/ Italiano.\n\nEstado Civil: Soltero.\n\nPeso: 78 kg.\n\nAltura: 1,90 mts.\n\nPosici\u00f3n: Mediocampista Ofensivo \/ Enganche \/ Media punta \/ Extremo.\n\nClub de debut: Talleres de C\u00f3rdoba.\n\nClub actual: PSG.","talking_about_count":5161,"username":"pastorej","website":"www.javierpastore.com ","were_here_count":0,"id":"145685275457870","name":"Javier Pastore (Oficial)","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pastorej","likes":994500,"cover":{"cover_id":749594258400299,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-frc3\/s720x720\/1385338_749594258400299_669492561_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"8 TIMES MISTER OLYMPIA,  FROM 1998 - 2005 www.facebook.com\/rcsups ","affiliation":"bodybuilding superchampion","awards":"1991 World Amateur Championships (Heavyweight\n1990 Mr. Texas (Heavyweight & Overall)\n1991 Mr. Universe\n1995 Canada Pro Cup\n1996 Canada Pro Cup\n1997 Grand Prix Russia\n1998 Night of Champions\n1998 Toronto Pro Invitational\n1998 Mr. Olympia\n1998 Grand Prix Finland\n1998 Grand Prix Germany\n1999 Mr. Olympia\n1999 World Pro Championships\n1999 Grand Prix England\n2000 Mr. Brody Langley\n2000 Grand Prix England\n2000 World Pro Championships\n2000 Mr. Olympia\n2001 Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic\n2001 Mr. Olympia\n2001 New Zealand Grand Prix\n2002 Mr. Olympia\n2002 Grand Prix Holland\n2003 Mr. Olympia\n2003 Grand Prix Russia\n2004 Mr. Olympia\n2004 Grand Prix England\n2004 Grand Prix Holland\n2004 Grand Prix Russia\n2005 Mr. Olympia","bio":"Alongside his eight Mr. Olympia wins as a professional bodybuilder, Coleman holds the record for most wins as an IFBB professional with 26. He broke the previous record (held by Vince Taylor at 22 wins) in Moscow on November 5, 2004.\n\nColeman graduated cum laude from Grambling State University (GSU) in 1986 with a B.S degree in accounting[citation needed]. While attending Grambling State University Coleman also played football as a middle linebacker with the GSU Tigers under famous coach Eddie Robinson. After graduation, Coleman became a police officer.\n\nBeing a police officer allowed Coleman the free time he needed to work out. Coleman's fellow officer suggested he attend a gym known as Metroflex. The owner of the gym was Brian Dobson, who happen to also be an amateur bodybuilder, offered Coleman a free lifetime membership to Metroflex if he would allow him to train Coleman for the upcoming Mr. Texas bodybuilding competition that year.\n\nAfter the training for the upcoming event of Mr. Texas, Coleman won first place in both the heavy weight and overall categories. He also defeated the man that trained him, Dobson. Also in 1990 not only did Coleman take the title of Mr. Texas but he also took titles in that years National Physique Committee (NPC) Texas Championships. In 1991 Coleman also won what is probably considered one of the most prestigious competitions in amateur bodybuilding, Mr. Universe. This victory qualified him to enter the professional contest sponsored by the IFBB, the sport's largest sanctioning body.\n\nColeman won his first competition as a professional\u2014the Canada Pro Cup in 1995. The following year he won the contest again. Followed by a first place win in 1997, The Russian Grand Prix.\n\nColeman's success as a professional bodybuilder has led to many product endorsements and other opportunities in his career. Due to his bodybuilding profession Coleman undergoes a lot of travel to places such as China, Brazil, and Australia. Coleman also makes many guest appearances at gym openings all around the U.S.\n\nColeman has also made some training videos. His first Training Video; The Unbelievable; The cost of Redemption; and On the Road. In these videos Coleman gives tips for more experienced weightlifters, while warning against over exertion and improper form.\n\nWhen working out, Coleman prefers to use free weights rather than machines in order to maximize his flexibility and range of motion. He lifts weights six days per week.\n\nColeman supports the Inner City Games, an organization that California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger co-founded in 1991. He was the recipient of the 2001 Admiral in the Texas Navy Certificate Award from Texas Governor Rick Perry for outstanding achievements in bodybuilding and for the promotion of physical fitness.\n\nOn June 30, 2009 on MuscleSport Radio, Coleman stated that he would compete in the 2010 Mr. Olympia competition.[citation needed] Coleman also indicated that he would not participate in the 2009 Mr. Olympia competition for lack of preparation time. On October 10, 2009 at the Northern Territory Fitness & Bodybuilding Titles in Darwin, Australia, Coleman confirmed that he would compete in the 2010 Mr. Olympia competition, however, he did not appear at the 2010 Mr. Olympia competition.\n","birthday":"05\/13\/1964","category":"Athlete","category_list":[{"id":"1600","name":"Athlete"}],"is_published":true,"location":{"street":"706 Gentry Drive","city":"Arlington","state":"TX","country":"United States","zip":"76018","latitude":32.654709,"longitude":-97.101669},"personal_info":"Is the man many consider the greatest champion in bodybuilding history making a historic comeback? \nBy: Roger Lockridge \n\nThe Return of Ronnie?\n8 Times he has held the Mr. Olympia title; tied for the most of all time. 26 times he has claimed victory in the IFBB; the most of any bodybuilder ever. Many consider him the Michael Jordan of bodybuilding. When Ronnie Coleman stepped offstage for the last time in the fall of 2007 at the Olympia, it was the end of an era of dominance that we may never see again. \n\nBut like the end of many great athletes' runs, many have speculated whether Ronnie will come back. Each year since his 4th place finish at the '07 Olympia, there have been rumors that he was coming back. The King would return to claim his throne. It's understandable because even though he has never competed since, Ronnie has been as close to the sport as ever. \n\nWhether it was his guest posing around the world, his appearances at all the major expos, his contributions most recently to Muscular Development Magazine, working on plans for the \"Ronnie Coleman Signature Series\" line of supplement products, or using his celebrity status to give back via his charity \"Free the World From Hunger\", Coleman has maintained his position as an ambassador and representative of bodybuilding because he knows that bodybuilding has given him so much and he wants to give back as much as he can. \n\nHe knows it, you know it, we all know it.\nWhen it comes to bodybuilding, Ronnie Coleman is the greatest.\n\nIs 2011 The Year It Happens?\nThose rumors have never been stronger than this year when Dan Solomon, Chad Nicholls, and Lee Thompson brought the subject up on Pro Bodybuilding Weekly when they announced that both Brian Dobson, owner of the world renowned Metroflex gym in Arlington, TX where Ronnie trains, and the promoter of the IFBB Masters World Championships in Miami announced that this was the year Coleman was coming back. \n\nSo is true? Will the man many consider the best ever make a triumphant return and prove that even as he enters his late 40's he still has what it takes to stand among the best? Bodybuilding.com chatted with the legend himself to find out the latest on what could be history in the making.  \n\nBodybuilding.com: You haven't been onstage since the '07 Olympia but rumors have been circulating for a long time that you were going to come back at some point. Did you think that was the last time you competed or did you know that you would make a comeback?\nRonnie Coleman: I always knew that I would make a comeback at some point. I didn't know when but I knew it would eventually happen. \n\nBBcom: Is this the year we will see you back in a pair of posing trunks?\nRC: Well to be honest I don't know if I am going to now or not. I knew I would comeback at some point because I want to prove to myself that I can still do it. If I do this it will be for me to prove to myself that I can still get onstage and bring a winning physique. \n\nBBcom: What is going to help you make the decision to return to an IFBB stage this year?\nRC: I don't know how well known it is but I had back surgery in '07 and it took about two years to recover. I just now feel comfortable enough to do it. It is different for me to prepare now because back when I competed I didn't travel or anything. I prepared and that was it. After this surgery, for a while I didn't even leave the house. \n\nI have a gym at home so if I felt good enough to work out I did it there. I am feeling good now but it's more of a mental game for me now. I need to make sure my head is right and I'm not going to worry about getting injured. Now that I'm older it's a head game to see if I want to put myself through all the work it takes to get ready for a show. \n\nAs I said earlier, if I do this it will be for me to prove I can do it. Before, I didn't have that issue because I competed for sponsors and other reasons. This will be all about challenging me if I do the show in December. We'll have to wait and see. \n\nBBcom: So all of the talks about coming back are a little premature. Is that what you are saying?\nRC: At this point, yeah it is. My back is coming along pretty good compared to where it was. I couldn't even take five steps before without hurting. Now I can walk a mile no problem. You know what I mean? \n\nBBcom: So if you decide you are mentally ready to prepare for the Masters World Championships, will it be more difficult for you to prepare since you haven't done it in a few years, or will it be like riding a bike so to speak?\nRC: Oh if I decide I am going to do it then the prep work will be nothing new for me and I will be able to do it without any problem. I may not be as strong as I used to be but I am still pretty strong and I know I can handle what I have to do in the gym to be ready to step onstage in Miami. The preparations don't bother me a bit. It's just a matter of deciding if I'm clear in my mind that I want to do it. \n\nAlso if I do it then it'll be different because this is for me and not for endorsements or anything like that. I'm not even with BSN anymore so this will be all about me and if I can still do it. A lot of the guys in that show are older and past their prime and are probably doing it to see if they can do it too. \n\nBbcom: You mentioned the work in the gym. Now that you are a few years older, will the training remain the same as it did when you were Mr. Olympia or will you change up what you do to get ready for the show?\nRC: Training will be a little different. I'm 46 now, will be 47 when the show comes around, so I'm not going to be as strong as I was when I was Mr. Olympia. What I used to call \"light weight\" will probably feel heavier. (He laughs) I won't be able to handle all the weight like I did when I filmed the videos and did all the other things I did back a few years ago. \n\nI have to make adjustments and train a little differently, but I will still give all the effort I did back then. That part of it will never change. I still believe in training heavy and hard. It's just I can't go as heavy as I did back then. \n\nBBcom: When you competed there weren't too many flaws with your physique. Now will you focus on improving any part in particular or will you just focus on bringing the best you've got?\nRC: Yeah I'm past the point now of worrying about weak points. I'm just going to focus on bringing the best I've got to the stage and that's it. Back then, whatever was considered weak on my body I would take time to improve. Nowadays I don't worry about things like that. \n\nBBcom: Will anyone be helping you get ready for the show or will you do the prep on your own?\nRC: Again that's something I haven't given much thought to and probably won't until I decide if I'm going to do the show or not. I have a lot of experience getting ready for shows so I may end up doing my own prep work, but we'll have to wait and see before I can answer that conclusively. \n\nBBcom: Have you given any thought to who else is in the lineup or are you just worrying about you?\nRC: I talked to the promoter and there were actually 12 guys invited. Dexter Jackson, former Mr. Olympia is doing it. Toney Freeman, who placed high at the Olympia is doing it. Samir Bannout who was dominant in his day ('83 Mr. Olympia), Chris Cormier, who always placed high in shows is doing it. \n\nIt's a good list of guys but some of them are older; even older than me. They're good though because I don't know if I could do it at their age. You can't blame them for doing it though because this show is invitation only and the purse is the 3rd highest on the entire circuit.\n\nBBcom: So when do you think you will make the ultimate decision to grace a bodybuilding stage with your presence?\nRC: I don't know when I will make the decision. I couldn't set a date, but when I do I will let everyone know. I would like to do it, and if my head is in it then it will be on for sure. \n\n\n","talking_about_count":6319,"username":"8xmisterO","website":"www.ronniecoleman.net","were_here_count":0,"id":"122788722443","name":"ronnie coleman","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/8xmisterO","likes":852288,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151844694982444","source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash4\/s720x720\/1452539_10151844694982444_1142845091_n.jpg","offset_y":50,"offset_x":0}}

He has played much of his career in a centre midfield role, but he has also been used as a second striker, holding midfielder, right back and right winger.\n\nGerrard, who has spent his entire career at Anfield, made his d\u00e9but in 1998 and cemented his place in the first team in 2000, succeeding Sami Hyypi\u00e4 as team captain in 2003. His honours include two FA Cups, three League Cups, two Community Shields, one Champions League, one UEFA Cup, and two Super Cups.\n\nGerrard made his international debut in 2000, and has since represented England at the 2000 and 2004 European Championships, as well as the 2006 World Cup \u2013 where he was the team's top goalscorer with two goals \u2013 and the 2010 World Cup, where he first captained his country in the absence of regular captain Rio Ferdinand, who missed the tournament through injury. He was named as the permanent England captain shortly before the 2012 European Championship, where he was named in the UEFA Team of the Tournament.\n\nGerrard has been described as one of the greatest English midfielders in history, \"a real leader, Gerrard is a tireless runner and has superb vision. His striking from distance is feared around the world and he is a prolific scorer for a midfielder.\" Gerrard came second only to Kenny Dalglish in the \"100 Players Who Shook The Kop\" \u2013 a Liverpool fan poll. Zinedine Zidane said in 2009 that he considered Gerrard to be the best footballer in the world. In 2005, Gerrard was honoured as the UEFA Club Footballer of the Year and won the Ballon d'Or Bronze Award. Additionally, he has been named to the PFA Team of the Year seven times, the UEFA Team of the Year and FIFA World XI three times, he was named PFA Players' Player of the Year in 2006 and the FWA Footballer of the Year in 2009. In 2010, The Guardian named Gerrard to their World XI team, which compiled the greatest footballers of all time onto one squad. He is, to date, the only footballer ever to have scored a goal in an FA Cup Final, a League Cup Final, a UEFA Cup Final and a Champions League Final.","category":"Athlete","category_list":[{"id":"1600","name":"Athlete"}],"is_published":true,"location":{"street":"","city":"Amman","state":"","country":"Jordan","zip":"0000","latitude":32.4782396,"longitude":35.7655259},"personal_info":"Personal information\nFull name - Steven George Gerrard\nDate of birth - 30 May 1980 (age 33)\nPlace of birth - Whiston, Merseyside, England\nHeight - 1.83 m (6 ft 0 in)[2]\nPlaying position - Midfielder\nClub information\nCurrent club - Liverpool\nNumber - 8","talking_about_count":34844,"username":"StevenGerrard","were_here_count":0,"id":"273063079480908","name":"Steven George Gerrard","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/StevenGerrard","likes":279553,"cover":{"cover_id":466025946851286,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-prn2\/1476539_466025946851286_781805482_n.jpg","offset_y":17,"offset_x":0}}

{"category":"Interest","description":"DeSean William Jackson is an American football wide receiver and return specialist for the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League . He played college football for the University of California, Berkeley, and was a two-time consensus All-American. He was drafted by the Eagles in the second round of the 2008 NFL Draft. Jackson has been selected to the Pro Bowl twice, and was the first player selected to the Pro Bowl at two different positions in the same year when he was named to the 2010 Pro Bowl as a wide receiver and return specialist.Early yearsJackson was born in Los Angeles, California. He attended Long Beach Polytechnic High School, the same high school as future Eagles teammate Winston Justice and many other current NFL players. He became one of the top wide receiver recruits in the nation, with many collegiate football programs pursuing his services. He was named the 2004 Glenn Davis Award winner by the Los Angeles Times as Southern California's player of the year. Some crack under the weight of newly heightened expectations.  Some put it on cruise control and coast along from past achievements in a fulfilled state of satisfaction.  It is a rare individual who rides the momentum of success towards bigger and better things in life.  Professional skateboarder Chris Cole, through his continual domination of competitions, has clearly earned himself the top spot amongst the elite of skateboarding.  Through it all, Chris has been grounded with the realization that life is all about deep-seated relationships fostered through respect and compassion.  As his profile ascended, he furthered his desire to perpetually self evaluate and improve all facets of life.  His forthright interactions with those in and out of the industry made a direct and positive impact on the image and character of skateboarding.  It was an image that at times took hits for being overrun with punk kids running amuck and creating havoc on public property.  As the spotlight's glow on Chris began to brighten, so did the viability and credibility of skateboarding as a whole.  It was rapidly becoming the fastest growing sport in America.  Chris wanted the world to see that skateboarding breeds individuals that are athletic, creative, and driven.  Rather than succumbing to the trappings of the \"live fast and die young\" mentality, Chris adopted his own credo of \"live rad and die proud\".  It is a concise and powerful statement that has guided him personally and throughout his professional career.  A career that was first set into motion at the ripe old age of 14.\n\nAt a time in life when most kids are figuring out what video game to play next, Chris had made the determination that he would forgo college and make his way in life by skateboarding full-time.  Chris was raised in Levittown, PA outside of Philadelphia.  He holds the Northeast corridor and the makeup of it\u2019s people near and dear to his heart.  He likens their notorious rudeness to a hardened exterior shell.  Once penetrated, the shell makes way for deeper and much more meaningful connections.  While in the Philadelphia area, Chris entered into local and regional skateboarding contests starting in his pre-teen years.  He won them early and he won them often.  He quickly established himself as an elite talent and landed corporate sponsorships by the age of 16. Chris credits the development of his riding style to his willingness to shred and skate all physical obstacles that present themselves in the realm of street skating.  He never wanted to be limited to just being great on ledges or handrails.  He wanted to crush gaps, ramps, and anything and everything there was to conquer.  It was this approach to street skating that garnered him a string of accolades, yet to cease or slow from being bestowed upon him.  He has received honors from the industry and direct praise from the fans like Transworld Skateboarding\u2019s \"Readers Choice Award\". He has the rarified distinction of being only one of two skaters twice named Thrasher Magazine\u2019s \u201cSkater of the Year\u201d (2005 & 2009). The Dew Tour, Maloof Money Cup, and Battle of the Berrics 2 are just a partial listing of contests he wrapped up for victory.  There was also the back to back gold medals won in consecutive years at the X Games, ESPN's elite action sports event. He became a featured rider in the smash hit video games \"Skate\" and \"Skate 2\" while also making numerous appearances in videos such as \"Bam Margera: CKY2K\".  While the physical expressions that Chris was able to display on a board clearly played a major role in all these triumphs, he attributes the success to something much simpler than that - Fun.  If Chris is not having fun, then he is not winning contests.  The foundation of his career advancement has been the passion and pure joy he has in his soul for skateboarding.  It is a wholehearted desire for riding and competing that words on a page fall short of describing.  It is the kind of infatuation that can make a 14 year old boy be acutely aware that instead of college, his future belongs thrashing through history.  \n\nChris indeed has made his mark on the history of skateboarding. {"category":"Athlete","description":"Ronald Antonio \"Ronnie\" O'Sullivan is an English professional snooker player from Chigwell, Essex. He is the reigning World Snooker Champion, having won the title for the fifth time in 2013.O'Sullivan turned professional in 1992, at the age of 16. Known for his rapid playing style, he soon earned the nickname \"The Rocket\". He won his first ranking title, the 1993 UK Championship, one week before his 18th birthday, and still holds the record as the youngest player ever to win a professional ranking tournament. He has won a total of 25 ranking titles in his career to date, including five World Championship and four UK Championship titles, and was ranked world number one for five seasons between 2002\/2003 and 2009\/2010. His non-ranking tournament achievements include four Masters and ten Premier League titles and winning the Nations Cup with England in 2000.O'Sullivan is joint third with John Higgins on the list of players to have won the most ranking titles, and is fourth behind Stephen Hendry, Ray Reardon, and Steve Davis on the list of players to have won the most World Championships in the modern era. With career earnings of over \u00a37 million, he is second after Hendry on snooker's all-time prize-money list. He is also second behind Hendry on the list of players making the most competitive century breaks, with a total of 715. He has compiled 11 maximum breaks in professional competition, a record he shares with Hendry. At the 1997 World Championship, he set the record for the fastest competitive maximum break at 5 minutes 20 seconds.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":1149,"website":"http:\/\/www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk\/Gloucester-MP-plays-snooker-ace-Ronnie-O-Sullivan\/story-11863581-detail\/story.html","were_here_count":0,"id":"109361512423166","name":"Ronnie O'Sullivan","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Ronnie-OSullivan\/109361512423166","likes":140078}

{"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Raw and WWE NXT Slammy Award-winning broadcaster Michael Cole","affiliation":"WWE ","bio":"The self-proclaimed \u201cVoice of WWE\u201d and \u201cfuture WWE Hall of Famer\u201d Michael Cole is the play-by-play announcer for Monday Night Raw and a color commentator on Friday Night SmackDown. Though he has been a fixture on WWE TV since mid-1997, only in 2010 did the WWE Universe realize exactly how loathsome Cole can be.\n\nBefore joining the wild world of WWE, Cole was a standout in the field of broadcast journalism, working for CBS radio and building a r\u00e9sum\u00e9 one wouldn\u2019t expect of an announcer who currently causes his broadcast colleagues and WWE fans to stock up on headache remedies.\n\nWhile working for CBS Radio in 1993, Cole covered the entire 51-day standoff at the Branch Davidian compound in Waco, Texas. In 1994, he traveled to Sarajevo for what was supposed to be a six-week assignment covering the siege of the city by Serbian forces. The assignment turned into a nine-month, life-changing experience that saw him report daily from a war-torn city, ducking snipers and mortar shells at every turn. His documentary, \"Voices of Bosnia,\" was critically acclaimed and won several major awards. With experience in reporting the most tragic of events, Cole was dispatched to Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995 to cover the horrific bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building.\n\nCole also covered three United States Presidential elections; in 1988 with Michael Dukakis, 1992 with Bill Clinton, and 1996 with Steve Forbes and then Bob Dole. One year after his final stretch of election coverage, Cole entered sports-entertainment.\n\nIn 1997, Cole brought his talents to WWE and sat alongside a litany of broadcast partners that include Jim Cornette, Tazz, John \u201cBradshaw\u201d Layfield, Jim Ross, Kevin Kelly, Jerry \u201cThe King\u201d Lawler, Jonathan Coachman, Mick Foley, Matt Striker, Todd Grisham, Josh Mathews and Booker T.\n\nHowever, in early 2010, the largely objective former journalist slowly showed signs of negative outspokenness while calling WWE NXT. The interviewer who once entertained the WWE Universe by receiving a wedgie by DX and getting humiliated by The Rock in verbal tirades slowly said and did things to make him more reviled by WWE fans.\n\nInsulting the likes of Jim Ross and former Divas Champion Eve, Cole\u2019s incendiary comments and aggressive support of The Miz got the announcer out from under the headset and into a bright orange singlet on The Grandest Stage of Them All.\n\nAt WrestleMania XXVII, Cole faced Raw announce team colleague Jerry Lawler with \u201cStone Cold\u201d Steve Austin was signed as special guest referee. It simply wasn\u2019t pretty but not just because of Cole\u2019s ludicrous ring wear. The Voice of WWE took a much needed beating in front of millions but left with a highly debatable victory by disqualification \u2013 a fact Cole is quick to recall on air almost weekly on Raw.\n\nIn the months that followed, Cole tasted \u201cde-feet\u201d in the form of a Kiss My Foot Match he lost to Lawler and the contemptible commentator ultimately apologized to both The King and the rest of the WWE Universe for his actions. This hasn\u2019t stopped Cole from offending and irritating viewers with his one-sided brand of broadcast journalism. The assignment turned into a nine-month life-changing experience that saw him report daily from the war-torn city, ducking snipers and mortar shells at every turn. His documentary, \u201cVoices of Bosnia,\u201d was critically acclaimed and won several major awards.\n\nExperienced in the face of tragedy, Cole was dispatched to Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995 to cover the horrific bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, where 168 people were lost their lives. Cole also covered three presidential elections \u2013 1988 with Michael Dukakis, 1992 with Bill Clinton, and 1996 with Steve Forbes and Bob Dole.\n\nIn 1997, Cole brought his talents to WWE. In his early days, he hosted the syndicated Livewire show, as well as Shotgun Saturday Night with Jim Cornette. By the end of that year, he was an announcer on Raw. From 1997 to 1999 he held regular stints as a Raw announcer, and when SmackDown made its debut in 1999, Cole was chosen for the lead play-by-play announcing role. Originally teamed up with Jerry Lawler, Cole was paired with Tazz in 2001 and the two were together for five years until his realignment with ECW in June 2006. After that, Cole found himself sitting beside then-retired JBL, Jonathan Coachman and later the Hardcore Legend himself, Mick Foley, until Cole was ultimately drafted to Monday Night Raw.\n\nIn his tenure behind the broadcast booth, Cole has sometimes found himself in the thick of the action. While some of his assignments are enviable (such as emceeing a Divas Bikini Contest, for instance), he has also found himself as the object of several SmackDown Superstars\u2019 ire. Regardless, his talent for calling the turbulent and unpredictable action of WWE has made him one of the top all-time announcers.\n","talking_about_count":10041,"username":"WWEMichaelCole","website":"http:\/\/www.wwe.com\/superstars","were_here_count":0,"id":"118277891560596","name":"Michael Cole - WWE","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/WWEMichaelCole","likes":333976,"cover":{"cover_id":345495655505484,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-frc3\/s720x720\/545005_345495655505484_1301368991_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"I'm just a skinny natural bodybuilder | 5'11\" 189lbs","awards":"2008 INBA Novice Mr Victoria and Novice Mr Australia\n2008 ANB Novice Mr Victoria\n\n2010 INBA Intermediate Mr Victoria and Intermediate Mr Australia (DQ'd)\n2010 ANB Intermediate and Overall Mr Victoria\n2010 ANB U90kg and Overall Mr Australia (DQ'd)\n\n2012 NABBA Class 2 State Champion\n2012 IFBB U90kg State Champion\n\n2013 IFBB FitX Mens Physique last place\n2013 INBA\n2013 ANB","bio":"Aaron Curtis was once a skinny boy, who dreamed of running marathons, surfing Pipeline and Waimea Bay, playing Australian rules football and competing in the Hawaiian Ironman triathlon.\n\nThroughout his younger years, he participated mainly in track and field, cross country and Australian rules football. He also participated in Gymnastics from ages 6-10.\n\nAaron began training with weights for no apparent reason in 1998. After numerous injuries, he began spending less time running track and playing football and more time in the school gymnasium. \n\nAdding more muscle to his little frame with each passing year, he no longer excelled in the sports he was most genetically gifted at (middle distance running\/cross country\/football) and moved more towards the throwing events to make the school track and field team.\n\nIn late 2002 Aaron fell out of a tree (yes srs) and tore a chunk of cartilage off the bottom of his femur, also tearing his medial ligament in the process. This forced Aaron to be far more inactive (cardio wise) than he was used to and he started spending even more time in the gym. After waiting around 12 months, he underwent a cartilage graft, which involved removing some of his own cartilage cells, culturing them up in the hospital and then later grafting the cartilage back into the injured knee. The recovery process meant spending 3 months on crutches whilst the graft hardened and set into place, during which time he hired a wheelchair and spend most of his spare time 'tricking' in the chair and seeing how fast it could go down his street. Six months post op, he started rehabbing the knee in the gym with very light bodyweight movements, extensions and curls. Twelve months post op, his knee was 100\u0025 and his legs were starting to take shape. \n\nStarting up a muck-around basketball team with some friends around 2004, who's uniform included rather tight singlets and short shorts (they were actually underwearz) he tried to get back into competitive sports, athletics\/football\/basketball.\n\nStruggling to be as competetive as he once was, he was plagued by soft tissue injuries and was becoming more and more frustrated.\n\nAfter tearing his hamstring for the 1647th time (not quite srs) running a 400m race in early 2008, he decided to hang up his spikes\/football boots and focus solely on becoming a competitive bodybuilder. \n\nHe had been eating\/training like a bodybuilder since 2003, so the lifestyle was there already. He thought he would give in to the constant pressure from others and may as well compete in a bodybuilding show and see how he faired.\n\nThe 2008 season went well and although overdieting left him flat and a little smaller than what he should have been, he won the INBA Mr Novice Australia title.\n\nHaving to sit out the 2009 bodybuilding season after tearing his medial ligament, vastus medialis, and adductor magnus, whilst participating in a wrestling\/rugby match during a \u2018foam party\u2019 at a nightclub in Indonesia (also srs), he focussed on the 2010 season.\n\n2010 was a very interesting year for Aaron Curtis. After having focussed on winning the state \u2018intermediate\u2019 title for the past 2 years, Aaron found himself winning the ANB state overall title and coming a close 2nd in the INBA state titles. He then went on to get a close 2nd yet again at the INBA nationals titles and came home from the 2010 ANB Australian Championships as  the overall national champion, I title he had never dreamed of winning in 2010, as he believed he was 5-10 years of training, away from such a title.\n\nAround 2 weeks after nationals, Aaron became aware of many athletes testing positive to methylhexaneamine due to use of many popular bodybuilding pre workout supplements. Methylhexaneamine is a dietry supplement which is legal for use \u2018out of competition\u2019 periods but is prohibited  \u2018in competition\u2019 periods. Aaron had been using the product \u2018jack3d\u2019 around the time of his comps and realised that he would soon be receiving a letter from ASADA\/WADA informing him of his positive test\/s. \n\nAaron was later banned from all ASADA\/WADA sanctioned sports for 2 years and stripped of his ANB national U90kgs and overall title and also his INBA state and national intermediate titles. He still holds the 2010 ANB Mr Victoria overall state title, as he did not test positive in that competition.\n\nAaron is now training hard during his forced offseason, focussing on being the biggest and best bodybuilder he can be, when he next gets up on stage.\n\nAaron is a lifetime natural athlete, with no use of any pro hormones, anabolic steroids, growth hormones or peptides. At this stage of his life he has no desire to \u2018enhance\u2019 and make the transition across to the \u2018untested\u2019 competitions.\n\nDuring his ban from natural competition, Aaron got up on stage in the NABBA and IFBB wirth the BIG BOYS! Still competing as natural athlete, not be taking any substances that are prohibited within the natural bodybuilding federations that he usually competes in, Aaron still managed to win his classes in both federations at the state championships. Having not expected to do very well in the untested federations, Aaron had not planned to go on to the national titles in either federation and had already booked a holiday to Indonesia post comp.\n\nIn early 2013 Aaron decided to compete in an IFBB mens physique competition at FitX, in offseason condition, as a joke. After being advised not to do so by his sponsors, Aaron decided he would still do the show, but had to crash diet for 4 weeks to try and get in shape. Aaron got back down to around 10\u0025 body fat for the show and thought he looked OK, but the judges thought otherwise and he placed dead last! Lolol.\n\nToo big for mens physique.\n\nAaron is currently preparing for the 2013 INBA and ANB state\/national bodybuilding shows, where he hopes to qualify for the Natural Olympia, held in San Diego, this November.\n\nWith the sole goal of becoming the best natural bodybuilder that he can be, Aaron puts very little emphasis on how he looks\/places compared to any other athlete. He focuses on bettering his past performances in regards to size\/symmetry\/proportion and definition of his own physique. For Aaron, bodybuilding competition is a way of measuring his own personal progress, not about winning titles or trophies. \n\n\u2018Get massive.\u2019 \u2013 Aaron Curtis =]\n","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"Australia Mate","zip":""},"personal_info":"5'11\" 189lbs (on stage), 225lbs (offseason).","personal_interests":"Eating, sleeping, training, surfing, watching sports, enjoying the suns warmth... and sleeping more.","talking_about_count":12395,"username":"skinnyaaroncurtis","website":"\u003C\u003Cnot-applicable>>","were_here_count":0,"id":"250000031724735","name":"Aaron Curtis","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/skinnyaaroncurtis","likes":276032,"cover":{"cover_id":584122984979103,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash3\/s720x720\/542241_584122984979103_2091134811_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar Shawn Michaels.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"Ask any Superstar on the WWE roster who the most gifted sports-entertainer of all time is and nearly everyone will have the same answer \u2014 Shawn Michaels.\n\nA cocky, confident heartbreaker from San Antonio, Texas, HBK started off his career as one-half of The Rockers and ended it in a classic match with The Undertaker at WrestleMania XXVI. Along the way, he won every major WWE title, two Royal Rumbles, entry into the WWE Hall of Fame and a reputation as The Icon, The Showstopper, The Main Event.\n\nHis days in the ring weren\u2019t always glorious, though. After charming crowds as a Rocker in the \u201990s, HBK infamously severed his partnership with Marty Jannety by smashing his friend\u2019s head through a window. And the notorious \u201cMontreal Screwjob\u201d of the 1997 Survivor Series involving his greatest rival, Bret \u201cHit Man\u201d Hart, could have killed a lesser Superstar\u2019s career. Instead, it only added to the allure of one of sports-entertainment\u2019s most captivatingly flawed figures. \n\nA rebel in leather chaps, Michaels bucked authority and surrounded himself with people who did the same. As the troublemaker behind DX, HBK made life a living hell for the McMahon family alongside his longtime running buddy Triple H. As a member of The Kliq, he did the same for the WWE locker room, carefully wielding his considerable influence to get the best treatment for himself and friends like Kevin Nash and Scott Hall.\n\nThe self-proclaimed \u201cSexy Boy\u201d could be an unrepentant primadonna, but he was so fluid and brilliant in the ring that it hardly mattered. In that time, he fell in love, had children, found religion. When he finally returned, Michaels displayed none of the flaws that plague many Superstars in their final years in the ring. Instead, The Icon continued to have career-defining matches right up until his last stand against The Phenom at WrestleMania XXVI. \n\nAlthough it was one of the final times WWE fans would hear the crack of Sweet Chin Music, audiences did not mourn HBK\u2019s retirement. He came to prominence after appearing in MTV's Jackass crew. He has since appeared in MTV's Viva La Bam and Bam's Unholy Union, all three Jackass movies, and Haggard and Minghags, both of which he co-wrote and directed.Early lifeMargera was born in West Chester, Pennsylvania, to Phil and April Margera. He is the younger brother of Jess Margera and nephew of Vincent Margera. His grandfather nicknamed him \"Bam\" at the age of three after his habit of running into walls. He attended East High School and cites friend Chris Raab as his only reason for attending high school.CareerTelevision and filmMargera began shooting videos of himself and his friends skateboarding and doing stunts, which eventually turned into the CKY video series. He independently released CKY. CKY2K, CKY3 and CKY4 have also been released. CKY stands for \"Camp Kill Yourself\", a reference to the film Sleepaway Camp. These early videos feature many of Margera's friends, including Ryan Dunn, Brandon DiCamillo, Rake Yohn, Chris Raab, Brandon Novak and others who form a loose collective known as the CKY Crew. {"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar Christian.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"Christian\u2019s been proving his worth in WWE from day one. In his first official bout in 1998 as a member of The Brood, the Toronto native set the bar rather high for himself by winning the Light Heavyweight Championship from Taka Michinoku. And he\u2019s raised it every year since.\n\nChristian\u2019s knack for wowing the WWE Universe, by executing innovative and high-impact maneuvers, has cemented his rep as a top-tier Superstar and led to some pretty epic victories alongside lifelong friend Edge during the TLC mayhem of the Attitude Era. Together, the duo laid claim to seven stunning World Tag Team Championships and engineered some of WWE's most memorably absurd moments, including their infamous \"five-second pose.\" They also pioneered the dreaded Con-Chair-To, a sadistic double-team strike in which both Canucks simultaneously whacked an adversary with a folding chair. This obsession with steel objects reached frenzied heights at WrestleMania 2000, where Edge & Christian, the Hardy Boyz and the Dudleys introduced the world to the first-ever Tables, Ladders and Chairs Match.\n\n\u201cCaptain Charisma\u201d eventually broke out on his own, birthing a pack of followers known as \u201cPeeps\u201d and winning numerous titles such as the prestigious Intercontinental Championship. In 2009, after taking a four-year sabbatical from WWE, he returned to his hardcore roots to notch the ECW Championship\u2014twice in one year.\n\nPerhaps none of his achievements, though, are as extraordinary as his victory in a brutal Ladder Match against Alberto Del Rio at Extreme Rules 2011, where Christian captured his first World Heavyweight Championship. He held the illustrious title for five days before seeing his reign ended prematurely by Randy Orton.\n\nThe loss narrowed Christian\u2019s focus on regaining the World Heavyweight Title by any means necessary, even if it meant constant pleas for \u201cone more match\u201d to prove his mettle. He kicked off his second reign with a victory over The Viper at Money in the Bank 2011, only to have Orton reclaim the title one month later at SummerSlam 2011. The charismatic competitor then struggled to regain his form and finally saw his year end due to injury.\n\nUpon realizing the honor of inducting his longtime friend and former partner, Edge, into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2012, Christian confessed to experiencing a \u201cmoment of clarity\u201d that reset his own career goals. He returned from injury at WWE Over the Limit 2012 and won a Battle Royal and a match with Cody Rhodes to claim the Intercontinental Championship for the fourth time. {"about":"The official WWE Facebook fan page of The Miz.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"First introduced to TV audiences as one of the seven strangers on \u201cThe Real World: Back to New York,\u201d The Miz parlayed his reality TV fame into a legitimate WWE career.\n\nAnd for those who think he\u2019s a fluke, just ask him. He proved everyone wrong, though, by winning the United States Championship, the Unified Tag Team Championship and several high-profile matches.\n\nThen in July 2010, Miz\u2019s career hit a turning point. By winning the Raw Money in the Bank Ladder Match, the Ohio native guaranteed himself a chance to capture his ultimate goal \u2014 the WWE Championship. And on the Nov. 22, 2010, edition of Monday Night Raw, The Miz finally made good on his persistent threats, successfully cashing in his WWE Title opportunity on a vulnerable Randy Orton to capture the most illustrious prize in sports-entertainment.\n\nFollowing the win, The Miz went on a blistering championship reign, backing up every caustic proclamation of his awesomeness by holding onto the title for an astounding 160 days. Su polivalencia y presencia total sobre el terreno de juego hacen de Pedro una pieza imprescindible en cualquier equipo de \u00e9lite, tanto en el juego puramente ofensivo como el trabajo de contenci\u00f3n.\n\nGeneroso en el esfuerzo y obstinado en la presi\u00f3n, con el bal\u00f3n en poder del contrario se transforma en un magn\u00edfico baluarte defensivo. Estas caracter\u00edsticas derivan en un futbolista con id\u00e9ntica calidad para rendir en ambas bandas, con profundidad, llegada y gol desde los dos carriles.\n\nPedro es el \u00fanico jugador en la historia del f\u00fatbol mundial que ha conseguido marcar en seis competiciones diferentes en una misma temporada, alz\u00e1ndose adem\u00e1s con los correspondientes seis t\u00edtulos. En una mete\u00f3rica trayectoria de tres temporadas en la \u00e9lite ha cuajado un palmar\u00e9s abrumador en el cual, entre otros logros, figuran una Copa del Mundo, una Eurocopa, dos Ligas de Campeones, tres t\u00edtulos de Liga en Primera divisi\u00f3n, dos Copas del Rey, tres Supercopas de Espa\u00f1a, dos Supercopas de Europa y dos Mundiales FIFA de Clubes.","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"P\u00e1gina Facebook Oficial de Pedro Rodr\u00edguez, jugador del F.C. {"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar Kane.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"If it seems improbable for hellfire and brimstone to be so utterly chilling, you haven\u2019t met Kane. At 7-feet tall and weighing in at more than 300 pounds, The Devil\u2019s Favorite Demon is a monstrous abomination that seems to have been extracted directly from your childhood nightmares.\n\nThe Big Red Monster has tormented WWE since his debut at Badd Blood in October 1997, when he tore off the cage door and unleashed hell during the first-ever Hell in a Cell Match between Shawn Michaels and his half-brother The Undertaker.\n\nKane is consumed by an infernal desire to set ablaze the lives of his fellow Superstars, leaving a scorched path of destruction behind his fiery footsteps. Some of The Big Red Monster\u2019s more demented acts have included setting a WWE Hall of Famer on fire, hitting a WWE executive with a Tombstone, kidnapping too many Superstars to mention and forcing a WWE Diva to marry him. No one is safe from his twisted desires and demonic impulses. Least of all, it would seem, Kane himself.\n\nFor years, the sadistic Superstar wore a ghoulish face mask designed to conceal hideous burns from a fire supposedly started by Undertaker years before. But WWE fans received a shock on one of the most infamous nights of Kane\u2019s career when,\u00ad after losing a Mask vs. Championship Match on Raw, the tortured soul was forced to unmask and reveal his face to the world.\n\nKane\u2019s career has been marked by some stellar and brutally woeful contests in the ring against some of the biggest names in WWE, including The Undertaker, \u201cStone Cold\u201d Steve Austin, Shawn Michaels, Edge and others. He\u2019s also pioneered some of the most vicious stipulations of all time, including First Blood, Inferno, Stretcher and even Till Death Do Us Part Matches.\n\nLike his sibling, Kane wields a highly decorated mantle of WWE glory, including reigns as WWE Champion, World Heavyweight Champion and ECW Champion. He has shown near-unprecedented versatility in the tag team ranks as well, finding championship success with a litany of partners such as X-Pac, Big Show and even twice with The Deadman. Most notably, the famed Brothers of Destruction simultaneously held the World Tag Team Championships and WCW Tag Team Championships during the Alliance\u2019s Invasion.\n\nHidden beneath a mask in his earliest WWE haunts, Kane reverted to concealing his face under a scarlet leather shroud in late 2011, and it wasn't long before The Big Red Monster set his demonic sights on Daniel Bryan. Although the submission specialist got the best of his newfound rival at SummerSlam, he may have awakened a more uncontrollable fire in The Devil\u2019s Favorite Demon, provoking him to attack Josh Mathews and Zack Ryder in incidents that inevitably led The Big Red Monster to the last place anybody expected: anger management. \n\nBy order of Raw General Manager AJ Lee, The Devil\u2019s Favorite Demon joined Bryan in anger management classes, and it\u2019s safe to say progress was slow at first. Though Kane opened up about his tormented life during the first session, he still had a long way to go to reach inner peace, as he viciously chokeslammed David Otunga on Raw. Things were looking up for The Big Red Monster after his second week of therapy, when he and Bryan shared a friendly (albeit reluctant) embrace when the WWE Universe voted for them to \u201chug it out\u201d on Monday Night Raw. A few shoves later, however, and the pair had to be pulled apart by WWE officials before they did any major damage.\n\nIn a bold experiment, Kane and Bryan\u2019s counselor, Dr. Shelby, next forced these unhinged Superstars to join forces as a tag team. Oddly enough, this tactic proved effective when the tumultuous team became the WWE Tag Team Champions at Night of Champions 2012. The following night on Raw, Kane & Bryan again overcame their issues \u2014 and their opponents \u2014 to defend their championship gold for the first time as a tandem that would come to be known as Team Hell No. While a tournament was arranged to determine the No. 1 contenders to their titles, Team Hell No achieved their greatest victory on the Oct. 1 episode of Raw when they defeated WWE Champion CM Punk & Dolph Ziggler. Less than a month later, Cody Rhodes & Damien Sandow, aka Team Rhodes Scholars, became the new No. 1 contenders, punching their ticket to face Team Hell No at Hell in a Cell. Discord cost the champions the match but not the titles, as they fell to Team Rhodes Scholars via disqualification.\n\nThe team\u2019s infighting again proved to be its downfall at Survivor Series when an argument between the pair led to Kane\u2019s elimination from the Traditional Survivor Series Elimination Tag Team Match. Kane & Bryan soon found themselves united in the face of a common enemy, however, when Dean Ambrose, Seth Rollins and Roman Reigns (The Shield) invaded WWE and attacked the pair on multiple occasions. Fate later afforded Team Hell No an opportunity to face their tormentors when WWE Champion CM Punk\u2019s knee surgery forced him out of his WWE Title defense at WWE TLC 2012. Unfortunately, fate also led Kane to be planted through a ringside barrier by Roman Reigns as the NXT invaders clinched an unlikely victory at the December pay-per-view.\n\nThe year 2013 kicked off on a positive note, however, as Kane and Bryan's newfound cameraderie led them to pass their four-month follow-up with Dr. Shelby on the Jan. 14 Raw. Ironically enough, however, the good doctor himself lost his temper following an insult by Team Rhodes Scholars. The next week, Kane and Bryan officially graduated Shelby's program, initiating a mass hug between the Superstars, Shelby, Jerry Lawler, Michael Cole, Dr. Sampson, Justin Roberts and the entire WWE Universe.\n\nTeam Hell No followed up the good feelings with a successful title defense over Team Rhodes Scholars at the Royal Rumble, but weren\u2019t on the same page later that night in the Royal Rumble Match. After Bryan eliminated his own partner, the smaller of the champions found himself knocked out of the ring and into Kane\u2019s arms. The Big Red Monster, left with the decision of dropping his pal or placing him back in the bout, decided on the former. The fickle friends butted heads again in February when they fought each other for a spell during an Elimination Chamber Match to determine the No. 1 Contender for the World Heavyweight Championship, though they were both eliminated by Mark Henry and seemingly had mended fences by the March 4 edition of Raw.\n\nLater that week, however, tragedy struck Kane when his father, Paul Bearer, passed away. And when CM Punk disrespected the memory of The Father of Destruction on the March 11 Raw, Kane took it upon himself to honor his father by defeating Punk in a brutal No Disqualification Match with aid from The Undertaker. The victory was ultimately marred when Punk attacked Kane with Bearer's sacred urn and absconded with it as Raw went off the air. Kane's frustration spilled over into the next week, although fate happily presented him an outlet for his anger: A tag title defense against Dolph Ziggler & Big E Langston at WrestleMania 29. \n\nThat outlet turned out to be just what The Big Red Monster needed. Despite the constant meddling of their ex-flame AJ Lee, Kane and Daniel Bryan persevered against The Showoff and his muscle, retaining their titles. The next night, they united with The Undertaker to drive back The Shield from a potential attack on The Phenom, but the \"Hounds of Justice\" retaliated two weeks later with a victory over Kane, Bryan and The Undertaker in London.\n\nStill very much in tune with his twisted dark side, Kane can still lock the WWE Universe in the grip of his grim black glove and leave the landscape of sports-entertainment in ember-laden ash, and woe be to the Superstar who forgets it.","category":"Athlete","company_overview":"Kane stats:\nHeight: 7 foot\nWeight: 326 pounds\nSignature Move: Chokeslam\nCareer Highlights: WWE Champion; Intercontinental Champion; World Tag Team Champion; WCW Tag Team Champion; Hardcore Champion\n","is_published":true,"talking_about_count":41398,"website":"http:\/\/www.wwe.com\/superstars","were_here_count":0,"id":"10270726229","name":"Kane - WWE Universe","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Kane-WWE-Universe\/10270726229","likes":4079172,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151612852611230","source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-prn2\/s720x720\/1236197_10151612852611230_1684651947_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"OFFICIAL ATHLETE PAGE \/\/ Rob Machado   http:\/\/www.robmachado.com","birthday":"10\/16\/1973","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"","city":"Cardiff-by-the-Sea","state":"CA","country":"United States","zip":""},"personal_info":"Rob Machado is not just one of the world\u2019s greatest surfers; he\u2019s one of the sport\u2019s most recognizable characters, a living icon who continues to expand the definition of what professional surfing is all about. Known for his Zen-like flow both on land and in the water, Machado was consistently seeded at the top of the rankings as a competitor on the ASP World Tour. His world-title-deciding heat at Pipeline against close friend Kelly Slater in 1995 remains perhaps the most dramatic \u2013 and uplifting \u2013 showdowns in competitive surfing history. With 12 career WCT victories, Machado was ranked among the top ten surfers for eleven straight years and was inducted into the Surfers Hall of Fame in 2000 and re-inducted in 2006.\n\n       But his contribution to the sport doesn\u2019t end with his accolades in a colored jersey. Since his departure from the ASP tour in 2001, Machado has been one of surfing\u2019s most committed ambassadors, roaming the globe, surfing the world\u2019s best waves and broadening the definition of high-performance surfing. From reinventing tube riding in the depths of Indo to blowing minds on the finless, wooden planks known as alaias, Machado is often seen as a modern-day Gerry Lopez: A true embodiment of style and aloha. \n\n       Rob\u2019s \u2018style\u2019 when he is not surfing is another admirable quality, as seen in his commitment to supporting various charitable causes. Rob has established The Rob Machado Foundation, which through his annual golf tournament supports various charities dedicated to environmental programs within Southern California. His foundation also works closely with the Cardiff Education Foundation on efforts to green Machado\u2019s hometown\u2019s elementary school district. He has also created the Rob Machado Surf Experience, a highly anticipated surf contest for girls and boys 16 and under in Rob\u2019s hometown of Cardiff-by-the Sea, California.\n\nRob\u2019s goodwill does not stop on the local-level, as this surf legend has also donated his time for an Indonesian well digging project with the Sumba Foundation, and for the Water Innovation Now (WIN) contest, which gave 500,000 kids the opportunity to come up with innovative ways to conserve our water as a result of Southern California\u2019s water crisis.\n\n       All of this \u2013 along with his down-to-earth, approachable aura \u2013 makes Machado one of surfing\u2019s most influential athletes of all time. And since he\u2019s still writing his incredible story, it\u2019s an influence that will only grow over time. \n\n","personal_interests":"family, surfing, music, golf, ping pong...","talking_about_count":549,"username":"RobMachadoSurf","website":"www.robmachado.com www.robmachadofoundation.org www.facebook.com\/RobMachadoFoundation ","were_here_count":0,"id":"106579103550","name":"Rob Machado","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/RobMachadoSurf","likes":219355,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151214186698551","source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash2\/522466_10151214186698551_1580742165_n.jpg","offset_y":45,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar Chris Jericho.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"There is one thing you can say about Chris Jericho \u2014 the guy knows how to make an entrance.\n\nDuring the summer of 1999, a millennium clock began counting down on Raw. WWE fans spent weeks wondering what the timer was leading to before getting an answer on Aug. 9 when the clock struck zero and Y2J appeared. Audaciously interrupting The Rock, the confident new competitor immediately announced himself as a performer who wasn\u2019t afraid to make a statement.\n\nSome people would crack under the hype of such a big debut. Jericho exceeded it. Over the next decade, The Ayatollah of Rock 'n' Rolla grabbed a record nine Intercontinental Titles, multiple Slammy Awards and the distinction of being the first Undisputed Champion in WWE history \u2014 an achievement he never fails to mention.\n\nSon of former NHL standout Ted Irvine, Jericho was born in Manhasset, N.Y., but raised in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. A wrestling fan from an early age, he trained in the famed Hart Family Dungeon and made his ring debut against Lance Storm when he was only 19. Starting out in the frigid armories of Canada, Jericho went on to perform across the globe in places like Mexico and Japan, infusing different international styles into his repertoire along the way. By the time he reached WCW in 1996, his loyal band of \u201cJerichoholics\u201d was growing rapidly.\n\nThe cocky competitor found success in WCW, winning the Cruiserweight and Television Titles on multiple occasions, but he soon grew frustrated with the locker room politicking that plagued the company. Sensing a brighter future in WWE, Jericho broke the walls down on Raw with a thrilling debut in 1999.\n\nHis place in WWE history was cemented on Dec. 9, 2001 at Vengeance, when he beat The Rock for the WCW Championship and \"Stone Cold\" Steve Austin for the WWE Championship on the same night, unifying both titles to become the first-ever Undisputed WWE Champion.\n\nMore big matches followed, but Jericho was forced out of WWE in August 2005 after losing a \u201cYou're Fired!\u201d Match to then-WWE Champion John Cena on Raw. During that two-year hiatus, Jericho pursued acting, toured with his heavy metal band Fozzy and penned the story of his career, \u201cA Lion's Tale: Around the World in Spandex.\u201d\n\nAfter a lengthy 2007 video campaign that foretold of a Superstar that would \u201cSave Us,\u201d Jericho came back again with a chip on his shoulder. Upset at WWE brass for passing him over for World Title opportunities, he went so far as to call his treatment a \"conspiracy.\" But while his attitude changed, his ability didn\u2019t. He won the World Heavyweight Championship for the third time at No Way Out in 2010 and enjoyed successful tag team runs with Edge and Big Show.\n\nJericho disappeared from WWE rings again after being punted in the head by Randy Orton, but he made a fiery return to Raw in January 2012. Following weeks of cryptic vignettes that warned, \u201cThe end begins on 1-2-12,\u201d the man who calls himself \u201cThe Best in the World at What He Does\u201d appeared out of the darkness in a jacket made of lights and bucked expectations by energetically running around the ring for 10 minutes, but never speaking a word. WWE fans didn\u2019t know quite what to make of Y2J\u2019s behavior, but Chris Jericho is nothing if not unpredictable. \n\nY2J eventually revealed that he returned to vanquish WWE of Superstars he believed to be ripping him off, namely CM Punk, who had taken to calling himself \"The Best in the World.\" Jericho's attack on Punk was extremely personal, taking shots at the WWE Champion's family. Y2J tried to wrest the belt away from Punk at WrestleMania XXVIII and in a Chicago Street Fight at Extreme Rules, but came up short. Undeterred by his losses to The Straight Edge Superstar, Jericho rebounded to notch the biggest victory of his WWE comeback when he showed up The Showoff, Dolph Ziggler, at SummerSlam in front of a sold-out STAPLES Center crowd.\n\nJericho's resurgence was short-lived, however, as he agreed to put his WWE contract on the line against Ziggler for The Showoff's Money in the Bank contract the very next night on Raw. The Mental Mastermind's decision wound up costing him dearly, with a hard-fought defeat to Ziggler putting an end to Jericho's seven-month run of 2012.\n\nBut as quickly as Jericho departed, he broke the walls down once again. To the shock of the Phoenix crowd, Y2J entered as the No. 2 entrant in the 2013 Royal Rumble Match. Standing face to face with No. 1 entrant Ziggler, Jericho and his longtime foe battled deep into the 30-man classic with the Fozzy frontman eventually being eliminated by Ziggler.\n\nFollowing his return at Royal Rumble, Jericho crossed paths with dancing Superstar Fandango \u2014 who refuses to step inside the ring until his name is pronounced correctly (it\u2019s FAHN-DAHN-GO). Y2J humorously mangled the pronunciation, resulting in an attack by Fandango that Jericho later reciprocated. As a result, WWE's first-ever Undisputed Champion took on the dancing competitor at WrestleMania 29.\n\nIn their Show of Shows tango, it was Fandango who shocked the WWE Universe by defeating the six-time World Champion in his very first competitve match. Jericho, a ring veteran, told WWE.com that the ball was now in his extravagant opponent's court, that it was up to him to run with it.\n\nIn the weeks following The Show of Shows, it became clear that the animosity between Y2J and Fandango was far from settled. In a battle against World Heavyweight Champion Dolph Ziggler on Raw, Jericho was distracted by the dancing Superstar's music and Ziggler capitalized for the win. Later that same evening, Jericho retaliated by tossing his nemesis off the entrance stage and relived his days on \u201cDancing With the Stars\u201d by tangoing with Fandango\u2019s dance partner.","category":"Athlete","company_overview":"Chris Jericho stats\nHeight: 6 foot\nWeight: 231 pounds\nFrom: Manhasset, N.Y.\nSignature Move: The Codebreaker; The Walls of Jericho; Lionsault\nCareer Highlights: WWE Championship; WCW Championship; Intercontinental Championship; European Championship; Hardcore Championship; World Tag Team Championship; ECW TV Championship; WCW TV Championship; WCW Cruiserweight Championship\n","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"","city":"Winnipeg","state":"MB","country":"Canada","zip":""},"talking_about_count":24071,"website":"http:\/\/www.wwe.com\/superstars\/smackdown\/chrisjericho\/bio\/?cid=FSL","were_here_count":0,"id":"8122075826","name":"Chris Jericho - WWE Universe","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Chris-Jericho-WWE-Universe\/8122075826","likes":1391139,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151875778315827","source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-prn1\/s720x720\/537202_10151875778315827_635760439_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"Thanks for checking out my page and being a fan!  The updates will be added by me and my team here, so we hope you enjoy them. ","affiliation":"Philadelphia Phillies","birthday":"12\/17\/1978","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"","city":"Philadelphia","state":"PA","country":"United States","zip":""},"personal_info":"Chase Utley was born on December 17, 1978, in Pasadena, CA. He was a tremendous baseball player growing up, spending countless hours playing wiffleball to perfect his swing. Chase played his high school baseball at Long Beach Poly High School, and was able to stay close to home when he was offered a scholarship to play for UCLA. In 2000, Utley burst onto the national scene when he was named Outstanding Player of the NCAA Regionals.\n\nAfter that season Chase was selected in the first round (15th overall) by the Philadelphia Phillies and began his journey through the minors. Chase worked his way all the way up through the Phillies farm system, with stints with the Batavia Muckdogs (A-Short Season) in 2000, the Clearwater Phillies (A) in 2001, and the Scranton\/Wilkes-Barre Red Barons (AAA) in 2002-03. In 2003, Chase split time between AAA and the majors but performed well when he got his shot in the big show. He recorded his first hit, a grand-slam, in his first big league start, and by the end of the season Utley was a regular in the Phillies line up.\n\n2006 was a break-out year for Chase Utley. He began the season playing in the inaugural World Baseball Classic, as the starting second baseman for Team USA. While the team didn\u2019t capture the gold, Utley got the year off to a good start by hitting .385 during the tournament. Chase carried that momentum into the 2006 season where he had a career year. During 2006 he hit .309, drove in over 100 runs, stole 15 bases, and hit 32 home runs, numbers that were good enough to make him the starting second baseman during the all-star game. Utley also grabbed national headlines during his 35-game hitting streak, the second longest in Phillies\u2019 history. His stellar play during the middle of the season was enough to make him the National League\u2019s Player of the Month for July.\n\nThe Phillies weren\u2019t able to make the playoffs in 2006, but that didn\u2019t end the year for Utley. He was selected for an all-star squad that traveled to Japan to play in a series against an all-star team made up of Japanese players. The American squad led by Utley and his Philadelphia teammate Ryan Howard swept the Japanese squad, capping a fantastic 2006 for Chase.\nIn 2007, Chase began the season on a roll and was selected by fans to be the starting second basemen in the 2007 MLB All-Star Game, his second such honor. After missing part of the season due to a broken bone in his hand, Chase returned to the Phillies lineup. In his first game back, he hit a home run and an RBI double and went 3 for 5. He finished the season with a .332 batting average, 22 home runs, 103 RBIs, and 48 doubles. Chase also led the Phillies to their first playoff appearance in 14 seasons. He earned the Silver Slugger Award for the second consecutive season.\n\nWhen the 2008 season rolled around, Chase picked up where he had left off in 2007. In the month of April, he hit a league-leading eleven home runs and was named the National League\u2019s Player of the Month. After going through a midseason slump, Chase broke out of the slump with a 4-for-5 performance in a 4\u20130 shutout over the Oakland Athletics. {"category":"Athlete","description":"Larry Joe Bird is an American former professional basketball player and coach and the current team president of the Indiana Pacers of the National Basketball Association . Drafted into the NBA sixth overall by the Boston Celtics in 1978, Bird started at small forward and power forward for thirteen seasons, spearheading one of the NBA's most formidable frontcourts that included center Robert Parish and forward Kevin McHale. Bird was a 12-time NBA All-Star and was named the league's Most Valuable Player three times. He played his entire professional career for Boston, winning three NBA championships and two NBA Finals MVP awards.Due to chronic back problems, he retired as a player in 1992. He was a member of the Dream Team that won the gold medal at the 1992 Summer Olympics. Bird was voted to the NBA's 50th Anniversary All-Time Team in 1996 and inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 1998. He served as head coach of the Indiana Pacers from 1997 to 2000. In 2003, he assumed the role of president of basketball operations for the Pacers, holding the position until retiring in 2012. After a year away from the position, he announced he would return to the Pacers as president of basketball operations in 2013. In addition to being part of the 50\u201340\u201390 Club, he is the only person in NBA history to be named Most Valuable Player, Coach of the Year, and Executive of the Year.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":354,"website":"http:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=6owRYSf9llMC&lpg=PA57&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false","were_here_count":0,"id":"104080469629941","name":"Larry Bird","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Larry-Bird\/104080469629941","likes":421775}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Franklin \"Frank\" Delano Gore is an American football running back for the San Francisco 49ers of the National Football League . He played college football for the University of Miami, and was drafted by the 49ers in the third round of the 2005 NFL Draft.Throughout his eight-year NFL career, Gore has often been ranked among the best and most respected running backs playing the game, having been selected to four Pro Bowls and achieving four straight seasons with 1,000 rushing yards, among his 6 total. While achieving some personal success, he struggled with a team that suffered numerous losing seasons until he and the 49ers achieved a 13-3 record in the 2011 season under new head coach Jim Harbaugh. In 2011, the 49ers won the NFC West division and reached the NFC championship game. In 2012, Gore helped lead the 49ers to Super Bowl XLVII. On December 30, 2012, Gore became the 49ers all-time leader in rushing touchdowns with 51.Early yearsGore was born in Miami, Florida, and grew up in Coconut Grove, Florida. He attended Coral Gables High School, where he excelled as a running back. He had two notable record-breaking games. Against Miami Northwestern High School, he had a then career high 293 yards and two touchdowns on 10 carries. In the next game, he broke that record with 319 yards and six touchdowns on 13 carries against number 3 ranked defense in the nation. During his senior year in 2000, Gore broke several Dade County single-season records, including rushing yards (2,997) and touchdowns (39). Heavily recruited, he was named the No. 1 prospect in Dade County by The Miami Herald, as well as No. 4 in Florida and No. 5 nationally.
