{"about":"Page Facebook Officiel de Raphael Varane - Site www.raphael-varane.net","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"talking_about_count":13263,"username":"raphaelvaraneofficiel","website":"http:\/\/www.raphael-varane.net","were_here_count":0,"id":"378423305523825","name":"Rapha\u00ebl Varane Officiel","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/raphaelvaraneofficiel","likes":468693,"cover":{"cover_id":665983080101178,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash3\/s720x720\/1460147_665983080101178_1316138826_n.jpg","offset_y":40,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"This is the Official Fan Page of Nonito \"Filipino Flash\" Donaire Jr.  Please send your pics w Nonito to fan\u0040filipinoflash.com  Add Flash to your network: Twitter: \u0040filipinoflash YouTube.com\/theofficialflash","affiliation":"Top Rank Boxing","birthday":"11\/16\/1982","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"    * WBA interim super flyweight world champion...\n    * World championship fights: 4-0, 4 KOs...\n    * Interim world championship fights: 1-0, 0 KOs\n    * Former IBF flyweight world champion, three successful defenses...\n    * Former NABF super flyweight champion...\n    * The Ring \"2007 Knockout of the Year\" - Donaire KO5 Darchinyan...\n    * The Ring \"2007 Upset of the Year\" - Donaire KO5 Darchinyan...\n    * 2000 U.S. National Championships (amateur), 106 pounds - Gold Medalist...\n    * 2000 National Junior Olympic Championships (amateur), 106 pounds - Gold Medalist...\n    * 1999 Junior Olympics International Championships (amateur), 106 pounds - Gold Medalist\n\nAt the age of 27, Nonito is a nine-year pro. The WBA interim super flyweight world champion, he won the title in August, 2009, and has made one successful defense.\n\nHe is also a former IBF flyweight world champion - he won the title in July, 2007, and made three successful title defenses. He vacated the title to move up in weight.\n\nNonito has an exceptional combination of skill, power, and speed, and is considered by most observers to be one of the top fighters at any weight in the ring today - one of the  best \"Pound for Pound.\"\n\nHe is coming off a third-round knockout win against former WBO interim mini-flyweight world champion Manuel Vargas in his last fight in February, 2010.\n\nAfter the fight, Dan Rafael wrote on ESPN.com [excerpts]: With his country's hero Manny Pacquiao at ringside, Donaire...took care of business in devastating fashion. Donaire, one of the top pound-for-pound fighters in boxing, expected to defend his interim 115-pound belt against Mexico's Gerson Guerrero. However, Guerrero fell out of the fight...when he failed a prefight eye exam. Vargas, also of Mexico, was brought in on short notice....\n\nVargas was game, though. He did his best but simply could not handle Donaire's size and strength. It was just a matter of time until Donaire put him out of his misery, which came in the third round. That's when Donaire drilled him with a huge left uppercut midway through the round. Vargas went down on a delayed reaction and could not beat the count....\n\nIt was an explosive and exciting performance from Donaire.... [End Rafael item]\n\nNonito won the IBF flyweight world title in July, 2007, with a spectacular, devastating one-punch knockout against previously undefeated defending champion Vic Darchinyan. The knockout was so devastating that during his post-fight interview, Darchinyan didn't seem to realize he had just been knocked out.\n\nBoxing News reported [excerpts]: Darchinyan...was caught with a left hook that was reminiscent of the perfect punch Sugar Ray Robinson used to knock out Gene Fullmer 50 years ago. What should not be forgotten is how well Donaire fought up the point of the stoppage. [End Boxing News item]\n\nThe fight won The Ring's annual awards for \"2007 Knockout of the Year\" and \"2007 Upset of the Year.\"\n\nNonito had an impressive amateur career, as well, which included wins against Ron Siler, who made the 2004 U.S. Olympic team, and current pro jr. middleweight prospect James Kirkland.\n\nRegarding his nickname, Nonito said, \"I got my name because I was pretty fast. Like in the gym, I was a lot faster than my brother or other fighters. They started calling me that around my fourth, fifth fight.\"\n\nFight by Fight - 2010 - in his last fight on 2-13-10 in Las Vegas, NV, he knocked out former WBO interim mini-flyweight world champion and late substitute Manuel Vargas (26-4-1): Nonito was originally scheduled to defend the WBA title against Gerson Guerrero, but Guerrero failed his eye exam; Vargas took the fight on short notice, and it was changed to a nontitle fight; Nonito quickly overpowered Vargas - he scored a knockdown with a left uppercut in the 3rd round, and Vargas was counted out at 1:33; after the fight, Nonito said, \"It didn't matter who I was fighting. I was able to figure him out early, and I knew in the first round he was feeling my power. At that point, it was just a matter of relaxing and not being careless.\"...\n\n2009 - WON WBA INTERIM S-FL WORLD TITLE - on 8-15-09 in Las Vegas he won a 12 round unanimous decision against Rafael Concepcion (13-3-1): the fight headlined at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino; Concepcion weighed in at 119.5 pounds, 4.5 pounds over the 115-pound limit, and was not eligible to win the title; Concepcion pressed forward, but Nonito boxed and moved well and built an early lead - he swept the first four rounds on two scorecards, and won three of the first four on the other; Nonito cut Concepcion over his left eye in the 2nd round, but also injured his left hand in the round; Concepcion rallied in the middle rounds - he won the 5th and 6th rounds on two scorecards, swept the 7th on all three, then won the 9th round on two scorecards; but Nonito finished the fight strongly - he sept the 10th and 11th rounds and won the 12th on two scorecards, and won by scores of 117-111, 116-112, 115-113; after the fight, Nonito said, \"I was confident in my power and I thought I could take him out, but he turned out to be a little bit tougher than I expected. I thought I was going to be able to take him out with my power punches and he ran into them, but he was absolutely a lot bigger than I was, and that was absolutely the key factor in this fight. If he was 115, he would have went down early with all the shots I hit him with. I thought I fought a good, smart fight and that I was in control. I'm very pleased.\"...\n\n3RD IBF FL WORLD TITLE DEFENSE - on 4-19-09 in Manila, PH, he TKO'd previously undefeated Raul Martinez (24-0): the fight headlined at Araneta Coliseum, and Nonito domoinated; he scored two knockdowns in the 1st round - the first with a left uppercut, the second with a right hand; he scored another knockdown with a right hand in the 2nd round; Nonito scored another knockdown with a left uppercut in the 4th round, and the referee stopped the fight at 2:42; after three rounds, Nonito led by scores of 30-24 on all three scorecards; after the fight, Nonito said, \"I knew if I hit him, I would hurt him. He sits on his punches, he's right there.\"...\n\n2008 - 1ST IBF FL WORLD TITLE DEFENSE - on 11-1-08 in Las Vegas, NV, he TKO'd Moruti Mthalane (22-1): the bout was co-featured with the Chavez Jr.-Vanda main event at Mandalay Bay, and it was an exciting fight; Mthalane gave a good effort and several rounds were close, but Nonito had the edge in most of them; he cut Mthalane badly over his right eye with a right hand in the 6th round, and the referee stopped the fight on the cut at 1:31; after five rounds, Nonito led by scores of 49-46, 49-46, 48-47; Nonito later said he broke the little finger on his left hand when he hit Mthalane on the elbow in the 2nd round...\n\n2007 - 1ST IBF FL WORLD TITLE DEFENSE - on 12-1-07 in Mashantucket, CT, he TKO'd Luis Maldonado (37-1-1): Nonito dominated the fight; he outboxed Maldonado, consistently landed the harder punches, and cut Maldonado over both of his eyes in the 2nd round; Nonito scored a knockdown with a left hook late in the 7th round then rocked Maldonado with a series of punches in the 8th, and the referee stopped the fight at 1:16; after seven rounds, Nonito led by scores of 70-62, 70-62, 69-63...\n\nWON IBF FL WORLD TITLE - on 7-7-07 in Bridgeport, CT, he TKO'd previously undefeated lefthanded defending champion Vic Darchinyan (28-0): it was a spectacular, devastating one-punch knockout; Nonito dominated most of the fight - he started fast and outworked Darchinyan in the early rounds and staggered him twice with left hooks late in the 3rd; Darchinyan rallied and landed a couple of hard left hands early in the 4th round, but Nonito scored a knockdown with a left hook midway through the 5th round that dropped Darchinyan flat on his back and bloodied his nose - he got up, but stumbled across the ring and fell face-first into the ropes, and the referee stopped the fight as Darchinyan's corner entered the ring at 0:38; after four rounds, the judges scored 40-36 Donaire, 38-38, 38-38; after the fight, Nonito said, \"I felt great in there tonight. I came in here as an underdog. Nobody believed in me,  but I did it. I said yesterday that one punch can make a difference between me and him. I think the key for me in tonight's fight was every time Darchinyan threw and landed, I punched back and that got him thinking. It took the bully out of him. I've fought guys who were heavier than Darchinyan, so I timed my shots. He has heavy hands, but my brother told me he's not as tough as he thinks he is. I shut him up and he still wouldn't admit in the ring after the fight that I beat him. I feel so unbelievably great, it hasn't even dawned on me yet what I have accomplished. This fight wasn't just for me. It was for my family and the Filipino people, too. I could feel their energy tonight.  I felt so good in the ring.\"...\n\nOn 5-12-07 in Reno, NV, he TKO'd Kevin Hudgins (5-9): Nonito staggered Hudgins a few times in the 1st round, and the referee stopped the fight at 2:29; after the fight, Nonito said, \"The first minute, I was rusty. I felt the rust. I got my way through it. The way my power is, all I have to do is get in shape. I heard he was very durable. It did worry me a little, but I did what I had to do.\"...\n\n2006 - 1ST NABF S FL TITLE DEFENSE - on 10-7-06 in Las Vegas he won a 12 round unanimous decision against Oscar Andrade (35-24-1): the fight was on the undercard of the Joel Casamayor-Diego Corrales main event and the Vic Darchinyan-Glenn Donaire co-feature at Mandalay Bay; Nonito built an early lead - he scored a knockdown in the 2nd round and swept the first three rounds on all three scorecards, but was cut over his right eye by a clash of heads in the 4th; Nonito then swept the 5th and 6th rounds, but Andrade had a few rallies in the second half of the fight - he swept the 7th round and won the 8th on two scorecards, then swept the 10th round, as well; but Nonito swept the 9th, 11th, and 12th, and won by scores of 118-109, 116-111, 116-111...\n\nOn 7-29-06 in Santa Ynez, CA, he TKO'd Jose Cardenas (5-6-1): Nonito scored two knockdowns in the 2nd round - the first with a left hook, the second with a right hand; Cardenas got up both times but was unsteady, and the referee stopped the fight at 1:48...\n\nWON VACANT NABF S-FL TITLE - on 1-20-06 in Temecula, CA, he won a 10 round split decision against Kahren Harutyunyan (13-2-3): it was a good fight; Nonito scored a knockdown in the 2nd round, but Harutyunyan came back and rocked Nonito in the 3rd and several rounds were close; Harutyunyan rallied and outworked Nonito in the last two rounds, but Nonito won by scores of 97-92, 97-92 Donaire, 95-94 Harutyunyan; after the fight, Nonito said he hurt his left hand; \"It's the same kind of cartilage injury I suffered in my last fight. I was in a lot of pain, especially after the seventh round. It made for me being off balance for a lot of the fight. I couldn't use my left hand as much as I wanted, but I knew I had to keep trying to use it and fight through the pain. I give Kahren a lot of credit. He is a really nice guy and fought his heart out, but I definitely thought I won the fight.\"...\n\n2005 - on 11-5-05 in Stateline, NV, he won an 8 round unanimous decision against Ilido Julio (33-6-1): the fight was on the undercard of the Jeff Lacy-Scott Pemberton main event, and Nonito dominated; Julio pressed forward, but Nonito boxed and counterpunched effectively, and Julio was penalized one point in the 4th round for low blows; scored 79-70 on all three scorecards...\n\nOn 10-1-05 in Reno, NV, he knocked out Daniel Gonzalez (3-1): the fight was on the undercard of the James Toney-Dominick Guinn main event; Nonito scored two knockdowns in the 1st round, and Gonzalez was counted out at 2:19...\n\nOn 7-2-05 in Las Vegas he won a 6 round unanimous decision against Larry Olvera (5-4-1): the fight was on the undercard of the Samuel Peter-Taurus Sykes main event; Nonito was very impressive - he scored one knockdown in the 1st round and another in the 2nd, and won by scores of 60-52, 59-53, 59-53...\n\nOn 5-13-05 in San Jose, CA, he TKO'd late substitute Paulino Villalobos (23-29-2): Villalobos took the fight on one day's notice; he pressed forward and gave a good effort, but Nonito dominated the fight; he consistently outworked Villalobos and landed the harder punches; he cut Villalobos over the left eye in the 4th round and over the right eye in the 5th, and the referee stopped the fight after the 6th round...\n\n2004 - on 11-12-04 in Montebello, CA, he won an 8 round unanimous decision against Gilberto Bolanos (3-6-1): Nonito scored two knockdowns in the first round and dominated the fight; scored 80-70, 79-71, 79-71; after the fight, Nonito said, \"He was a tough guy. I give him credit. I could not believe he would get up from the knockdowns. I wanted to knock him out, but a win is a win. I'm happy with the victory, but I was disappointed that I wasn't able to finish him off. I want to stay at 115 pounds. I'm confident in my power for a fighter my size.\"...\n\nOn 6-18-04 in Montebello he TKO'd Ricardo Barrera (16-4-1): Barrera started to swell around his eyes in the 1st round; the swelling worsened as the fight progressed, and the referee stopped the fight on the injury after the 4th round; after the fight, Nonito said, \"He is a tough guy with a big heart. I was surprised he didn't go down from my punches. To be the second person after Rafael Marquez to score a knockout over Barrera is an honor, because Marquez is such a great fighter. I'm very happy with my performance tonight.\"...\n\n2003 - on 6-27-03 in Vallejo, CA, he TKO'd Jorge Lopez (2-6-1): at 1:43 of the 1st round...\n\n2002 - on 11-2-02 in Taguig, PHIL, he won an 8 round unanimous decision against Mark Sales (6-14-2)...\n\nOn 9-1-02 in Guam he knocked out Kaichon Sor Vorapin (3-4): in the 2nd round...\n\nOn 5-31-02 in Paranaque City, PHIL, he knocked out Noel Alma (debut): in the 1st round...\n\n2001 - on 7-3-01 in Monterey, CA, he TKO'd Jose Luis Torres (0-3): at 0:30 of the 1st round...\n\nOn 6-8-01 in Inglewood, CA, he won a 4 round unanimous decision agianst Salvador Santoya (debut): scored 40-34 on all three scorecards...\n\nOn 3-10-01 in Vallejo he lost a 5 round unanimous decision against Rosendo Sanchez (2-1)...\n\nAMATEUR, PERSONAL BACKGROUND: Nonito said, \"I was born in Bohol, Philippines. I was 10 years old when we moved to the States. I have two brothers and one sister. Glenn is three years older than me, he's the eldest of the family. [note: Glenn Donaire was an accomplished amateur who also competed in the 2000 Olympic Trials, and is now a professional]...\n\n            \"Glenn started boxing before I did, about a year, and he was bringing trophies and getting attention from everybody. It was really cool, how he felt, how the smile was on his face, and I wanted to bring that smile to everybody - I wanted to bring some of my accomplishments, too. I was 11 when I got started, and I've been hooked.\n\n\"My dad had never trained anybody before us. We were his first fighters. He fought, he was in karate, boxing, all kind of martial arts, he was in the military in the Philippines. It was more of a street-fight thing. But he had never trained anybody. He didn't hardly know how to do anything. The first night that we did mitts with him it was so awkward, so funny, that we just started cracking up right in the middle of the ring. Eventually, we stepped it up and he went way beyond the other coaches' talent.\n\n\"I had 68 wins and eight losses as an amateur. I was in the Nationals every year, I fought with the best at that time. The only international I fought was for the JOs International in Puebla, Mexico.\n\n\"I moved back to the Philippines for about a year, I think it was in 2001 to 2002. I've been back here in California since then.\"...\n\n            Nonito and Rachel Marcial were married on August 8, 2008, in a private ceremony at Stewart's Cove in Carmel, California...\n\nAMATEUR HIGHLIGHTS:\n\n2000 NATIONAL JUNIOR OLYMPICS, Marquette, Mich., 106 pounds - GOLD MEDALIST: in the quarterfinals on 6-23-00 he won a 5-0 decision against Manuel Perez of Denver, Colo.; in the semifinals on 6-24-00 he won on walkover against Dat Nguyen of of Woliluku, Hi.; in the finals on 6-25-00 he won a 3-2 decision against James Kirkland of Austin, Tex....\n\n2000 OLYMPIC TRIALS, Tampa, Fla., 106 pounds: in the quarterfinals on 2-9-00 he won a 19-7 decision against Ron Siler of Cincinnati, Oh. [note: four years later, Siler went on to make the 2004 U.S. Olympic team at 112 pounds]; in the semifinals on 2-10-00 he won a 16-3 decision against Bradley Martinez of Ft. Carson, Colo.\/Army; in the finals on 2-12-00 he lost an 8-6 decision against Brian Viloria of Waipahu, Hawaii; in the finals of the challengers' bracket on 2-13-00 he lost by walkover against Karoz Norman of St. Louis, Mo.; looking back, Nonito said, \"I was only 17 and I had a heartache, because I thought I won the fight against Brian Viloria. It was controversial, and knowing that my goal was in my grasp, just right there, it broke my heart. After the decision, people were booing and throwing chairs. It was a fight to remember. There was actually a protest, my brother did a protest, because he beat Viloria more than I ever did. He walked him down like he was nothing. They offered me a scholarship at Northern Michigan, but it was something I turned down. So I turned pro.\n\n\"If I had won the Challenge bracket, we would have to pay our own way to go to, I think it was Boston. We didn't have enough money to do that, so I didn't fight. I thought it was worthless. I had beat that guy in the Nationals in January. I stopped him in the third round. He was so happy, knowing that I wouldn't go in there with him. I knew I would lose by decision even if I won the fight. That happens too much in the amateurs.\"...\n\n2000 U.S. NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS, Colorado Springs, Colo., 106 pounds - GOLD MEDALIST: in his first fight on 1-12-00 in he won a 22-8 decision against Raul Martinez of San Antonio, Tex.; in the quarterfinals on 1-13-00 he stopped Robert Ceron of Doraville, Ga., at 0:49 of the 4th round; in the semifinals on 1-14-00 he stopped Karoz Norman of St. Louis, Mo., at 0:40 of the 3rd round; in the finals on 1-15-00 he won on walkover against Aaron Todd of Troup, Tex...\n\n1999 INTERNATIONAL JUNIOR OLYMPICS, Mexico City, Mexico, 106 pounds - GOLD MEDALIST: in the quarterfinals he drew a bye; in the semifinals he won a 6-0 decision against Miguel Lopez of Mexico; in the finals he won a 7-6 decision against Isidro Granados of Mexico...\n\nSTRENGTHS: Has good skills, speed, and movement...has good punching power in both hands...physically strong, is always in top condition...is experienced against top opposition...had a strong amateur background...\n\nPROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE: 24 fights...128 total rounds...23 world championship rounds...12 interim world championship rounds...\n\nAVERAGE LENGTH OF BOUTS: 5.3 rounds...\n\nKNOCKOUT PERCENTAGE: 65 \u0025...\n\nDISTANCE FIGHTS: 12 rounds - 2 (2-0)...10 rounds - 1 (1-0)...\n\nHe debuted at the age of 18 on 2-22-01 in Inglewood and knocked out Jose Lazaro (1-3-1): at 1:46 of the 1st round...","talking_about_count":4764,"username":"nonitodonaire","website":"www.FilipinoFlash.com","were_here_count":0,"id":"105584362039","name":"Nonito Donaire Jr.","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/nonitodonaire","likes":188297,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151571783317040","source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash3\/s720x720\/529390_10151571783317040_751258436_n.jpg","offset_y":19,"offset_x":0}}

It was there, that his cricketing talents were nourished by the Principal, G.L. Galappathy and coach Lionel Wagasinghe. Fastest 100 was taken away from him by Afridi but he still holds the fastest 50 and fastest 150. His party is the United People's Freedom Alliance (UPFA) of President Mahinda Rajapaksa. Jayasuriya says that he intends to continue playing cricket if he is elected. {"about":"Welcome to the Xavi Hern\u00e1ndez  Facebook Fan Page !","awards":"Premio Don Bal\u00f3n: Jugador revelaci\u00f3n de la Liga 1998-1999\nPremio Don Bal\u00f3n: Mejor jugador espa\u00f1ol de la Liga 2004-2005\nMejor jugador de la Eurocopa 2008\nEquipo ideal de la Eurocopa 2008\nMejor constructor de juego del mundo seg\u00fan la IFFHS: 2008, 2009, 2010\nXI Mundial FIFA-FIFPro: 2008, 2009, 2010\nEquipo del A\u00f1o de la UEFA: 2008, 2009, 2010\nMejor jugador de la Final de la UEFA Champions League 2008-09\nMejor centrocampista del a\u00f1o de la UEFA Champions League 2008-09\nBal\u00f3n de Bronce de la Copa Mundial de Clubes de la FIFA 2009\nPremios LFP: Mejor Mediocentro de la Liga BBVA 2009\nBal\u00f3n de Oro: Bal\u00f3n de Bronce 2009\nFIFA World Player: Tercer clasificado 2009\nEquipo ideal de la Copa del Mundo: 2010\nPremio World Soccer: Mejor jugador del mundo 2010\nFIFA Bal\u00f3n de Oro: Tercer clasificado 2010","bio":"(Xavier Hern\u00e1ndez Creus; Terrassa, 1980) Futbolista espa\u00f1ol perteneciente a la disciplina del F\u00fatbol Club Barcelona desde las categor\u00edas inferiores hasta su consolidaci\u00f3n en el primer equipo. El f\u00fatbol de toque de bal\u00f3n con jugadores de gran t\u00e9cnica que impuso el denominado Dream Team de Johan Cruyff ten\u00eda su gozne en este centrocampista de t\u00e9cnica depurada que protege el bal\u00f3n como nadie y \"lee\" con admirable sencillez el ritmo que debe adquirir el partido en cada fase del juego. Al t\u00e9rmino de la Eurocopa de 2008, que gan\u00f3 la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola por segunda vez en la historia, fue elegido Mejor Jugador del torneo, una distinci\u00f3n que raramente recae en un centrocampista y que reconoc\u00eda su fundamental aportaci\u00f3n. Xavi fue adem\u00e1s una pieza esencial en la consecuci\u00f3n del \"triplete\" del Bar\u00e7a (que gan\u00f3 en 2009 la Liga, la Copa del Rey y la Champions League) y en el triunfo de la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola en el Mundial de Sud\u00e1frica en 2010, en el que Espa\u00f1a se proclam\u00f3 por primera vez campeona del mundo.\n\n\nXavi Hern\u00e1ndez\n\nSu progenitor, que fue jugador del Sabadell, le inculc\u00f3 la pasi\u00f3n por el f\u00fatbol. Los ojeadores del F\u00fatbol Club Barcelona le siguieron en varios partidos infantiles de la ciudad egarense a instancias del padre. Por fin, a los once a\u00f1os, hizo una prueba y en julio de 1991 ingres\u00f3 en la Masia, la residencia de las futuras estrellas del Bar\u00e7a que no proceden de la Ciudad Condal. Xavi se fij\u00f3 de inmediato en su maestro Josep Guardiola, su actual entrenador y figura clave del Dream Team en aquel entonces. Mir\u00e1ndose en aquel espejo, su progresi\u00f3n fue tan mete\u00f3rica que el propio Guardiola, que un d\u00eda lo observaba desde la banda en un partido de juveniles, pronostic\u00f3 a sus compa\u00f1eros: \"\u00c9ste nos va a jubilar a todos\". M\u00e1s o menos as\u00ed ser\u00eda. Xavi se convirti\u00f3 en el sucesor natural de Guardiola, a pesar de que de la cantera surgir\u00edan otros excelentes organizadores que se vieron obligados a abandonar las filas del club, como Cesc F\u00e1bregas o Vlikel Arteta, que disputan la Premier League inglesa y escocesa, respectivamente.\n\nSu predisposici\u00f3n para aprender cosas, la madurez que irradiaba a tan corta edad y su calidad futbol\u00edstica propiciaron que en la temporada 1997-1998 pasara del juvenil al Barca B, en el que de inmediato se convirti\u00f3 en el \"cerebro\" del equipo. Un equipo en el que Xavi no s\u00f3lo mandaba y organizaba, sino que marcaba goles con facilidad gracias a sus inesperadas llegadas al \u00e1rea y a su maestr\u00eda en el lanzamiento de faltas con barrera. Ya entonces, a pesar de su baja estatura (1,70 m) y su menuda complexi\u00f3n (pesa 63 kilos cuando est\u00e1 en plena forma), ser\u00eda un maestro en la conducci\u00f3n del bal\u00f3n y en la protecci\u00f3n del mismo.\n\nEn la temporada siguiente altern\u00f3 sus actuaciones con el B y con el primer equipo, con el que debut\u00f3 el 18 de agosto de 1998 de la mano del t\u00e9cnico neerland\u00e9s Louis Van Gaal, en un partido de la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a ante el Real Mallorca. Fue titular y, adem\u00e1s, marc\u00f3 un gol. Van Gaal lo hizo debutar en la Liga el 3 de octubre de aquel mismo a\u00f1o en el Mestalla frente al Valencia, que cay\u00f3 derrotado por 1-3. Sus intermitentes actuaciones con el primer equipo dieron alas a un Bar\u00e7a alica\u00eddo que ocupaba la d\u00e9cima posici\u00f3n de la tabla. Xavi marc\u00f3 un gol decisivo que dio la victoria a su equipo en el campo del Valladolid, y a partir de aquella victoria, contando m\u00e1s asiduamente con su presencia, los azulgranas remontaron de forma tan espectacular que ganar\u00edan la Liga 1998-1999. Era su segundo t\u00edtulo profesional, porque poco antes hab\u00eda ganado el Campeonato del Mundo Sub-20 disputado en Nigeria.\n\n\n \nEn la temporada 1999-2000, debido a una lesi\u00f3n de Guardiola, Xavi se consolid\u00f3 en el primer equipo. Convencido de sus posibilidades, su juego madur\u00f3 exponencialmente. Entretanto, su estelar actuaci\u00f3n en Nigeria propici\u00f3 que el 15 de noviembre de 2000 debutara con la selecci\u00f3n absoluta ante los Pa\u00edses Bajos. Pocos a\u00f1os despu\u00e9s ya ser\u00eda convocado regularmente para defender los colores de Espa\u00f1a. A partir de la temporada 2000-2001, y con la marcha de Guardiola al calcio italiano, Xavi se convirti\u00f3 en titular indiscutible, tanto con Van Gaal como con los entrenadores subsiguientes: Carles Reixach, Radomir Antic y Frank Rijkaard. En el Barca, sin embargo, no alcanzar\u00eda su tercer t\u00edtulo, el de Liga, hasta el 14 de mayo de 2005, tras una marcha penosa del equipo y del club por un desierto de desprop\u00f3sitos. En verano del mismo a\u00f1o se proclam\u00f3 campe\u00f3n de la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a, t\u00edtulo que renovar\u00eda al a\u00f1o siguiente, en el que en el partido de vuelta marc\u00f3 un gol decisivo ante el Real Club Espa\u00f1ol, al que los azulgranas superaron por 3-0.\n\nHabitualmente las lesiones lo respetaban, por lo que siempre estuvo en forma cuando se requer\u00eda su participaci\u00f3n. S\u00f3lo cabe mencionar una rotura del ligamento cruzado anterior de la rodilla derecha en un entrenamiento en el Camp Nou, en diciembre de 2005. Aquel percance trunc\u00f3 su proyecci\u00f3n al obligarlo a estar ausente durante cinco meses, hasta finales de abril de 2006, fecha en que reapareci\u00f3 ante el C\u00e1diz C. F. Aquel a\u00f1o los azulgranas consiguieron de nuevo el t\u00edtulo de Liga y la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a. Pero el mayor momento de gloria de aquel a\u00f1o 2006 para un equipo que funcionaba como una m\u00e1quina (gracias al trabajo de Xavi y Andr\u00e9s Iniesta en la medular y las genialidades de Ronaldinho y Eto'o en la delantera) lleg\u00f3 con la victoria en la Liga de Campeones, la asignatura pendiente del Bar\u00e7a, que s\u00f3lo ten\u00eda en sus vitrinas la conseguida por el Dream Team en 1992. Xavi, sin embargo, no pudo participar en la final ante el Arsenal F. C. debido a su baja forma por la lesi\u00f3n.\n\n\nCelebrando junto a Iniesta la Champions 2009\n\nEn 2007, en el partido de Liga de Campeones ante el Olympique de Lyon, disputado el 19 de septiembre, Xavi igual\u00f3 a Migueli como jugador del F. C. Barcelona que m\u00e1s partidos hab\u00eda disputado en competiciones europeas (85). Y super\u00f3 al m\u00edtico central ceut\u00ed el 2 de octubre de aquel mismo a\u00f1o en un partido frente al VfB Stuttgart. La diferencia, por supuesto, seguir\u00eda aumentando. En cuanto a sus partidos con el Bar\u00e7a, el 24 de noviembre de 2007 y ante el club decano espa\u00f1ol, el Recreativo de Huelva, igual\u00f3 la cifra de 400 partidos oficiales que ostentaba Guardiola.\n\nPero sin el t\u00edtulo de Campe\u00f3n de Europa de Naciones de 2008, en la que Xavi explot\u00f3 al m\u00e1ximo unas cualidades que no prodigaba (pases en profundidad al delantero con mayor ventaja y chutes desde fuera del \u00e1rea), no habr\u00eda ocupado las primeras p\u00e1gina de la prensa. En esa Eurocopa, disputada en Austria y Suiza, el centrocampista azulgrana, adoctrinado por Luis Aragon\u00e9s, adelant\u00f3 su posici\u00f3n con \u00e9xito rotundo. Marc\u00f3 su primer gol el 26 de junio frente a Rusia. Y en la final ante Alemania, Xavi dio el pase de gol a Fernando Torres, quien marc\u00f3 el \u00fanico tanto del encuentro. Su actuaci\u00f3n en la Eurocopa le vali\u00f3 el premio al Mejor Jugador de la competici\u00f3n, una menci\u00f3n que habitualmente recae en un delantero goleador. Los medios de comunicaci\u00f3n, sin embargo, coincidieron en que era una elecci\u00f3n acertada. Adem\u00e1s de esta distinci\u00f3n mayor, Xavi hab\u00eda sido galardonado como el mejor futbolista de las temporadas 1998-1999 y 2004-2005 por la revista deportiva Don Bal\u00f3n, y ya en 1999 hab\u00eda recibido el premio El Pa\u00eds como futbolista revelaci\u00f3n.\n\n\nCon David Villa en la final de la Eurocopa 2008\n\nSi con la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola hab\u00eda vivido uno de los mejores momentos al ganar la Eurocopa, la temporada 2008-2009 le reservaba a\u00fan un destino superior: ser parte esencial, junto con Iniesta, de la organizaci\u00f3n del juego del F.C. Barcelona en la que fue sin duda la mejor temporada de la historia del club. El Bar\u00e7a, en efecto, logr\u00f3 algo tan ins\u00f3lito en el f\u00fatbol mundial como el \"triplete\", la victoria en los tres torneos en que participaba: la Liga espa\u00f1ola, la Copa del Rey y la Champions League. El juego exhibido por el equipo maravill\u00f3 a todo el mundo; por supuesto que fue el nuevo entrenador, su admirado Josep Guardiola, el principal art\u00edfice de esa revoluci\u00f3n, pero tales \u00e9xitos no son concebibles sin organizadores de la talla de Iniesta y del propio Xavi.\n\nLa temporada 2009-2010 sum\u00f3 su quinto t\u00edtulo liguero a su palmar\u00e9s, tras una re\u00f1id\u00edsima competici\u00f3n en la que el F\u00fatbol Club Barcelona y el Real Madrid alcanzaron registros vertiginosos tanto en goles como en puntos, ganando 31 de los 38 partidos disputados. El Bar\u00e7a, que se anot\u00f3 tambi\u00e9n la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a, no pudo sin embargo revalidar su victoria en la Champions League al caer en semifinales.\n\nFinalizada la temporada, el Mundial de Sud\u00e1frica de 2010 deparar\u00eda a Xavi el \u00faltimo t\u00edtulo que le quedaba por ganar. Pese a la decepcionante derrota inicial frente a Suiza, la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola entrenada por Vicente del Bosque se mantuvo fiel a su estilo, y de la mano de Xavi y de sus restantes cerebros centrocampistas (Iniesta, Xabi Alonso, Cesc F\u00e0begras) encaden\u00f3 una victoria tras otra hasta derrotar a Alemania en las semifinales y a Holanda en la final. Por primera vez, despu\u00e9s de d\u00e9cadas \u201csin pasar de cuartos\u201d, Espa\u00f1a se proclamaba campeona del mundo.\n\nJugador m\u00e1s bien fr\u00edo en el campo, sus compa\u00f1eros alaban su entereza y su capacidad para remontar un partido que parece perdido. No va de estrella medi\u00e1tica, aunque cualquier equipo de \u00e9lite estar\u00eda encantado de contar con sus servicios. Pero \u00e9l se siente tan identificado con su club de toda la vida y con su afici\u00f3n que no ha escuchado los cantos de sirena de otras ligas y otros clubes; piensa retirarse en el Barcelona, cuyo entrenador lo mima y dosifica por temor a las lesiones, aline\u00e1ndolo en los partidos clave. {"category":"Athlete","description":"Jos\u00e9 Miguel Cabrera Torres , commonly known as Miguel Cabrera is a Venezuelan professional baseball first baseman with the Detroit Tigers of Major League Baseball . He bats and throws right-handed. He can also play third base, left field and right field. Cabrera is an eight-time All-Star, having been selected to both the National League and American League All-Star Teams. Cabrera has started at least 100 games at first base, third base, left field and right field. He progressed through the Florida Marlins minor league system, before being called up from the Double-A Carolina Mudcats in June 2003. Cabrera went on to help the Marlins win the World Series that year as their clean-up hitter.Cabrera is widely regarded to be one of the best pure hitters in baseball, hitting at a high average with power to all fields. He has posted at least 30 home runs in nine different seasons with a career batting average of.321. Cabrera has also driven in over 100 runs in each of the last ten seasons, every season aside from his rookie campaign when he played in only 87 games. He began his Racing career at the late age of 17, competing in the Street Stock division at Concord (N.C.) Motorsport Park. His first race car was a 1979 Monte Carlo that he co-owned with older half-brother Kerry. Within two seasons, the young Earnhardt, Jr. had honed his driving abilities to the point of joining the Late Model Stock Car division. There he developed an in-depth knowledge of chassis setup and car preparation, while racing against Kerry and Dale's sister Kelley Earnhardt-Elledge. Junior ran 9 Busch Series races between 1996 and 1997 for Dale Earnhardt Inc. and Ed Whitaker, respectively, before driving for Dale Earnhardt Inc. in the Busch Series full time in 1998. Earnhardt, Jr. won consecutive NASCAR Busch Series Championships in 1998 and 1999 over Matt Kenseth. Also in 1999 he drove in 5 Winston Cup races in the #8 Budweiser Chevrolet for Dale Earnhardt Inc., then in 2000 he went full time in the Winston Cup series.\n\nAfter much speculation, Dale Earnhardt, Jr. announced on May 10, 2007, that he would leave Dale Earnhardt Inc., the company founded by his father, to drive for another team in 2008. Earnhardt expressed that his decision was based entirely on his desires to achieve his career goal of a Sprint Cup Championship, and his apparent belief that he would not be able to attain that objective while driving for DEI. He said that unless he could gain majority ownership, and therefore control, of DEI, that he was not confident in the organization\u2019s ability to field the elite level equipment that would yield the elusive title\nDale Earnhardt Jr. (left) standing between of two different paint schemes for the #88 Chevy. He has joined Hendrick which is the team of Jimmie Johnson, Jeff Gordon and Casey Mears.\n\nOn July 13, 2007, it was announced that his long-time primary sponsor Budweiser would not be with Earnhardt Jr. when he made the move to Hendrick. Other contractual agreements in place at Hendrick Motorsports are said to have prevented a relationship with Bud.[6]\n\nOn August 15, 2007 it was announced that Dale Earnhardt Jr. would not be taking his familiar #8 with him to Hendrick Motorsports in 2008. His late grandfather, Ralph Earnhardt, used that number and Earnhardt Jr. picked it when he entered the Cup Series in 1999. Earnhardt's father also used #8 early in his career. Earnhardt Jr. blamed his stepmother for not allowing the #8 to move with him to Hendrick Motorsports. Earnhardt Jr. said negotiations broke down when Teresa Earnhardt asked for part of the licensing revenue, along with wanting the number back after he retired.\n\nEarnhardt Jr. will move to the #88 car with Tony Eury, Jr. coming to Hendrick to remain as his crew chief. His maternal grandfather, Robert Gee, was one of the first employees of All Star Racing, initially a Late Model Sportsman (now Nationwide Series) team with Gee as Hendrick's partner, which is now Hendrick Motorsports. Hendrick said about Earnhardt and his uncles, \"I can look at Robert Gee Jr., or Jimmy Gee, or Dale Jr., and all I see is Robert Gee. They're the spitting image of him. I go back and look and pictures from when we did things together, and I have to say, I owe Robert a lot.\"\n\nIn 2008, Hendrick Motorsports has merged its Nationwide Series team to Dale's JR Motorsports, with the cars coming from Dale's shop, which includes his mother and uncles.\n\n2008\nDale Earnhardt Jr. performing a burnout after his win in the 2008 Budweiser Shootout\nDale Earnhardt Jr. performing a burnout after his win in the 2008 Budweiser Shootout\nEarnhardt at Daytona\nEarnhardt at Daytona\n\nEarnhardt started the season by winning the 2008 Budweiser Shootout, a non-points paying exhibition. It was his first race for Hendrick. He lead for a total of 47 of 70 laps, a Budweiser Shootout record. He followed that up five days later with a win in the Gatorade Duel. This was his third career win in the duels, however he was unable to follow it up with victory in the Daytona 500, finishing 9th. Ryan Newman was the winner of the event.\n\nDale Earnhardt Jr was docked 50 points because his rear spoiler didn't meet the specified height in the Nationwide Series. Team owner Rick Hendrick was also docked 50 owner points along with Jr. \n\nDale Jr. started 15th for the Auto Club 500 because qualifying was rained out and the lineup will be by owner points from last season. When he came back down the track he took out Jr. When the cameras caught up with Earnhardt in the garage, he was irritated about the fact that they were even out on the track in those conditions. It had been raining all weekend and water was \"weeping\" out of the cracks on the track causing slick spots in the corners. The race was later rain delayed until Monday and Earnhardt finished the race 40th, dropping him to 23rd (from 8th) in the points standing.\n\nHowever, at the Las Vegas Motor Speedway, Junior finished the race second behind Carl Edwards after starting the race 8th. {"category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":" Kimbo Slice aka Kevin Ferguson was born on February 8, 1974 and is a Miami, Florida-based street fighter turned mixed martial arts (MMA) fighter. He first appeared in several filmed underground fights which have spread primarily on the Internet. Law enforcement never intervened as the fights were considered consensual. Kimbo has since left street fighting behind and is now putting his efforts towards becoming a professional mixed martial arts fighter. Slice is currently training with retired MMA fighter Bas Rutten.\nFerguson was a star defensive football player for Miami Palmetto High School in the Pinecrest area of Miami, Florida. In college, he went on to the University of Miami on academic scholarship, but did not play football. He was there for only a year and a half.\nAs Kimbo Slice, Ferguson worked as a bodyguard for RK Netmedia, a Miami-based pornography production\/promotion company responsible for a number of popular adult subscription websites, such as MILF Hunter. Rolling Stone called Slice \"The King of the Web Brawlers\".\nOne of Slice's most notable fights was a controversial late 2004 encounter with Sean Gannon, a former Boston Police officer who trains in MMA. Slice was defeated by Gannon (although Gannon used many moves which were not agreed upon before the fight such as choking and kneeing) and, due to the popularity of the fight video, Gannon began fighting within the Ultimate Fighting Championship.\nSlice made his sanctioned MMA debut against former WBO Heavyweight champion boxer Ray Mercer at Cage Fury Fighting Championships 5, in Atlantic City on June 23, 2007. The match was scheduled as a three-round exhibition utilizing all professional rules of MMA combat. Slice defeated Mercer with a guillotine choke at 1:12 into the first round. In a post-fight interview, Slice stated that he would like to fight David \"Tank\" Abbott. Abbott, who was a spectator, stood up from his seat and accepted the call out. One of the matchmakers for CFFC asked Slice for his assurance so that an October 12th bout at Cage Fury Fighting Championships 6 between Slice and \"Tank\" Abbott could be organized. This event was later canceled due to a promotion dispute. On October 11, 2007, Proelite.com announced that they had signed Slice to a deal and that he would make his debut on the November 10 EliteXC.Originally set to make his professional MMA debut against Mike Bourke, the reformed street fighter was set to face Bo Cantrell after Bourke sustained a shoulder injury.Kimbo defeated Cantrell 19 seconds into the first round by submission due to strikes.\nSlice will be featured on The Iron Ring, a new television series airing on BET which features MMA prospects. Slice will be a part of the selection process for the participants.\nOn February 16th, 2008, Kimbo fought Tank Abbott in the main event at EliteXC: Street Certified. He won by KO 43 seconds into the first round.\nSlice has revealed that he currently lives with his family in Miami, and is the father of six children: three girls and three boys. His first two sons are named Kevin, his first daughter is named Rab and his third son is named Kevlar. His youngest two daughters have names beginning with K.\n\nKIMBO QUOTES:\n\n\u201cKimbo has been my name all my life. Slice was given to me by fans on the Internet. I accept it. It was cool. After the first fight I had with Big D in the backyard, I caught him with a left hook that sliced the bottom of his eye, and I guess broke his whatever. His eyeball came a couple inches down, almost out of his head. They branded me with that name. {"about":"Frisbee Trick Shots & Ultimate Frisbee\nhttp:\/\/youtube.com\/BrodieSmith21\nhttp:\/\/BSmith21.com","awards":"2006, 2010, 2012 National Champion\n2007, 2009, 2010 AC All-Region\n2010 Runner-Up Callahan\n3rd Place at 2010 & 2011 Club Nationals\n","birthday":"08\/29\/1987","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"3-Time National Champion in Ultimate Frisbee.  I play professional Ultimate for the Chicago Wildfire and do Frisbee Trick Shots.\n\nI make YouTube videos! You should watch!\n\nFrisbee Trick Shot Channel:\nhttp:\/\/youtube.com\/brodiesmith21\n\nUltimate Frisbee Vids:\nhttp:\/\/youtube.com\/everythingultimate\n\nMy Personal Vlogs:\nhttp:\/\/youtube.com\/brodiesmithvlog\n\nMy Store:\nhttp:\/\/BSmith21.com\n\nTwitter!\nhttp:\/\/twitter.com\/brodiesmith21\n\nGoogle+\nhttp:\/\/plus.google.com\/u\/0\/+BrodieSmith\n\nI first started playing Ultimate Frisbee my junior year in high school. The number of people that played at a time all depended on how many people were out there. If we had 14 guys show up we would play 7 on 7, but most of the time there were 30 plus so we would play 15 on 15. Basically we had no idea how many were suppose to play at a time. Also, nobody knew what a flick, hammer, scoober, or huck was. We only threw backhands because we knew no better. Even though we weren't that great and didn't know what we were doing we still had a lot of fun! At the time what began as just a fun activity to do after xc or track practice has now become a huge part of my life.\n\nAccepted to University of Florida!!!! Go Gators!!!!\n\n2006 - \n\nI was lucky enough to make the Florida Ultimate Frisbee team my freshman year. Through the season I learned a lot from my teammates (Kurt Gibson, Tim Gehret, Bill MacQueen, and Cyle Van Auken) and my Coach (Kurt Dahlenburg). I played offense that year and got valuable experience on spacing and ways to cut. Winning the National Championship was an amazing team accomplishment and it was awesome to see the Seniors go out on top.\n\n2006 National Champions\n\n2007 - \n\nI knew after losing Callahan winner Tim Gehret and one of our main handlers Bill MacQueen that we would need someone to step up. After being a primary deep receiver my freshman year I knew I had to become more of a threat as a thrower. I worked a lot with Kurt perfecting my flick and worked with Tim on my backhand. It was a very difficult season, but ended up being very rewarding. Nationals that year was very hot. I didn't train hard enough in the off-season to prepare myself and ended up getting what we think was a heat stroke. Playing against Colorado in the Semi's while I was blacking out was an experience I never wanted to go thru again. Unfortunately heat stroke would find me again.\n\n2007 3rd Place (T)\n\n2008 - \n\nEverybody was coming back. We were ready to take the title. Unfortunately we didn't have enough in the Championship game against one of the top 10 college teams in my opinion ever (Wisconsin). It was sad to see the seniors go out like that. Watching Kurt Gibson (one of the best college players to ever play the game) and Cyle Van Auken (maybe the person with the biggest impact on the Florida Program) leave like that put a terrible feeling in my stomach.\n\n2008 Runner Up\n\n2009 -\n\nThe year of the biggest heartbreak I have ever been thru. We crushed everyone that year. We felt untouchable and we acted like it. We would beat you on the field and then tell your girlfriend about it afterwards. We went into Sectionals and joked around the entire time disrespecting our opponents as well as the game. Going into Regionals we felt as confident as ever. Some would say we got what we deserved. Miguel went down with a fracture in his heel. Chris was cramping so bad he couldn't stand up. And for me I was hit with a heat stroke even worse than 2007. With 3 of our top players out or hurting we lost to a very solid Virginia team. We went down into the backdoor games and players that had only seen the field in garbage time were now playing in the biggest points of our season. Everyone battled, but it wasn't enough. NC State played a incredible game against us and got the last ticket to Nationals. This moment in my career I decided that I would never let something like this happen again.\n\n2009 Regional Qualifier\n\n2010 -\n\nRedemption! We started off 2010 the same way we started 2009. Thinking we were better than everyone we played on and off the field. I had to leave the team after Stanford Invite to get my life back on track. After a few weeks I was ready to return and asked if the team would take me back. After a long meeting I discussed how I wanted the team to change. I wanted to play with more respect for ourselves and our opponents. I never worked harder in my life on and off the field. We all worked our tails off. I had a great workout routine (gym 5-6 times a week, biking, swimming, and running). When we hit nationals we were not going to be denied. Winning it all just made everything so worth it and put my life in such a better perspective. I want to thank everyone that has helped my get to the point I'm at in life. My family, friends, teammates, coaches, and my savior Jesus Christ. I am forever grateful.\n\n2010 NATIONAL CHAMPIONS","talking_about_count":10858,"username":"BrodieSmith21","website":"http:\/\/youtube.com\/brodiesmith21","were_here_count":0,"id":"103677859716108","name":"Brodie Smith","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/BrodieSmith21","likes":111196,"cover":{"cover_id":563370377080185,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-prn2\/1482807_563370377080185_205973736_n.jpg","offset_y":43,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"The Official Facebook Page of 49ers Wide Receiver Anquan Boldin - Super Bowl XLVII Champion, 2003 NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year, 3 Time NFC Pro Bowler.","affiliation":"San Francisco 49ers","birthday":"10\/03\/1980","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"As one of the most prolific athletes in Palm Beach County history, Anquan Boldin has had a remarkable athletic career at the high school, collegiate, and professional level. Entering his 10th NFL year, Boldin has received countless accolades, including three-time Pro Bowl performer, NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year, 2010 Ravens Walter Payton Man of the Year, and the Palm Beach County Sports Hall of Fame 2012 inductee, to name a few. As a Ravens player, Boldin has recorded the fastest player in NFL history to record 600 career receptions, reaching the milestone on 9\/26\/10 vs. Cle. in his 98th career game. Boldin also earned AFC Offensive Player of the Week in 2010.\n\nWhile a Cardinal, Anquan made enormous achievements with five, 1,000 yard seasons.  This past season, On November 15, 2009 in a game against the Seattle Seahawks, Boldin became the fifth fastest NFL player ever to gain 7,000 receiving yards.  In 2008 Anquan helped lead his team to their first ever Superbowl as well as his third Pro Bowl season.  Anquan demonstrated true team player skills and leadership that season after a triumphant return from a horrific hit causing surgery procedures to correct a fractured facial bone.\n\nIn 2006, Anquan was seventh in the league in receiving yards with 1,203 and was selected to his second Pro Bowl. It was his third, 1,000-yard season.\n\nIn 2004, Anquan was named a Walter Payton Man of the Year finalist. This award is given by the NFL in recognition of players in off-the-field community service as well and playing with excellence.  That same year he was also awarded the Ed Block Courage Award by the Arizona Cardinals.\n\nA second-round draft choice in 2003, Boldin became the most prolific rookie receiver in league annals, with 101 receptions (which broke the record of 98 held by New England\u2019s Terry Glenn in 1996). The only rookie selected to the 2004 Pro Bowl, Boldin recorded five 100-yard games in his rookie season and was the only receiver to post a 100-yard game for the Cardinals in 2004. In his first professional season, Boldin caught at least three passes in all 16 games and his five 100-yard receiving games were the most by Cardinal since 1998 (Frank Sanders, 5).\n\nFormer quarterback for Florida State, he was the consummate team player. As a senior in 2002, he led the Seminoles in receiving a large tally of notable stats, including 65 receptions for 1,011 yards (15.6-yard average) and 13 touchdowns. During his time there, he rushed 21 times for 86 yards (4.1\u2013 yard average) and completed 7 of 16 passes (43.8 percent) for 111 yards and a score. He played receiver and quarterback in the final college game versus Georgia in the Sugar Bowl, had 3 receptions for 34 yards, and a 5-yard touchdown. He completed 6 of 14 passes for 78 yards and a 40-yard score, as well as added 34 rushing yards on 13 carries.\n\nAnquan began the Anquan Boldin \u201cQ81\u2033 Foundation during his sophomore season with a mission to bring hope to underprivileged children. Well-known throughout the league for his work ethic, his character, and his professionalism, Anquan is also known for his generosity in giving back to his community as evidenced by his charitable activities in both Arizona and his home state of Florida.  This past summer, Pahokee Middle\/High School was named the Anquan Boldin Stadium. {"category":"Athlete","description":"Miroslav Josef Klose is a German professional footballer who plays as a striker for Lazio in the Serie A.Klose holds German nationality and has played 130 times and scored 68 goals for Germany. With five goals, he was the top scorer and Golden Boot winner at the 2006 World Cup in Germany, the first German player to win the award since reunification. Klose also scored five goals in his debut World Cup, the 2002 World Cup, all of which were headers. He scored four times in the 2010 World Cup, giving him a total of 14 World Cup goals and putting him joint second along with Gerd M\u00fcller on the list of top FIFA World Cup goalscorers. Klose is also one of only two players, along with Peruvian Te\u00f3filo Cubillas, to have scored at least five goals in two different World Cups, as well as the only player to have scored at least four in three different tournaments. {"category":"Athlete","description":"Zdeno Ch\u00e1ra is a Slovak professional ice hockey defenseman who currently serves as captain of the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League (NHL). He won the James Norris Memorial Trophy while playing for the Bruins in 2008\u201309. At 6\u00a0ft 9\u00a0in (2.06 m), he is the tallest player ever to play in the NHL. He is also the second European-born and trained captain to win the Stanley Cup and the first born and trained in a country beyond the Iron Curtain.Playing careerNew York Islanders (1997\u20132001)Ch\u00e1ra was drafted 56th overall by the New York Islanders in the third round of the 1996 NHL Entry Draft. Ch\u00e1ra would spend his first season in North America with the Prince George Cougars, who subsequently selected Ch\u00e1ra in that year's CHL Import Draft. Ch\u00e1ra spent four seasons with the Islanders organization, becoming a reliable stay at home defender in a primarily defensive role. He earned a reputation as a tough player to play against \u2013 intimidating, physically strong, and a punishing hitter who could, on occasion, fight. His physical strength also gave him a very hard slap shot, which seemed to improve each season, although Ch\u00e1ra was never deployed in an offensive role as an Islander. He was traded to the Ottawa Senators during the 2001 NHL Entry Draft as part of a deal to acquire forward Alexei Yashin. At the time, it was believed that the deal would vastly improve the Islanders, who were never a contending team when Ch\u00e1ra played there. Ch\u00e1ra was part of a package deal that included Bill Muckalt and the second overall pick from that year's draft (which the Senators used to select Jason Spezza).","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":153,"website":"http:\/\/www.nhl.com\/columns\/wigge\/chara020103.html","were_here_count":0,"id":"112209188795068","name":"Zdeno Ch\u00e1ra","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Zdeno-Ch\u0025C3\u0025A1ra\/112209188795068","likes":94056}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Kimi-Matias R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen is a Finnish racing driver. After nine seasons racing in Formula One, in which he won the Formula One World Drivers' Championship, he competed in the World Rally Championship in 2010 and 2011. In 2012, he returned to Formula One, driving for Lotus and continued to drive for Lotus in 2013. On September 11, 2013, Ferrari announced their signing of R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen on a two year contract, beginning in the 2014 season.R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen entered Formula One as a regular driver for Sauber-Petronas in. Having previously only raced in very junior open-wheel categories, he was given his Super Licence from the F\u00e9d\u00e9ration Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA) after a performance delivery promise by his team boss, Peter Sauber. He joined McLaren Mercedes in, and became a title contender by finishing runner-up in the and championships to Michael Schumacher and Fernando Alonso, respectively. R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen's 2003 and 2005 seasons were plagued by severe unreliability from his McLaren cars.R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen switched to Ferrari in 2007, becoming the highest paid driver in motor sport with an estimated wage of $51 million per year. His move to Ferrari saw him secure his first Formula One World Drivers' Championship, beating McLaren drivers Lewis Hamilton and Fernando Alonso by one point, as well as becoming one of the very few drivers to win in their first season at Ferrari. In 2008, he equalled the record for fastest laps in a season for the second time. However, with Ferrari's desire to get Fernando Alonso in the team with his Santander sponsorship, R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen left the sport and Scuderia Ferrari F1 Team in 2009. R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen then went into WRC to drive a Citro\u00ebn C4 WRC for the Citro\u00ebn Junior Team in the World Rally Championship for 2010. Along with rallying, R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen also competed in NASCAR, and made his debut for Kyle Busch Motorsports in the Camping World Truck Series. R\u00e4ikk\u00f6nen made his return to F1 when he signed a 2-year deal with Lotus starting with the 2012 Formula One season. In his comeback season, he won the 2012 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix. His consistent performances allowed him to end the season 3rd in the Drivers' Championship.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":332,"website":"http:\/\/formula1.ferrari.com\/news\/back-kimi","were_here_count":0,"id":"114362288579881","name":"Kimi Raikkonen","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Kimi-Raikkonen\/114362288579881","likes":108598}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Sourav Chandidas Ganguly, affectionately known as Dada is a former Indian cricketer and captain of the Indian national team. Currently, he is a cricket commentator and President of the Editorial Board with Wisden India. Born into an affluent Brahmin family, Ganguly was introduced into the world of cricket by his elder brother Snehasish. He is regarded as one of India's most successful captains in modern times. He started his career by playing in state and school teams. Currently, he is the 5th highest run scorer in One Day Internationals and was the 3rd person in history to cross the 10,000 run landmark, after Sachin Tendulkar and Inzamam Ul Haq. In 2002, the Wisden Cricketers' Almanack ranked him the sixth greatest ODI batsman of all time, next to Viv Richards, Sachin Tendulkar, Brian Lara, Dean Jones and Michael Bevan.After playing in different Indian domestic tournaments, such as the Ranji and Duleep trophies, Ganguly got his big-break while playing for India on their tour of England. He scored 131\u00a0runs and cemented his place in the Indian team. Ganguly's place in the team was assured after successful performances in series against Sri Lanka, Pakistan and Australia, winning the Man of the Match awards. In the 1999 Cricket World Cup, he was involved in a partnership of 318\u00a0runs with Rahul Dravid, which remains the highest overall partnership score in the World Cup tournament history.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":290,"website":"http:\/\/stats.espncricinfo.com\/ci\/engine\/player\/28779.html?captain=1;class=2;filter=advanced;orderby=default;template=results;type=allround","were_here_count":0,"id":"107927392561473","name":"Sourav Ganguly","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Sourav-Ganguly\/107927392561473","likes":412784}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Lynn Nolan Ryan, Jr. (born on January 31, 1947), nicknamed \"The Ryan Express\", is a former Major League Baseball pitcher and chief executive officer (CEO) of the Texas Rangers.During a major league record 27-year baseball career, he pitched in 1966 and from 1968 to 1993 for four different teams: the New York Mets, California Angels, Houston Astros, and Texas Rangers. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1999.Ryan, a hard-throwing, right-handed pitcher, threw pitches that were regularly recorded above 100 miles per hour (161\u00a0km\/h). The high velocity remained throughout his career, even into his 40s. Ryan was also known to throw a devastating 12\u20136 curveball at exceptional velocity for a breaking ball.While his lifetime winning percentage was.526, Ryan was an eight-time MLB All-Star, and his 5,714 career strikeouts rank first in baseball history by a significant margin. He leads the runner-up, Randy Johnson, by 839 strikeouts. Similarly, Ryan's 2,795 bases on balls lead second-place Steve Carlton by 962 \u2014 walking over 50\u0025 more hitters than any other pitcher in Major League history. Ryan and Sandy Koufax are the only two pitchers inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame who had more strikeouts than innings pitched. Other than Jackie Robinson (whose number was retired by the entire MLB), Ryan is currently the only major league baseball player to have his number retired by at least three different teams: the Angels, Astros, and Rangers.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":72,"website":"https:\/\/s3.amazonaws.com\/Todd_Staples\/Staples_PR_2014.pdf\/","were_here_count":0,"id":"107822445913934","name":"Nolan Ryan","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Nolan-Ryan\/107822445913934","likes":112520}

Anyone making obscene remarks of any nature will be blocked and reported to Facebook!","affiliation":"Team Khan","awards":"Former IBF World Light-Welterweight Champion \nCurrent SUPER WBA World Light-Welterweight Champion\nCurrent WBA World Light-Welterweight Champion\nFormer Commonwealth Lightweight Champion\nFormer WBA International Lightweight Champion\nFormer WBO Inter-Continental Lightweight Champion [2x]\nFormer IBF Inter-Continental Light-Welterweight Champion\nOlympic Silver Medalist (2004)","bio":"Catapulted into the limelight from the 2004 Silver medal Olympic podium Amir Khan has become Britain's highest-profile boxer racking up an impressive professional fight record; having become the World Light Welterweight Champion in July 2009 after his life changing fight against Andreas Kotelnik.\n\nOver the past four years Amir has ridden high at the top of his game to a rapturous reception in Britain, State-side and beyond. Sensationally losing for the first time in his professional career to Columbian bruiser Breidis Prescott in September 2008 - the tempest of conjecture and condemnation fuelled media frenzy was followed in quick succession by a grueling and inspirational new training regime with Coach Freddie Roach in L.A.\n\nThe boy from Bolton came back to the ring with brutal vengeance as he sent Oisin Fagan flailing to the floor in December 2008. Khan did not just convincingly put the boy down for a compelling victory - he exuded a fresh, calm, persona; a measured aggressor spearing his prey with a jab as he circled, finding his target and then unleashing a flurry of blows, taking him apart and sending him to the floor twice inside the first round\u2026 97 seconds into the second it was all over.\n\nKhan's World Title Fight in July 2009 with Kotelnik was an extremely intense match. Both were on top form but it was Khan\u2019s display of speed, stamina and boxing skill that saw him victorious.\n\nLiving to box has been a self proclaimed obsession for Amir Khan; one that has turned him from a talented streetwise boy, into a self assured man and not forgetting to mention, World Champion.\n\nIf you were to ask anyone about Amir Khan's talent, they would undoubtedly say he was born to be a boxer. His calm exterior unnerving to his opponents; his craving to win making him faster and stronger than others; these are but a few reasons why he has become not only a winner, but an icon.\n\nThe fight between Amir Khan and Andreas Kotelnik did not start of as expected. Due to an unfortunate injury, Kotelnik had to postpone the fight until July 18th, subsequently delaying Amir Khan from holding the World Light Welterweight Champion title by just under a month.\n\nThere was a distinct buzz on the night of the match. Everyone who attended the fight or watched it on television could tell that this fight would be a defining moment for Khan. 12 rounds later and that moment arrived, propelling the Bolton Boxer to staggering new heights in his career.\n\nThose who know and train with Khan have expressed their delight at the victory. Freddie Roach exclaimed \"I love bringing the best out of people and he's more of a complete fighter now. He feints better and goes to the body, like an old school fighter. People were saying Amir was done after getting knocked out by Prescott, but in three fights he is world champion.'","birthday":"12\/08\/1986","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"Premier House, Prince Street, Bolton","city":"Bolton","state":"","country":"United Kingdom","zip":"BL1 2NP"},"personal_info":"Bringing you all the latest news, stories, videos, photos, polls, competitions, exclusive content, direct messages and much more from Team Khan and Amir himself!","personal_interests":"Amir of course loves Boxing. {"about":"Noi adoriamo DIEGO ARMANDO MARADONA... Fan Page NON ufficiale.","bio":"DIEGO ARMANDO MARADONA\n \nMaradona nasce il 30 ottobre 1960 nel quartiere povero di Villa Florito, nella periferia di Buenos Aires, dove trascorre i giorni di bambino giocando per strada e dimostrando gi\u00e0 sprazzi di talento definito unanimamente divino. \nLa sua carriera inizia nell'argentinos Junior, per poi proseguire, sempre in Argentina, nelle fila del Boca Juniors (squadra della quale Maradona \u00e8 sempre rimasto accesissimo tifoso). \nEsordisce a livello internazionale con la nazionale giovanile argentina (con cui vincer\u00e0 il titolo mondiale nel 1979) e da li a poco verr\u00e0 inserito nella nazionale maggiore. \nDopo il mondiale del 1982 in Spagna, viene ingaggiato dal Barcellona e approda finalmente sul palcoscenico del calcio europeo. \nIn spagna Diego gioca per due stagioni, collezionando prestazioni memorabili e un terribile infortunio (Goicoechea, difensore dell'Athletic Bilbao, gli frattura la caviglia sinistra e gli rompe i legamenti con un'entrata assassina). \nNel 1984 l'evento che segna la svolta nella vita calcistica di Maradona: il 30\/06\/1984 firma un contratto con il Napoli. \nLa citt\u00e0 partenopea adotta subito Dieguito a suo idolo e il calore dei tifosi viene ricambiato dall'amore che sempre Maradona manifester\u00e0 nei confronti di quella che diventer\u00e0 la sua \"seconda patria\". \nCon il Napoli Diego raggiunge i traguardi pi\u00f9 prestigiosi: 2 scudetti, 1 coppa italia, 1 coppa UEFA e una supercoppa italiana. \nE' il periodo pi\u00f9 felice di Maradona: ai successi sul campo si affiancano una condizione fisica e tecnica all'apice e una fama inarrivabile nel mondo, in questo periodo Diego E' il calcio. \nNel frattempo trascina la nazionale Argentina alla vittoria nei mondiali del 1986 in Messico: Maradona disputa un torneo strepitoso segnando nella stessa partita due goals(che sarebbero rimasti nella storia) contro l'Inghilterra, uno di mano (la cosiddetta \"mano di Dio\") e il secondo dribblando avversari come birilli e incantando tutti gli appassionati del mondo. \nNegli anni novanta arriva il declino della sua stella: nel 91 viene trovato positivo ad un controllo antidoping in campionato e di conseguenza squalificato per 15 mesi. \nScontata la squalifica Diego rifiuta di tornare al Napoli: l'idillio con la citt\u00e0 \u00e8 rimasto sempre lo stesso, ma i rapporti con la societ\u00e0 sono franati. \nChiede perci\u00f2 di essere ceduto e nel 1992 torna nella Liga spagnola con la maglia del Siviglia. \nL'anno seguente (1993) sembra veder rinascere Diego: ritorna in nazionale e aiuta l'Argentina a superare l'Australia nello spareggio per la qualificazione ai mondiali americani del 94. \nMa ormai la sua carriera ha imboccato il viale del tramonto e tutti gli sportivi soffrono per come questo grande campione riesca a farsi del male: \u00e8 il giugno del 1994, Stati Uniti d'America, campionato mondiale, Diego risulta positivo al test antidoping ed \u00e8 cacciato dalla manifestazione..... \nTorner\u00e0 ancora sui campi da gioco (nel 95 col Boca), ma si tratter\u00e0 solo dell'ombra del campione che fu. \nUna cosa risalta nitidamente agli occhi di tutti gli sportivi: tanto era grande in campo Diego, quanto era debole nella vita. \nLe cronache recenti parlano di un uomo imbolzito, grasso, che fatica a rimettere nei giusti binari una vita rovinata dalla droga, ma chiunque abbia visto un suo goal, una punizione, un dribbling.... o un semplice sorriso che regalava senza protervia, non pu\u00f2 dimenticare il \"Pibe de Oro\", forse il pi\u00f9 grande fantasista del mondo, di certo l'ultimo grande giocatore tutto \"talento e fantasia\" in un calcio gi\u00e0 divenuto troppo tattico e fisico.. \n\nUN BREVE RIASSUNTO DELLA VITA DI MARADONA\n \n30\/10\/1960: Diego Armando Maradona nasce a Lan\u00fas, nella periferia di Buenos Aires. E' il quinto degli otto figli di Diego Maradona e Dalma Salvadora Franco. \n5\/12\/1970: Inizia a giocare nelle Cebollitas, la squadra giovanile dell'Argentinos Juniors. \n20\/10\/1976: Gioca la prima partita nella Serie A argentina con la maglia dell' Argentinos Juniors contro il Talleres de C\u00f3rdoba, dieci giorni prima del suo sedicesimo compleanno, entrando all'inizio del secondo tempo con la maglietta numero 16 al posto di Giacobetti. \n14\/11\/1976: Segna il suo primo gol, contro Lucangioli, portiere del San Lorenzo di Mar del Plata. \n27\/02\/1977: Debutta con la maglia della nazionale argentina contro l'Ungheria. \nMaggio 1978: L'allenatore della nazionale Cesar Menotti non lo convoca per il mondiale del 1978 ritenendolo troppo giovane. \n2\/6\/1979: Segna il suo primo gol in nazionale, a Glasgow contro la Scozia. \n7\/9\/79: Guida l'Argentina alla vittoria della Coppa del Mondo giovanile in Giappone segnando anche un gol su calcio di punizione nella finale vinta 3-1 contro l'Unione Sovietica. \n19\/2\/1981: Si trasferisce al Boca Juniors. \n22\/2\/1981: Debutta nel Boca vincendo 4-1 contro il Talleres de C\u00f3rdoba e segnando due reti. \n16\/8\/1981: Vince il campionato con il Boca Juniors. \n\n4\/6\/1982: Firma per il Barcellona . \n24\/9\/1983: Subisce l'infortunio pi\u00fa grave della sua carriera quando Andoni Goicoechea, difensore dell'Athletic Bilbao, gli frattura la caviglia sinistra e gli rompe il legamento. \n30\/6\/1984: Firma per il Napoli. \n5\/7\/1984: Presentazione ai tifosi del Napoli -foto!- in una festa indimenticabile. \n22-29\/6\/1986: Segna prima il celebre gol con la \"Mano di Dio\" e poi realizza un gol meraviglioso nella vittoria per 2-1 contro l'Inghilterra nei quarti del mondiale. Guida praticamente da solo l'Argentina fino al trionfo contro la Germania Ovest per 3-2 nella finale. \n10\/5\/1987: Guida il Napoli alla vittoria del primo scudetto (foto della squadra). \n17\/5\/1989: Vince la Coppa UEFA col Napoli, che ottiene la prima vittoria in una competizione europea. \nAgosto-Settembre 1989:Trascorre due mesi in Argentina, tornando in Italia solo dopo l'inizio del campionato. \n29\/4\/1990: Vince il secondo scudetto col Napoli. \n8\/7\/1990: Porta l'Argentina alla finale del mondiale a Roma, partita persa per 1-0 con la Germania Ovest a causa di un calcio di rigore molto dubbio. \n17\/3\/1991: Viene trovato positivo a un controllo antidoping e viene squalificato per 15 mesi dai campi di calcio. \n1992: Rifiuta di tornare al Napoli dopo la squalifica e chiede un trasferimento. Viene ingaggiato dal Siviglia. \n4\/10\/1992: Debutta con la maglia del Siviglia, perdendo 2-1 contro l'Athletic Bilbao. \n10\/10\/1993: Lascia il Siviglia per il Newell's Old Boys in Argentina. Perde la prima partita per 3-1 contro l'Independiente. \n31\/10\/1993: Ritorna a giocare in nazionale a Sydney contro l'Australia per gli spareggi di qualificazione al mondiale USA 1994. Pareggia 1-1 e il gol argentino \u00e8 propiziato da una grande giocata di Diego. \n17\/11\/1993: L'Argentina con Maradona come capitano batte 1-0 l'Australia e si qualifica per il mondiale. \n2\/12\/1993: Gioca la sua ultima partita con il Newell's contro l'Hurac\u00e1n. \nGiugno 1994: Gioca due partite con la nazionale argentina nel mondiale americano segnando anche un gran gol contro la Grecia, prima di essere squalificato per uso di efedrina, sostanza non consentita dalla FIFA. \n3\/10\/1994: Prima esperienza da allenatore: viene ingaggiato dal Deportivo Mandiy\u00fa di Corrientes. Due mesi dopo rinuncer\u00e1 all'incarico. \n6\/5\/1995: Seconda esperienza da allenatore: viene ingaggiato dal Racing. Quattro mesi dopo dar\u00e1 le dimissioni. \n7\/10\/1995: Ritorna a giocare nel Boca Juniors nella partita Boca-Col\u00f3n 1-0. I tifosi del Boca gli preparano un'accoglienza indimenticabile nello stadio della \"Bombonera\". \n1996: Continua a giocare per il Boca Juniors. \n24\/8\/1997: Ritorna in gran forma a giocare per il Boca Juniors, segnando nella partita vinta 4-2 contro l'Argentinos Juniors. Viene di nuovo trovato positivo, nonostante ci siano dei sospetti su un possibile complotto. \n25\/10\/1997: Gioca la sua ultima partita col Boca, vincendo 1-2 in casa del River Plate. \n30\/10\/1997:Decide di ritirarsi dal calcio proprio il 30 ottobre, giorno del suo 37esimo compleanno. \n1998: Non gioca la coppa del mondo, ma va in Francia per commentare le partite per una televisione argentina. \nNovembre 1998: Torna per la prima volta in Italia dopo oltre sette anni. \n1999: Approva con entusiasmo la realizzazione di un film sulla sua vita e partecipa al film \"Tifosi\" (foto) \n\n\n\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nPremi ottenuti durante la sua carriera: \n\n* 1978: Capocannoniere del Campionato Metropolitano. \n* 1979: Capocannoniere del Campionato Metropolitano. \n* 1979: Capocannoniere del Campionato Nazionale. \n* 1979: Campione del Mondo juniores con la nazionale argentina. \n* 1979: \"Olimpia de Oro\" al Miglior calciatore argentino dell'anno. \n* 1979: Scelto dalla FIFA come Miglior Calciatore dell'anno in Sudamerica. \n* 1979: Ottiene il Pallone d'Oro come Miglior Calciatore del momento. \n* 1980: Capocannoniere del Campionato Metropolitano. \n* 1980: Capocannoniere del Campionato Nazionale. \n* 1980: Scelto dalla FIFA come Miglior Calciatore dell'anno in Sudamerica. \n* 1981: Capocannoniere del Campionato Nazionale. \n* 1981: Riceve il Trofeo Gandulla come Miglior Calciatore dell'anno. \n* 1981: Campione di Argentina con il Boca Juniors. \n* 1983: Vince la Coppa del Re con il Barcellona. \n* 1985: Viene nominato ambasciatore dell'UNICEF. \n* 1986: Campione del Mondo con la nazionale argentina. \n* 1986: Vince il secondo \"Olimpia de Oro\" al Miglior calciatore argentino dell'anno. \n* 1986: E' dichiarato \"Cittadino Illustre\" della Citt\u00e0 di Buenos Aires. \n* 1986: Ottiene la Scarpa d'Oro consegnata dalla Adidas al miglior calciatore dell'anno. \n* 1986: Ottiene la Penna d'Oro come miglior calciatore in Europa. \n* 1987: Campione d'Italia con il Napoli. \n* 1987: Vince la Coppa Italia con il Napoli. \n* 1988: Capocannoniere della Serie A con il Napoli. \n* 1989: Vince la Coppa UEFA con il Napoli. \n* 1990: Campione d'Italia con il Napoli. \n* 1990: Ottiene il Premio Konex di Brillante per la sua abilit\u00e0 sportiva. \n* 1990: Secondo posto nella Coppa del Mondo. \n* 1990: Nominato Ambasciatore dello Sport dal Presidente dell'Argentina. \n* 1990: Vince la Supercoppa Italiana con il Napoli. \n* 1993: Premiato come Miglior Calciatore Argentino di tutti i tempi. \n* 1993: Vince la Coppa Artemio Franchi con la nazionale argentina. \n* 1995: Ottiene il Pallone d'Oro alla carriera. \n* 1995: Premiato come \"Maestro Ispiratore di Sogni\" dall'Universit\u00e0 di Oxford. \n* 1999: \"Olimpia de Platino\" al Miglior Calciatore del secolo. \n* 1999: Riceve dalla AFA il premio come miglior sportivo del secolo in Argentina. \n* 1999: {"about":"Welcome to FERNANDO TORRES 9 - the facebook fanpage about the best footballer in the world!! Enjoy ;) Your admins www.fb.com\/ft9fan","bio":"Full name: Fernando Jos\u00e9 Torres Sanz\nNickname: El Ni\u00f1o (=\"The Child\")\nDate of birth: 20th March 1984\nPlace of birth: Fuenlabrada, Madrid, Spain\nHeight: 1,86 m (6 ft 1 in)\nWeight: 78 Kg\n\nGirlfriend: Olalla Dom\u00ednguez Liste - now Olalla Torres (birth date: 1 January 1985; wedding date: 27 May 2009)\nDaughter: Nora (birth date: 8 July 2009)\nSon: Leo (birth date: 6 December 2010)\n\nYouth career: \nAtletico Madrid (1995-2001)\n\nSenior career: \nAtletico Madrid (2001-2007), Liverpool (2007-2011), Chelsea (since 2011)\n\nNational team: \nSpain U15 (2000), Spain U16 (2001), Spain U17 (2001), Spain U18 (2001), Spain U19 (2002), Spain U21 (2002\u20132003), Spain (since 2003)\n\n     Fernando Jose Torres Sanz, more commonly known as just Fernando Torres, was born in Madrid, Spain, on 20 March 1984. He currently plays in the Premiership for Liverpool Football Club and is viewed as one of the best strikers in the world. Fernando has been successful throughout his career, from his time in Spain with Atletico Madrid to his time at Liverpool and at international level with Spain.\n     Like many young boys, Torres developed a keen interest to the beautiful game from a young age. His grandfather was a keen Atletico Madrid supporter and his brother played at an amateur level as a goalkeeper. Initially, Fernando Torres wanted to emulate the bit of success his brother had in that position. However, as with many players they find out their best position a few years into playing. Despite starting off as a goalkeeper, Torres developed an eye for goal and after scoring 55 goals for academy club Rayo 13, he soon realized that his best position was upfront.\n     In 1995, Spanish club Atletico Madrid trailed three of Rayo 13's star players, with Fernando being one of them. He impressed at his trial, and they decided to sign the young striker at the age of eleven.\n     Fernando Torres continued to make great progress through the ranks at the club during his teenage years, and his first chance to impress on a global scale came when Atletico Madrid decided to enter a team in the U15 Nike Cup. They won the tournament, with Torres voted the best player. Many were starting to see the potential in him, and his prospect excited many fans of the   Spanish club. At 15, he signed a professional contract with the club, and made his first team debut at the age of 17 against Leganes. Atletico were then promoted back to La Liga in 2001-02 season. Eventually, he went on to become club captain and scored 84 goals from 214 appearances for the team he had been with for many years. Despite this emotional attachment, when Liverpool came in with an offer of around \u00a320 Million, he decided to leave the club for England in 2007.\n     Torres had the opportunity to showcase his skills in the Premiership and for Liverpool. With the high transfer fee, many thought he may not respond well to the pressure being placed on him by the football world. This, however, was not the case.\n     The striker settled quickly at Liverpool, and immediately started to score goals on a regular basis. His first hat-trick was scored in September against Reading. He went on to score 33 goals in total, and since has become a respected figure in the Liverpool team and has scored 9 goals in all competitions so far in the 2008\/09 season.\n     Fernando Torres has also impressed at an international level for Spain and is known for scoring the winning goal against Germany in the Euro 2008 final. He continues to impress for both club and country and is recognized as one of the best strikers in the game.","birthday":"03\/20\/1984","category":"Athlete","company_overview":"!WARNING!\nPage \"Fernando Torres 9\" hasn't any contact with official sources or Fernando.
