{"about":"Xavi H\u00e9rnandez  :) ,, News , Photos , Videos , Everything \u2665 ","awards":"Premio Don Bal\u00f3n: Jugador revelaci\u00f3n de la Liga 1998-1999\nPremio Don Bal\u00f3n: Mejor jugador espa\u00f1ol de la Liga 2004-2005\nMejor jugador de la Eurocopa 2008\nEquipo ideal de la Eurocopa 2008\nMejor constructor de juego del mundo seg\u00fan la IFFHS: 2008, 2009, 2010\nXI Mundial FIFA-FIFPro: 2008, 2009, 2010\nEquipo del A\u00f1o de la UEFA: 2008, 2009, 2010\nMejor jugador de la Final de la UEFA Champions League 2008-09\nMejor centrocampista del a\u00f1o de la UEFA Champions League 2008-09\nBal\u00f3n de Bronce de la Copa Mundial de Clubes de la FIFA 2009\nPremios LFP: Mejor Mediocentro de la Liga BBVA 2009\nBal\u00f3n de Oro: Bal\u00f3n de Bronce 2009\nFIFA World Player: Tercer clasificado 2009\nEquipo ideal de la Copa del Mundo: 2010\nPremio World Soccer: Mejor jugador del mundo 2010\nFIFA Bal\u00f3n de Oro: Tercer clasificado 2010\n","bio":"(Xavier Hern\u00e1ndez Creus; Terrassa, 1980) Futbolista espa\u00f1ol perteneciente a la disciplina del F\u00fatbol Club Barcelona desde las categor\u00edas inferiores hasta su consolidaci\u00f3n en el primer equipo. El f\u00fatbol de toque de bal\u00f3n con jugadores de gran t\u00e9cnica que impuso el denominado Dream Team de Johan Cruyff ten\u00eda su gozne en este centrocampista de t\u00e9cnica depurada que protege el bal\u00f3n como nadie y \"lee\" con admirable sencillez el ritmo que debe adquirir el partido en cada fase del juego. Al t\u00e9rmino de la Eurocopa de 2008, que gan\u00f3 la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola por segunda vez en la historia, fue elegido Mejor Jugador del torneo, una distinci\u00f3n que raramente recae en un centrocampista y que reconoc\u00eda su fundamental aportaci\u00f3n. Xavi fue adem\u00e1s una pieza esencial en la consecuci\u00f3n del \"triplete\" del Bar\u00e7a (que gan\u00f3 en 2009 la Liga, la Copa del Rey y la Champions League) y en el triunfo de la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola en el Mundial de Sud\u00e1frica en 2010, en el que Espa\u00f1a se proclam\u00f3 por primera vez campeona del mundo.\n\n\nXavi Hern\u00e1ndez\n\nSu progenitor, que fue jugador del Sabadell, le inculc\u00f3 la pasi\u00f3n por el f\u00fatbol. Los ojeadores del F\u00fatbol Club Barcelona le siguieron en varios partidos infantiles de la ciudad egarense a instancias del padre. Por fin, a los once a\u00f1os, hizo una prueba y en julio de 1991 ingres\u00f3 en la Masia, la residencia de las futuras estrellas del Bar\u00e7a que no proceden de la Ciudad Condal. Xavi se fij\u00f3 de inmediato en su maestro Josep Guardiola, su actual entrenador y figura clave del Dream Team en aquel entonces. Mir\u00e1ndose en aquel espejo, su progresi\u00f3n fue tan mete\u00f3rica que el propio Guardiola, que un d\u00eda lo observaba desde la banda en un partido de juveniles, pronostic\u00f3 a sus compa\u00f1eros: \"\u00c9ste nos va a jubilar a todos\". M\u00e1s o menos as\u00ed ser\u00eda. Xavi se convirti\u00f3 en el sucesor natural de Guardiola, a pesar de que de la cantera surgir\u00edan otros excelentes organizadores que se vieron obligados a abandonar las filas del club, como Cesc F\u00e1bregas o Vlikel Arteta, que disputan la Premier League inglesa y escocesa, respectivamente.\n\nSu predisposici\u00f3n para aprender cosas, la madurez que irradiaba a tan corta edad y su calidad futbol\u00edstica propiciaron que en la temporada 1997-1998 pasara del juvenil al Barca B, en el que de inmediato se convirti\u00f3 en el \"cerebro\" del equipo. Un equipo en el que Xavi no s\u00f3lo mandaba y organizaba, sino que marcaba goles con facilidad gracias a sus inesperadas llegadas al \u00e1rea y a su maestr\u00eda en el lanzamiento de faltas con barrera. Ya entonces, a pesar de su baja estatura (1,70 m) y su menuda complexi\u00f3n (pesa 63 kilos cuando est\u00e1 en plena forma), ser\u00eda un maestro en la conducci\u00f3n del bal\u00f3n y en la protecci\u00f3n del mismo.\n\nEn la temporada siguiente altern\u00f3 sus actuaciones con el B y con el primer equipo, con el que debut\u00f3 el 18 de agosto de 1998 de la mano del t\u00e9cnico neerland\u00e9s Louis Van Gaal, en un partido de la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a ante el Real Mallorca. Fue titular y, adem\u00e1s, marc\u00f3 un gol. Van Gaal lo hizo debutar en la Liga el 3 de octubre de aquel mismo a\u00f1o en el Mestalla frente al Valencia, que cay\u00f3 derrotado por 1-3. Sus intermitentes actuaciones con el primer equipo dieron alas a un Bar\u00e7a alica\u00eddo que ocupaba la d\u00e9cima posici\u00f3n de la tabla. Xavi marc\u00f3 un gol decisivo que dio la victoria a su equipo en el campo del Valladolid, y a partir de aquella victoria, contando m\u00e1s asiduamente con su presencia, los azulgranas remontaron de forma tan espectacular que ganar\u00edan la Liga 1998-1999. Era su segundo t\u00edtulo profesional, porque poco antes hab\u00eda ganado el Campeonato del Mundo Sub-20 disputado en Nigeria.\n\n\n\nEn la temporada 1999-2000, debido a una lesi\u00f3n de Guardiola, Xavi se consolid\u00f3 en el primer equipo. Convencido de sus posibilidades, su juego madur\u00f3 exponencialmente. Entretanto, su estelar actuaci\u00f3n en Nigeria propici\u00f3 que el 15 de noviembre de 2000 debutara con la selecci\u00f3n absoluta ante los Pa\u00edses Bajos. Pocos a\u00f1os despu\u00e9s ya ser\u00eda convocado regularmente para defender los colores de Espa\u00f1a. A partir de la temporada 2000-2001, y con la marcha de Guardiola al calcio italiano, Xavi se convirti\u00f3 en titular indiscutible, tanto con Van Gaal como con los entrenadores subsiguientes: Carles Reixach, Radomir Antic y Frank Rijkaard. En el Barca, sin embargo, no alcanzar\u00eda su tercer t\u00edtulo, el de Liga, hasta el 14 de mayo de 2005, tras una marcha penosa del equipo y del club por un desierto de desprop\u00f3sitos. En verano del mismo a\u00f1o se proclam\u00f3 campe\u00f3n de la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a, t\u00edtulo que renovar\u00eda al a\u00f1o siguiente, en el que en el partido de vuelta marc\u00f3 un gol decisivo ante el Real Club Espa\u00f1ol, al que los azulgranas superaron por 3-0.\n\nHabitualmente las lesiones lo respetaban, por lo que siempre estuvo en forma cuando se requer\u00eda su participaci\u00f3n. S\u00f3lo cabe mencionar una rotura del ligamento cruzado anterior de la rodilla derecha en un entrenamiento en el Camp Nou, en diciembre de 2005. Aquel percance trunc\u00f3 su proyecci\u00f3n al obligarlo a estar ausente durante cinco meses, hasta finales de abril de 2006, fecha en que reapareci\u00f3 ante el C\u00e1diz C. F. Aquel a\u00f1o los azulgranas consiguieron de nuevo el t\u00edtulo de Liga y la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a. Pero el mayor momento de gloria de aquel a\u00f1o 2006 para un equipo que funcionaba como una m\u00e1quina (gracias al trabajo de Xavi y Andr\u00e9s Iniesta en la medular y las genialidades de Ronaldinho y Eto'o en la delantera) lleg\u00f3 con la victoria en la Liga de Campeones, la asignatura pendiente del Bar\u00e7a, que s\u00f3lo ten\u00eda en sus vitrinas la conseguida por el Dream Team en 1992. Xavi, sin embargo, no pudo participar en la final ante el Arsenal F. C. debido a su baja forma por la lesi\u00f3n.\n\n\nCelebrando junto a Iniesta la Champions 2009\n\nEn 2007, en el partido de Liga de Campeones ante el Olympique de Lyon, disputado el 19 de septiembre, Xavi igual\u00f3 a Migueli como jugador del F. C. Barcelona que m\u00e1s partidos hab\u00eda disputado en competiciones europeas (85). Y super\u00f3 al m\u00edtico central ceut\u00ed el 2 de octubre de aquel mismo a\u00f1o en un partido frente al VfB Stuttgart. La diferencia, por supuesto, seguir\u00eda aumentando. En cuanto a sus partidos con el Bar\u00e7a, el 24 de noviembre de 2007 y ante el club decano espa\u00f1ol, el Recreativo de Huelva, igual\u00f3 la cifra de 400 partidos oficiales que ostentaba Guardiola.\n\nPero sin el t\u00edtulo de Campe\u00f3n de Europa de Naciones de 2008, en la que Xavi explot\u00f3 al m\u00e1ximo unas cualidades que no prodigaba (pases en profundidad al delantero con mayor ventaja y chutes desde fuera del \u00e1rea), no habr\u00eda ocupado las primeras p\u00e1gina de la prensa. En esa Eurocopa, disputada en Austria y Suiza, el centrocampista azulgrana, adoctrinado por Luis Aragon\u00e9s, adelant\u00f3 su posici\u00f3n con \u00e9xito rotundo. Marc\u00f3 su primer gol el 26 de junio frente a Rusia. Y en la final ante Alemania, Xavi dio el pase de gol a Fernando Torres, quien marc\u00f3 el \u00fanico tanto del encuentro. Su actuaci\u00f3n en la Eurocopa le vali\u00f3 el premio al Mejor Jugador de la competici\u00f3n, una menci\u00f3n que habitualmente recae en un delantero goleador. Los medios de comunicaci\u00f3n, sin embargo, coincidieron en que era una elecci\u00f3n acertada. Adem\u00e1s de esta distinci\u00f3n mayor, Xavi hab\u00eda sido galardonado como el mejor futbolista de las temporadas 1998-1999 y 2004-2005 por la revista deportiva Don Bal\u00f3n, y ya en 1999 hab\u00eda recibido el premio El Pa\u00eds como futbolista revelaci\u00f3n.\n\n\nCon David Villa en la final de la Eurocopa 2008\n\nSi con la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola hab\u00eda vivido uno de los mejores momentos al ganar la Eurocopa, la temporada 2008-2009 le reservaba a\u00fan un destino superior: ser parte esencial, junto con Iniesta, de la organizaci\u00f3n del juego del F.C. Barcelona en la que fue sin duda la mejor temporada de la historia del club. El Bar\u00e7a, en efecto, logr\u00f3 algo tan ins\u00f3lito en el f\u00fatbol mundial como el \"triplete\", la victoria en los tres torneos en que participaba: la Liga espa\u00f1ola, la Copa del Rey y la Champions League. El juego exhibido por el equipo maravill\u00f3 a todo el mundo; por supuesto que fue el nuevo entrenador, su admirado Josep Guardiola, el principal art\u00edfice de esa revoluci\u00f3n, pero tales \u00e9xitos no son concebibles sin organizadores de la talla de Iniesta y del propio Xavi.\n\nLa temporada 2009-2010 sum\u00f3 su quinto t\u00edtulo liguero a su palmar\u00e9s, tras una re\u00f1id\u00edsima competici\u00f3n en la que el F\u00fatbol Club Barcelona y el Real Madrid alcanzaron registros vertiginosos tanto en goles como en puntos, ganando 31 de los 38 partidos disputados. El Bar\u00e7a, que se anot\u00f3 tambi\u00e9n la Supercopa de Espa\u00f1a, no pudo sin embargo revalidar su victoria en la Champions League al caer en semifinales.\n\nFinalizada la temporada, el Mundial de Sud\u00e1frica de 2010 deparar\u00eda a Xavi el \u00faltimo t\u00edtulo que le quedaba por ganar. Pese a la decepcionante derrota inicial frente a Suiza, la selecci\u00f3n espa\u00f1ola entrenada por Vicente del Bosque se mantuvo fiel a su estilo, y de la mano de Xavi y de sus restantes cerebros centrocampistas (Iniesta, Xabi Alonso, Cesc F\u00e0begras) encaden\u00f3 una victoria tras otra hasta derrotar a Alemania en las semifinales y a Holanda en la final. Por primera vez, despu\u00e9s de d\u00e9cadas \u201csin pasar de cuartos\u201d, Espa\u00f1a se proclamaba campeona del mundo.\n\nJugador m\u00e1s bien fr\u00edo en el campo, sus compa\u00f1eros alaban su entereza y su capacidad para remontar un partido que parece perdido. No va de estrella medi\u00e1tica, aunque cualquier equipo de \u00e9lite estar\u00eda encantado de contar con sus servicios. Pero \u00e9l se siente tan identificado con su club de toda la vida y con su afici\u00f3n que no ha escuchado los cantos de sirena de otras ligas y otros clubes; piensa retirarse en el Barcelona, cuyo entrenador lo mima y dosifica por temor a las lesiones, aline\u00e1ndolo en los partidos clave. De la temporada 2010-2011 sin duda se recordar\u00e1 el extraordinario gol con que Xavi abri\u00f3 el marcador frente al Madrid de Mourinho.\n","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"Barcelona, TERRASSA, Spain","zip":""},"talking_about_count":4729,"username":"Elmaestro.Xavier","website":"http:\/\/www.xavihernandez.com ","were_here_count":0,"id":"424281067591316","name":"Xavi Hernandez","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/Elmaestro.Xavier","likes":303526,"cover":{"cover_id":651539911532096,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-frc3\/s720x720\/1238128_651539911532096_976800920_n.png","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Donald Jerome Driver is a former American football wide receiver, New York Times bestselling author and season 14 Dancing with the Stars champion. After playing college football for Alcorn State University, Driver was picked by the Green Bay Packers in the seventh round of the 1999 NFL Draft. Driver spent his entire 14-season National Football League career with the Packers and holds the franchise's all-time records for most career receptions and receiving yards.Early lifeDonald Jerome Driver was born in Houston, Texas on February 2, 1975. Driver was the middle child of five siblings. Driver's parents, Marvin Driver Jr. and Faye Gray divorced when he was just a young boy. Donald had a tough childhood living out of a U-Haul truck for a period of time during his early teens, after a collection agency confiscated his family's possessions. Donald spent multiple nights in motel rooms that his mother had purchased with food stamps. Driver and his older brother Marvin III, began stealing cars and selling drugs during their teenage years in order make it from day to day. Driver was quoted by USA Today stating, \"You try to do anything you can to provide for your family.\" At the age of 14 years old, Donald would move in with his grandmother, Betty Lofton. This was the point of time where Driver's life started to turn around.Donald Driver shone as an athlete early in his years at Milby High in Houston. He lettered four times each in track, football, basketball and baseball. Donald was a Texas All-State honorable mention in Football, where he played at the wide receiver, defensive back, and kickoff return positions.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":67,"website":"http:\/\/www.donalddriver80.com\/donald.htm","were_here_count":0,"id":"112169405467151","name":"Donald Driver","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Donald-Driver\/112169405467151","likes":128335}

{"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar Alberto Del Rio","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"Born into Mexican nobility, Alberto Del Rio is the son of famous luchador Dos Caras, who is linked by blood to Spanish royals Ferdinand and Isabella. Although hailing from a wealthy family, Del Rio has great empathy for the working class in addition to his passion for high culture.\n\nDuring summer 2010, Del Rio debuted in WWE, making an immediate impact on SmackDown by interrupting and insulting the 619\u2019s own Rey Mysterio. Later that night, Del Rio backed up his bluster by making the former World Champion tap out to his signature Cross Armbreaker. Del Rio quickly followed up on his early success by winning several high-profile matches, including 2011\u2019s 40-Man Royal Rumble Match and WWE Money in the Bank\u2019s Raw Ladder Match that July. These triumphs were key in helping Del Rio fulfill his \u201cdestiny\u201d at 2011\u2019s SummerSlam, where he cashed in his Money in the Bank contract to defeat CM Punk and become the first-ever Mexican-born WWE Champion.\n\nIn October 2011, Alberto Del Rio captured championship gold a second time, in a Triple Threat Match against CM Punk and John Cena at WWE Hell in a Cell. In April 2012, Del Rio officially became a SmackDown Superstar. Day by day, the Mexican Superstar is proving that his unbounded talent, pride and aggression are more than just a formula for winning inside the ring, but the very \u201cEssence of Excellence\u201d in WWE.\n\nDel Rio\u2019s quest to capture the World Title ran through Night of Champions, where he faced World Heavyweight Champion Sheamus. {"birthday":"01\/17\/1942","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"Muhammad Ali (born Cassius Marcellus Clay Jr. on January 17, 1942) is a retired American boxer and former three-time World Heavyweight Champion. To date, he remains the only man to have won the linear heavyweight championship three times (the linear title is recognized by tracing an - almost - unbroken lineage of titleholders going back over 100 years, with nearly every champion defeating the previous titleholder in the ring). Ali was also the winner of an Olympic Light-heavyweight gold medal. In 1999, Ali was crowned \"Sportsman of the Century\" by Sports Illustrated and the BBC.\n\nCassius Marcellus Clay, Jr., was born in Louisville, Kentucky. He was named after his father, Cassius Marcellus Clay Sr., who was named for the 19th century abolitionist and politician Cassius Clay. Ali changed his name after joining the Nation of Islam in 1964, subsequently converted to Sunni Islam in 1975 and then Sufism.[1]\n\nAli was known for his fighting style, which he described as \"Float like a butterfly, sting like a bee\". Throughout his career Ali made a name for himself with great handspeed, as well as swift feet and taunting tactics. While Ali was renowned for his fast, sharp out-fighting style, he also had a \"great chin\", displaying great courage and an ability to take a punch throughout his career.","personal_interests":"Biography\n\nEarly life\n\nCassius Clay, Jr., was born on January 17, 1942. His father, Clay Sr., painted billboards and signs, and his mother, Odessa Grady Clay, was a household domestic. Although Clay Sr. was a Methodist, he allowed Odessa to bring up both Clay boys as Baptists.[2]\n\nAmateur career; Olympic gold\n\nClay was first directed toward boxing by Louisville police officer, Joe E. Martin, who encountered the then twelve-year-old Cassius Clay fuming over the fact that his bicycle had been stolen.[3] However, without Martin knowing, Clay also began training with Fred Stoner at another gym.[who?] In this way, he could continue making $4 a week on Tomorrow's Champions, a TV show that Martin hosted, while benefiting from the coaching of the more-experienced Stoner, who continued working with Clay throughout his amateur career.[who?]\n\nClay's last amateur loss was to Kent Green of Chicago, who could say he was the last person to defeat the champion until Ali lost to Joe Frazier in 1971 as a pro. Under Stoner's guidance, Cassius Clay went on to win six Kentucky Golden Gloves titles, two national Golden Gloves titles, an Amateur Athletic Union National Title, and the Light Heavyweight gold medal in the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome.[4] Clay's record was 100 wins, with five losses, when he ended his amateur career.\n\nAli states (in his 1975 autobiography) that he threw his Olympic gold medal into the Ohio River after being refused service at a 'whites-only' restaurant, and fighting with a white gang. Whether this is true is still debated, although he was given a replacement medal during the opening ceremony of the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta, where he lit the torch to start the games.\n\nEarly professional career\n\nAfter his Olympic triumph, Clay returned to Louisville to begin his professional career. There, on October 29, 1960, he won his first professional fight, a six-round decision over Tunney Hunsaker, who was the police chief of Fayetteville, West Virginia.\n\nStanding tall, at 6-ft, 3-in (1.91 m), Clay had a highly unorthodox style for a heavyweight boxer. Rather than the normal style of carrying the hands high to defend the face, he instead relied on foot speed and quickness to avoid punches and carried his hands low.\n\nFrom 1960 to 1963, the young fighter amassed a record of 19-0, with 15 knockouts. He defeated boxers such as Tony Esperti, Jim Robinson, Donnie Fleeman, Alonzo Johnson, George Logan, Willi Besmanoff, Lamar Clark (who had won his previous 40 bouts by knockout), Doug Jones and Henry Cooper.\n\nClay built a reputation by correctly predicting the round in which he would \"finish\" several opponents, and by boasting before his triumphs. Clay admitted he adopted the latter practice from \"Gorgeous\" George Wagner, a popular professional wrestling champion in the Los Angeles area who drew thousands of fans. Often referred to as \"the man you loved to hate,\" George could incite the crowd with a few heated remarks, and Ali followed suit.\n\nAmong Clay's victims were Sonny Banks (who knocked him down during the bout), Alejandro Lavorante, and the aged Archie Moore (a boxing legend who had fought over 200 previous fights, and who had been Clay's trainer prior to Angelo Dundee). Clay had considered continuing using Moore as a trainer following the bout, but Moore had insisted that the cocky \"Louisville Lip\" perform training camp chores such as sweeping and dishwashing. He also considered having his idol, Sugar Ray Robinson, as a manager, but instead hired Dundee.\n\nClay first met Dundee when the latter was in Louisville with light heavyweight champ Willie Pastrano. The teenaged Golden Glove winner traveled downtown to the fighter's hotel, called Dundee from the house phone, and was asked up to their room. He took advantage of the opportunity to query Dundee (who was working with, or had, champions Sugar Ramos and Carmen Basilio) about what his fighters ate, how long they slept, how much roadwork (jogging) they did, and how long they sparred.\n\nFollowing his bout with Moore, Clay won a disputed 10-round decision over Doug Jones in a matchup that was named \"Fight of the Year\" for 1963. Clay's next fight was against Henry Cooper, who knocked Clay down with a left hook near the end of the fourth round. The fight was stopped in the fifth due to deep cuts over Cooper's eyes.\n\nDespite these close calls, Clay became the top contender for Sonny Liston's title. Despite his impressive record, however, he was not widely expected to defeat the champ. The fight was scheduled for February 25, 1964 in Miami, Florida, but was nearly canceled when the promoter, Bill Faversham, heard that Clay had been seen around Miami and in other cities with the controversial Malcolm X. At the time, The Nation of Islam \u2014 of which Malcolm X was a member \u2014 was portrayed as a \"hate group\" by most of the media. Because of this, news of this association was perceived as a potential gate-killer to a bout where, given Liston's overwhelming status as the favorite to win (7-1 odds[5]), had Clay's colorful persona and nonstop braggadocio as its sole appeal.\n\nFaversham confronted Clay about his association with Malcolm X (who, at the time, was actually under suspension by the Nation as a result of controversial comments made in the wake of President Kennedy's assassination, which he called a case of \"the chickens coming home to roost\"). While stopping short of admitting he was a member of the Nation, Clay protested the suggested cancellation of the fight. As a compromise, Faversham asked the fighter to delay his announcement about his conversion to Islam until after the fight. The incident is described in the 1975 book The Greatest: My Own Story by Ali (with Richard Durham).\n\nDuring the weigh-in on the day before the bout, the ever-boastful Clay, who frequently taunted Liston during the buildup by dubbing him \"the big ugly bear\" (among other things), declared that he would \"float like a butterfly and sting like a bee,\" and, summarizing his strategy for avoiding Liston's assaults, said, \"Your hands can't hit what your eyes can't see.\"\n\nFirst title fight\n\n    Main article: Muhammad Ali versus Sonny Liston\n\nClay, however, had a plan for the fight. At the pre-fight weigh-in, Clay's pulse rate was around 120, more that double his norm of 54. Liston, along with others, misread this as nervousness, and as such, was typically over-confident and unprepared for any result other than a quick knockout victory in his favor. In the opening rounds, Clay's speed kept him away from Liston's powerful head and body shots, as he used his height advantage to beat Liston to the punch with his own lightning-quick jab.\n\nBy the third round, Clay was ahead on points and had opened a cut under Liston's eye. Liston regained some ground in the fourth, as Clay was blinded by a substance in his eyes. It is unconfirmed whether this was something used to close Liston's cuts, or deliberately applied to Liston's gloves for a nefarious purpose; however, Bert Sugar (author, boxing historian and insider) has recalled at least two other Liston fights in which a similar situation occurred, suggesting the possibility that the Liston corner deliberately attempted to cheat.\n\nWhatever the case, Liston came into the fourth round aggressively looking to put away the challenger. As Clay struggled to recover his vision, he sought to escape Liston's offensive. He was able to keep out of range until his sweat and tears rinsed the substance from his eyes, responding with a flurry of combinations near the end of the fifth round. By the sixth, he was looking for a finish and dominated Liston. Then, Liston shocked the boxing world when he failed to answer the bell for the seventh round, later claiming a shoulder injury as the reason. Cassius Clay had indeed \"Shook up the world!\" just as he had promised.\n\nIn the rematch, which was held in May 1965 in relatively-remote Lewiston, Maine, Ali (who had by now publicly converted to Islam and changed his name) won by knockout in the first round as a result of what came to be called the \"phantom punch.\" Many believe that Liston, possibly as a result of threats from Nation of Islam extremists, or in an attempt to \"throw\" the fight to pay off debts, just wanted to call it a day and waited to be counted out (see Muhammad Ali versus Sonny Liston). Others, however, discount both scenarios and insist that it was a quick, chopping Ali punch to the side of the head that legitimately felled Liston.\n\nIn November 1965 Ali fought Floyd Patterson in his second title defense including his rematch with Liston. Ali completely dominated Patterson, who lost by technical knockout at the end of the 12th round. Ali savagely beat Patterson, because of his refusal to call Ali by his new name, and Patterson's denouncement of the Nation of Islam. Ali defended his title seven times in 1966 and 1967.\n\n...\n\n(cf Wikipedia)","talking_about_count":295,"were_here_count":0,"id":"31094044651","name":"Mohamed Ali","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Mohamed-Ali\/31094044651","likes":221375}

{"about":"Younis Khan's biggest fanpage page on Facebook.\nFollow our twitter account: www.twitter.com\/YK313. Dedicated to Younis Khan's most loyal fans.","affiliation":"PCB","awards":"Numerous Man of The Match Awards, ICC Test Batsmen Ranking Top, ICC WC T20 2009 etc.","bio":"One of Pakistan's modern batting greats, Younis Khan is the kind of man who responds best in adversity. A Test average of over 50, a triple-hundred, a famous double-hundred against India in India, and a brilliant rearguard partnership to clinch Pakistan's 3-0 Test whitewash over England, leave no doubt about his quality and class. \n\nHe is also one of the most successful fielders for Pakistan, and can bowl respectable slow-medium. As a captain, Younis has enjoyed success in leading Pakistan to the world Twenty20 title in 2009. Much of his persona evokes the idea of the quintessential Pathan warrior - committed, inspired, capable, and bearing the burden of conflict with fortitude and poise. Born in Mardan, a prominent city in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Younis moved at an early age to Karachi, where he caught the eye of Rashid Latif and Saeed Anwar at Malir Gymkhana, one of the city's renowned sports clubs.\n\n The relationship with Latif blossomed into a nurturing mentorship, guiding Younis towards entry onto the world stage. After two impressive domestic seasons, he got a Test call-up, and marked it with a century on debut. Style and aesthetics are not his strongest points. His technique relies on a good deal of bottom hand, which deprives it of the fluidity and grace that is typical of Asia's best batsmen. Yet when Younis gets going, he produces results in the face of steep odds. Indeed, the steeper the odds, the more Younis seems to thrive.\n\n His match-winning 267 and 84 not out in Bangalore came after a string of low scores prompted a sarcastic comment from the team manager that leaked into the media. His greatest captaincy feat - the world Twenty20 championship in England - was achieved weeks after Pakistan cricket had been devastated by the terror attacks in Lahore. And though his triple-century came at home on a flat track, the innings began under pressure when Younis, eschewing the night watchman, stepped out himself in the dying moments of the second day with Pakistan staring at a huge Sri Lankan total. \n\nUnsurprisingly for a rearguard specialist, Younis has emerged a master of the fourth innings. Among players with 1000 or more fourth-innings Test runs, his average is among the highest. Along with these accomplishments, Younis's career has also seen turmoil. Inability to control infighting within the team and display tact with the PCB led to him losing the captaincy in late 2009, and he effected a moody refusal when circumstances changed and it was offered again.\n\n His nature is to be inward-looking and intensely focused, quietly fighting his way through. While this makes for a reclusive personality that shuns the media and runs afoul of officialdom, it has also been the source of Younis's batting strength and his extraordinary resilience as a cricketer.","birthday":"11\/29\/1975","category":"Athlete","description":"Dedicated to Younis Khan's most loyal fans.","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"DHA","city":"Karachi","state":"","country":"Pakistan","zip":"74000"},"personal_info":"Full Name\nMOHAMMAD YOUNIS KHAN. \n\nBirthday\nNovember 29, 1977.\n\nBirthplace\nMardan, North-West Frontier Province (now Khyber Pakhtunkhwah)  Pakistan.\n\nStar Sign\nSagittarius.\n\nHeight\n5ft 11in.\n\nNickname\nYK\n\nResidence\nKarachi.\n\nFamily\nMarried (2 children); Six older brothers, three older sisters.\n\nEducation\nIslamia Arts & College, Karachi .\n","personal_interests":"Cricket, Football, Fishing etc.","talking_about_count":19088,"username":"313YK","website":"http:\/\/www.espncricinfo.com\/ci\/content\/player\/43652.html","were_here_count":0,"id":"148715015151314","name":"Younis Khan","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/313YK","likes":156603,"cover":{"cover_id":648393915183419,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash3\/s720x720\/1463415_648393915183419_983663892_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"about":"Taekwondo and Brazilian Jiu Jitsu Master! In a 35 years career his work has been featured in hundreds of magazines, newspapers, books, movies and TV Shows!!","bio":"(From Wikipedia)\n \nAndr\u00e9 Lima (martial artist)\n \n \nAndr\u00e9 Alex Lima (Born 1966), better known as Andr\u00e9 Lima is a Brazilian Martial Arts expert, former competitor and pioneer of Brazilian Martial Arts in the United States who lives and teach Martial Arts in Los Angeles. He\u2019s a Grand Master is Taekwondo and also holds black belts in Karate and Brazilian Jiu Jitsu. During his more than 30 years career in Martial Arts he was featured in articles and interviews of approximated 500 martial arts magazines around the world. In 2008 he was the lead actor in a Hollywood Mixed Martial Arts movie called Beyond the Ring.\n \nBiography\nAndr\u00e9 Lima was born in 1966 in Piaui, Brazil and lived there until 1973 when his parents moved to the city of Bras\u00edlia were he began his journey into martial arts. He started studying and competing in Taekwondo under the guidance of Masters Soo Myung Choi and Carlos Eduardo Loddo. In 1983 Lima\u2019s family relocated to Ceara, in the north of Brazil and at that time there were no Taekwondo schools in that region. In 1984 he started the first one, been recognized today as a pioneer of this art in the north of the country. During the time in Ceara, Lima formed the first group of local black belts, national champions, organized the first State championship and in 1986 founded the local governmental organization to control and regulate the practice of Taekwondo in that State. Between 1985 and 87 he made several appearances in Brazilian television, in 1986 he performed a remarkable Martial Arts demonstration for the station Rede Globo. Lima jumped of the third floor of a building; then jumped over a car to break a board in the other side and broke a pile of 20 tiles with his head. In Ceara, Lima as well studied and competed in Karate, winning a State championship and achieving his black belt in 1986 under Master Francisco Gilson de Almeida. In 1986 he also began studding Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu under Master Francisco Sa. In 1987, he attended Medical school for a year at the Federal University of Ceara. In 1988 Lima moved to Europe and started competing in the international tournament circuit. He fought in France, Spain, Portugal, Luxemburg and Belgium winning numerous local and international titles. In 1988 he began to be featured in a variety of European martial arts magazines such as: Karate from France, Combat from England, Budo from Germany, Cinturon Negro from Spain and Samurai from Italy, becoming an internationally recognized figure in the martial arts world. In most of the time Lima resided in Europe he was based in France where he worked teaching Taekwondo in Paris. He devoted some of his time in France and trained Kickboxing with French champion Dominique Valera. He worked temporarily as a Taekwondo teacher in the city of Braga, Portugal. In 1988 he won the Portuguese National Taekwondo Championships held in the city of Porto. In 1989 Lima moved to New York City and started to teach Taekwondo in Queens. He competed in the East Coast Point Fight Karate Circuit winning a World Title in 1990 for the World Professional Karate Organization in Manhattan. In 1990 Lima arrives in Los Angeles establishing permanent residence. He began teaching and competing in Taekwondo, winning a number of competitions in the West Coast. In 1991 he became a student of the Machado Brazilian Jiu Jitsu Academy and in the same year he began working as a freelance writer, making interviews and writing articles for a variety of martial arts and fitness magazines in the United States and Europe. He interviewed celebrities like: Arnold Schwarzenegger, Steven Seagal, Van Damme and Chuck Norris. In 1992 Lima was accepted by the US Immigration Service as a permanent resident and received his green card in the category of special skills. In 1997 he became a citizen of the United States. Lima retired from martial arts competition in 1992, but came back as a contender a few times. In 1993 he represented the United States in an international match against the Korean National Team. In 2001 he competed in the Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Pan-American Championships in Florida taken 2nd place In 1995 Lima founded the first Lima Taekwondo Academy, a chain of Martial Arts gyms in Los Angeles. In 2000 he was the author of a Martial Arts book called Combat Kicking released in the United States and England. Since 1992 Lima has had a number of small roles as an actor and stunt man in movies such as: Zwischensaison (1992), Best of the Best II (1993), Red Sun Rising (1993), Sworn to Justice (1996), The Silent Force (2001). In 2004 he received a black belt in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu from Rigan Machado in Los Angeles; in 2008 he was inducted by the Martial Arts Hall of Fame in New York City. In 2008 he starred with Gary Busey in a Hollywood Mixed Martial Arts movie called Beyond the Ring and had a role in the television show Comedy Central. In 2009 he was promoted to 7th degree black belt by the World Taekwondo Federation in a belt test promoted by the Kukkiwon and received the title of Grand Master.\nLima was one of the first Brazilians martial arts experts to emigrate and teach Martial Arts in the United States and extensively promoted Brazilian fighters and Instructors. In a career spanning three decades he was featured in numerous newspapers articles, television interviews, books, movies and approximated 500 martial arts and fighting magazines in the United States, Europe, South America and Australia. Lima speaks four languages: Portuguese, English, French and Spanish and had traveled to 32 countries in activities related to martial arts.","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"BIRTH NAME: Andre Alex Lima\nHEIGHT: 6\u20192\u201d \/ 1.86 m\nWEIGHT: 200 lb \/ 90 kg\nBIRTH PLACE: Brazil\nCITZENSHIP: Brazil \/ USA\nRESIENCE: Los Angeles, CA\nPROFESSION: Martial Arts Master\nBLACK BELT: Taekwondo \/ Karate \/ Brazilian Jiu Jitsu\nHOBBY: Photography \/ Hand Guns Expert","talking_about_count":14664,"website":"www.limataekwondo.com","were_here_count":0,"id":"96783966201","name":"TAEKWONDO - ANDRE LIMA","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/TAEKWONDO-ANDRE-LIMA\/96783966201","likes":162784,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151402696231202","source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash3\/s720x720\/543144_10151402696231202_886143410_n.jpg","offset_y":33,"offset_x":0}}

His predominant position is defensive midfielder but he can also play in a more advanced role and has played at right back, which he occasionally did for former club Chelsea, as well as France.Early careerLass was turned down by football clubs as a youngster. FC Nantes deemed him too \"small and lightweight\" to succeed at 170\u00a0cm and 58\u00a0kg (5'7\" and 9 stone). Lass admitted he thought his \"football career was over\". {"category":"Interest","description":"Andrew Eugene \"Andy\" Pettitte is an American former baseball starting pitcher who played 18 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB), primarily for the New York Yankees. He also pitched for the Houston Astros. Pettitte won five World Series championships with the Yankees and was a three-time All-Star. He ranks as MLB's all-time postseason wins leader with 19.Pettitte was drafted by the Yankees organization in 1990, and he signed with them a year later. After debuting in the major leagues in 1995, Pettitte finished third in voting for the American League (AL) Rookie of the Year Award. In 1996, he led the AL with 21 wins and was runner-up for the AL Cy Young Award, and two years later, he was named the Yankees' Opening Day starter. Pettitte established himself as one of the \"Core Four\" players who contributed to the Yankees' late-1990s dynasty that produced four championships. Pettitte won the 2001 American League Championship Series Most Valuable Player (MVP) Award in helping his team win the pennant. After spending nine seasons with the Yankees\u2014a stint in which he won at least 12 games each season\u2014Pettitte signed with the Astros in 2004. He rejoined the Yankees in 2007 and later that season admitted to using human growth hormone to recover from an elbow injury in 2002. Pettitte's second tenure with the team lasted six seasons, interrupted by a one-year retirement in 2011, and produced a fifth World series championship.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":28,"website":"http:\/\/sports.espn.go.com\/mlb\/spring2008\/news\/story?id=3251828","were_here_count":0,"id":"103117869728690","name":"Andy Pettitte","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Andy-Pettitte\/103117869728690","likes":68032}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Abhinav Singh Bindra is an Indian shooter and is a World and Olympic champion in the 10 m Air Rifle event. By winning the gold in the 10\u00a0m Air Rifle event at the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, he became the first Indian to win an individual gold medal at the Olympic Games. It was also India's first gold medal since 1980, when the Men's Field Hockey Team won the gold. He is the first and only Indian to have held both the World and Olympic titles at the same time, a feat he accomplished by capturing the Gold Medal at the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing, after having won the gold at the 2006 ISSF World Shooting Championships.CareerEarly yearsAbhinav Bindra was born in the home of Punjabi Sikh family. He studied at The Doon School for two years before moving to St. Stephen's School, Chandigarh; he graduated from Stephen's in 2000. His parents had an indoor shooting range installed at their home in Patiala, Punjab. His Mental Coach was Surabh Bhattacharjee and Abhinav Kumar residing in Patna, who has been closely associated with him since the beginning of his career. Bhattacharjee and Lt. Col. Dhillon (who was also his first Coach) were the first ones to spot the potential in Abhinav. Bindra was the youngest Indian participant at the 2000 Olympic Games. His current coach is five-time Olympic shooter Gabriele B\u00fchlmann from Basel, Switzerland, with whom he trained in Germany before the Olympics. In the 2000 Olympics Bindra achieved a score of 590, placing him 11th in the qualification round, and did not qualify for the finals since only the top eight competed in the finals. After his disappointing performance, Bindra said that he has no plans to retire from shooting.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":110,"were_here_count":0,"id":"103764946329498","name":"Abhinav Bindra","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Abhinav-Bindra\/103764946329498","likes":111192}

{"about":"The Official Facebook Page of Stuart Broad","bio":"In his early cricketing career, Broad had been shaping up to be an opening bat just like his dad Chris, until he suddenly shot up. Within 18 months he had transformed himself into a medium-fast bowler and was playing for England Under-19 and Leicestershire's first XI. A few months later and he's gone from England's A team to a call-up to the full one-day side. Talk about a meteoric rise.\n\n\"I thought I may as well try bowling because I can't just stand around in the field all day,\" he shrugged - and promptly took 9 for 72 for England Under-19s in ODIs against Sri Lanka and 30 first-class wickets at 27.69 in ten matches in 2005.\n\nBut those early years as a batsman did not go amiss. After his first eight Tests, he had racked up three half-centuries from the pivotal No. 8 position, and push his Test average above 40 - a mark his father (39.54) just missed out on over the course of his 25-match career.\n\nAt the age of just 19, he was called into the England A set-up in the West Indies to replace James Anderson who flew out to bolster the seniors in India and was twice selected for England A during the 2006 season.\n\nHis early performances for the one-day team, against Pakistan, were promising but he was left out of the Champions Trophy, but more out of a feeling of not wanting to push him too hard, too soon. He was named in the Academy team to be based in Perth during the Ashes and by the end of the winter he had joined the World Cup squad in the Caribbean.\n\nInjury deprived him of a Test debut in May 2007, but he marked his return to the one-day side with 3 for 20 against West Indies at Lord's, and he was then announced in England's squad for the first Test against India in July. His stock continued to rise on tour with England in Sri Lanka when his 11 cheap wickets helped them to a 3-2 series victory.\n\nHe was then called up for the subsequent Test series in December, making his debut on a slab of Colombo concrete and toiling for 36 sweaty overs. The subsequent tour of New Zealand proved to be his making, however. With Matthew Hoggard and Steve Harmison both lacking form, he was selected for the Wellington Test. The decision was immediately vindicated, if not with a huge match-haul then certainly by the composure and control he showed.\n\nThe following Test in Napier, however, demonstrated his immense allround talent. A vital 42 helped prop up England's first innings before he took 3 for 54, testing all New Zealand's batsmen with pace and bounce. A diving catch at backward square leg confirmed, if there were any doubts, that England had found themselves a Test cricketer of rare class and even rarer composure.\n\nThat impression continued to climb during England's home season in 2008 when no less a technical purist as Geoffrey Boycott likened his tall elegant batting style to Sir Garfield Sobers. Although he has struggled at times for consistency with his bowling, his unmistakable talent was out on show again against South Africa in Durban in 2009 as helped bowl England to a famous innings victory.","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_interests":"The Broad Appeal \n\nWebsite: thebroadappeal.org\nTwitter: \u0040thebroadappeal","talking_about_count":9850,"username":"StuartBroadOfficial","website":"http:\/\/www.stuart-broad.com\/, http:\/\/twitter.com\/StuartBroad8","were_here_count":0,"id":"154546228008190","name":"Stuart Broad","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/StuartBroadOfficial","likes":166199,"cover":{"cover_id":354263041369840,"source":"http:\/\/scontent-b.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-frc1\/s720x720\/1002464_354263041369840_392081054_n.jpg","offset_y":37,"offset_x":0}}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Christopher Henry \"Chris\" Gayle is a Jamaican cricketer who plays international cricket for the West Indies. He captained the West Indies' side from 2007 to 2010. He plays domestic cricket for Jamaica, and also represents the Royal Challengers Bangalore in the Indian Premier League, the Sydney Thunder in the Big Bash League and the Dhaka Gladiators in the Bangladesh Premier League. He has also represented Worcestershire, the Western Warriors, Barisal Burners and the Kolkata Knight Riders in his career. He was also selected for team Uva Next for the inaugural Sri Lanka Premier League in 2012.He is one of only four players who have scored two triple centuries at Test level: 317 against South Africa in 2005, and 333 against Sri Lanka in 2010. He is known as a big hitter, often hitting sixes; in 2012 he became the first player to hit a six off the first ball of a Test match. Playing for Royal Challengers Bangalore, he scored a 30-ball century, the fastest across any format, that became the highest individual T20 score . It eclipsed the previous mark set by Brendan McCullum of Kolkata Knight Riders. At the launch of the Caribbean Premier League he was announced as the first franchise player for the league.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":789,"website":"http:\/\/www.espncricinfo.com\/twenty20wc\/engine\/current\/match\/287853.html","were_here_count":0,"id":"104358599601495","name":"Chris Gayle","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Chris-Gayle\/104358599601495","likes":393729}

{"about":"The official WWE Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar David Otunga.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"After winning notoriety in the world of reality TV (on VH1\u2019s \u201cI Love New York 2\u201d) and in American tabloids (as the fianc\u00e9 of Grammy and Academy Award-winning actress, Jennifer Hudson), David Otunga began making headlines of his own on WWE NXT\u2019s inaugural season.\n\nAs anyone confronted with Otunga's impressive physique can testify, the competitor has more than his fair share of brawn and good looks. But he backs up these natural gifts with intelligence, all powered by a blue chip Harvard Law School education.\n\nAlthough he failed to win WWE NXT, Otunga made a powerful opening statement on Raw, where he joined winner Wade Barrett and his fellow season one Rookies to form The Nexus. This destructive faction, incensed by their perceived poor treatment on NXT, dismantled Superstars indiscriminately, demanding that management grant them bona fide contracts. \n\nThanks to the Anonymous Raw General Manager, Otunga finally signed with WWE in 2010. He\u2019s made the most of his opportunity since, notching the WWE Tag Team Championship twice, with Michael McGillicutty as well as one-time Nexus member John Cena.\n\nIn late 2011, Otunga flew solo and provided pro bono legal counsel to John Laurinaitis \u2014 in between contesting matches with the likes of Randy Orton and Sheamus. After Big Johnny was ousted from WWE, Otunga began representing others, including Ricardo Rodriguez in a lawsuit against World Heavyweight Champion Sheamus. \n\nThe suave Superstar even lit up the silver screen, cast as a police officer in the 2013 Halle Berry film \"The Call.\"\n\nThe jury is still out on the bowtied, litigious Otunga, who comes across like a super-sized Carlton Banks these days. But he knows as well as anyone, in the WWE court of law, the burden of proof is on him to make his case as a legitimate title contender. {"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Diva Layla.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"Utilizing skills honed while a member of the Miami Heat dance squad, Layla won the 2006 Diva Search to earn her opportunity in WWE.\n\nThe flirty contest winner made her first appearance at that year\u2019s SummerSlam, and then the English-born beauty took her sweet dance moves to ECW, where she wowed the WWE Universe as part of the Extreme Expos\u00e9.\n\nBy 2009, Layla joined forces with Michelle McCool to form Team Lay-Cool on SmackDown. The \u201cFlawless\u201d duo seemed inseparable, even going as far as referring to themselves as the self-professed \u201cco\u2013Women\u2019s Champions\u201d when Layla held the title. But it wasn\u2019t long before Layla enjoyed her own time in the spotlight.\n\nAlongside McCool in a 2-on-1 Handicap Match for the title, Layla pinned Beth Phoenix in May 2010 on SmackDown to become the first-ever British Women's Champion, and with that accolade, she also became the last Women\u2019s Champion, as the title was retired shortly thereafter.\n\nThings started to unravel between Lay-Cool in 2011, culminating with a Loser Leaves WWE Match at Extreme Rules, which saw the end to their friendship and McCool\u2019s departure from WWE. Despite the victory over her ex-friend, an injury sidelined the British beauty for the rest of the year.\n\nAfter lengthy rehab on her knee, Layla finally returned to the ring at Extreme Rules 2012 where she defeated Nikki Bella to win the Divas Title, proving that she hadn\u2019t lost a step in her time away from the squared circle. {"about":"The official Facebook fan page for WWE Superstar Wade Barrett.","affiliation":"WWE","bio":"Trained in bare-knuckle brawling on the mean streets of Preston, England, Wade Barrett brings strength, arrogance and cunning to the ring in equal measure. Barrett\u2019s cold and ruthless leadership proved difficult to withstand. Even the mighty John Cena couldn\u2019t withstand the onslaught, first becoming a lackey to Barrett\u2019s goon squad and then being unceremoniously ousted from WWE after Barrett ordered his firing.\n\nAfter Cena was reinstated, Barrett jumped over to SmackDown, forming The Corre, intent on dominating Friday nights just as handily as he had Mondays. Shortly thereafter, Barrett defeated Kofi Kingston to become the Intercontinental Champion. He then used The Corre as hired muscle to ensure he would keep the championship gold until the group imploded along with Wade\u2019s Intercontinental Title reign. With no other Superstars at his side, the scheming Superstar employed his self-proclaimed \u201cBarrett Barrage\u201d \u2014 a one-man mission of mercilessness that targeted even those at WWE\u2019s peak, most notably Randy Orton.\n\nFollowing a partially dislocated elbow that kept him out of action for nearly seven months, a reinvigorated Barrett made his intense return to WWE in September 2012. The English Superstar used his downtime to get back to basics and \u201creignite the flame\u201d \u2014 presumably through participation in the sort of bare-knuckle boxing he took part in early in his past.\n\nKnocking out anyone in his path with a devastating elbow strike he\u2019s dubbed the Bull Hammer, Barrett racked up victory after victory upon his return, establishing himself as a contender for the Intercontinental Title, which he captured on the Dec. 31, 2012, edition of Raw.\n\nBarrett then set his sights on the Royal Rumble Match and the prize of a World Title opportunity at WrestleMania 29. Barrett had an impressive showing in the over-the-top-rope classic, but was ultimately eliminated by NXT upstart Bo Dallas, who the Brit intends on sending back to the developmental territory he came from.\n\nHe\u2019s also making his foray into films with a role in \u201cDead Man Down.\u201d Barrett beamed as he introduced the film\u2019s trailer on Raw, saying it would make him a star. The Brit isn't taking kindly to anyone who tries to diminish his role in the flick. After Chris Jericho and The Miz ragged on him during the March 11 edition of Raw, Barrett set off a brawl during their No. 1 Contender\u2019s Match that night.\n\nBarrett later defeated both men in a Triple Threat Match. Overconfidence may have cost the British Superstar a match against The Awesome One on the March 26 Raw, though. The Intercontinental Champion brashly interrupted Triple H, leading The Game to deliver a vicious low blow. In the match, Barrett tapped out to The Miz\u2019s Figure-Four Leglock. The result was the same on the WrestleMania 29 Interactive Pre-Show, but this time, The Awesome One walked out of MetLife Stadium with the Intercontinental Title.\n\nThe Brit was on the warpath after his loss, and in a rematch little more than 24 hours later, he reclaimed the Intercontinental Championship from The Miz. With a vicious Bull Hammer elbow, Barrett won his third Intercontinental Title on Raw! Things seemed to be back on track for the former bare-knuckle brawler, until the following week on Raw, when he was upset by R-Truth in a non-title match. Barrett once again found himself needing to bounce back. He did exactly that with two impressive victories, over Justin Gabriel on WWE Main Event and William Regal on a SmackDown from London, respectively.\n\nArmed with an arsenal of brutal strikes, there\u2019s not a doubt in anyone\u2019s mind The Barrett Barrage is back on course.","category":"Athlete","company_overview":"Stats:\nHeight: 6 feet 5 inches\nWeight: 265\nFrom: Manchester, England","is_published":true,"location":{"street":"","city":"Manchester","state":"","country":"United Kingdom","zip":""},"talking_about_count":266,"website":"http:\/\/www.wwe.com\/superstars","were_here_count":0,"id":"333832427272","name":"Wade Barrett - WWE Universe","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Wade-Barrett-WWE-Universe\/333832427272","likes":343695,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151361976352273","source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash3\/s720x720\/940916_10151361976352273_234571543_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Dale Willem Steyn is a South African cricketer who plays in Test and One Day International cricket for South Africa. He is currently the number one ranked Test bowler in the world and has been for the past 4 years, achieving the 900+ points benchmark on 13 November 2011 following his important early work with pace bowling expert, Ian Pont. Steyn plays domestic cricket in South Africa for Cape Cobras. He is a right-arm fast bowler, and bowls at speeds of around 145\u2013150\u00a0km\/h (his fastest being recorded at 156.2\u00a0km\/h during the 2010 IPL, Bangalore Royal Challengers against Kolkata Knight Riders). He bowls at a very fast pace with a slinging action, releasing the cricket ball low. This distinctive action has earned him the nickname 'Slinga Malinga'. He took six wickets in his Test debut against world champions Australia in 2004. He has constantly troubled batsman with his lively pace and well directed bouncers during his maiden tour of Australia along with his unique bowling action that many batsmen struggle to adapt to.\n\nSubsequently, during the tour of New Zealand in 2004\/2005, his action was found so hard to play by the Kiwi batsmen that the captain, Stephen Fleming requested the umpire to remove his red tie so that they would be able to see the ball being released from Malinga's hand. The umpire did not do so.\n\nAlong with the bouncer, he has a variety of balls, which also include the yorker, which is very hard to play, considering the fact that he regularly bowls between 140 KM and 150 KM.\n\n\nLasith Malinga was the surprise selection for Sri Lanka's tour to Australia in 2004, though he had a fearsome reputation on the domestic circuit. Malinga bowls with a distinctive and explosive round-arm action which generates genuine pace and can disconcert batsmen who struggle to pick up the ball's trajectory. Already, he is rated the fastest bowler in Sri Lanka. His first performance in Sri Lankan colours was also impressive - he took 6 for 90 against a Northern Territory Chief Minister's XI. That paved the way for his inclusion in the Test team, and he acquitted himself quite well too, dismissing Darren Lehmann and Adam Gilchrist in the same over.He is developing into Sri Lanka's key pace-bowling wicket-taker, especially as Chaminda Vaas continues to lose pace. {"about":"3 times World Superbike Champion: 2001 - 2006 - 2008 - \u0040TroyBaylisstic on twitter -\nBaylisstic21 on Instagram","bio":"Troy was born on the 30th March 1969, the only son of Warren and Lorraine and his childhood years were spent on the family farm in Taree, New South Wales, Australia with his sister, Jana.\nAt the age of six, Troy\u2019s father gave him a \u201cMonkey\u201d bike to ride around the farm and by the age of 10 he had decided it was time to go racing! For the next four years he traveled the circuits with his father racing in motocross and dirt track events.\nHis love of action sports then led Troy towards surfing and he spent all his spare time on the beach. He met his future wife, Kim, at the age of 18 and his craze for physical fitness made him turn his competitive spirit towards cycle racing. What kind of cycle racing? All kinds\u2026 mountain bikes, speed trials, triathlons. If it had pedals, Troy raced it!\nIn 1992 the attraction of motorcycle racing was too great for Troy to resist and he returned to motorcycle racing, but this time around he would try his hand at road racing. His first races were on his ZXR750 street bike but he thought that he had better \u201cget serious\u201d and changed it for a 250 Sports Production bike.\nHe rode the Kawasaki KR1 in the 250 Sports Production class and was soon winning club events. By the end of the year he entered a few Australian National Sports Production races and won those too. This was fun!\n1993 was a busy year for Troy not only because he wanted to mov\ne up to a bigger bike but also because he married his girlfriend, Kim.\n\nHaving discovered the thrill of racing on circuits, and being eager to start moving up the ladder, Troy raced a Kawasaki 600 and progressed to competing in a few Australian national events by the end of the year.\nIn 1994 Troy rode the same bike to 6th in the Australian National 600 Championship and won the 600 race at Bathurst.\nTroy was, by now, proving that he was a force to be reckoned with in Australia and in 1995 he confirmed that reckoning by taking 2nd place in the championship.\nBy 1996 it was time for Troy to move up another step and, with the backing of Team Kawasaki Australia, entered the Australian Superbike Championship and finished an incredible 3rd.\nIt was in 1997 that the world would see Troy compete in two great World Championship events and recognise his talent and potential. Not only did he improve upon his 1996 placing by finishing 2nd in the Australian Superbike Championship aboard the Ansett Air Freight Suzuki but, entered as a wildcard, he amazed world class teams by finishing 5th in both races of the Phillip Island World Superbike round.\nIf anyone needed further proof of his abilities, they surely had it when the Grand Prix event rolled into town at Phillip Island and, once again as a wildcard entry, Suzuki offered Troy a ride on their 250cc machine. Suzuki had struggled all year to have good results in this incredibly competitive class but Troy immediately qualified it 6th on the grid and even battled for the lead before finally finishing 6th in the race.\nHe thought that the GPs might be his next step but for a phone call from somebody watching that 250 GP race from the other side of the world. If Troy thought that he had made it in 1997, then he certainly hadn\u2019t bargained on the events of the next three years.\nDarrell Healey was the Englishman who had been watching the 1997 Phillip Island 250 GP from the other side of the world.\nAs owner of the Team GSE, he phoned Troy directly after the GP and invited him to move to England to race the GSE Ducati in the British Superbike Championship.\nAt the beginning of 1998, Troy moved his family to England and finished 8th in what was probably the toughest National Championship in the world: The British Superbike Championship.\nIn 1999 having settled into the incredibly professional GSE team, Troy was ready for action. Qualifying in six pole positions and five front row positions (excluding poles), he scored six wins and 14 podium finishes in all and won the British Championship by 28 points.\nTroy was British Superbike Champion! Because he had won the series on a Ducati, his trophy was presented by none other than the World Champion, King Carl Fogarty. Next stop: the United States of America!\n2000 was a typical example of how unpredictable racing can be. Troy had already moved from Australia to England and now, in February of 2000, he moved from England to the US in order to ride a Ducati for the Vance & Hines team in the AMA Superbike Championship. He immediately impressed with his aggressive riding style and set pole position at his first race in the Daytona 200, but crashed out during the race. He then moved on to round 2 at Sears Point and, once again, put the Ducati onto pole position but the race was cancelled because of adverse weather conditions.\nBy this time, Troy was straining at the leash to show how fast he could be. He wouldn\u2019t have to wait long\u2026 Back in Phillip Island, Australia - the place where it had all started for Troy three years ago - World Champion Carl Fogarty had crashed during the second leg of the World Superbike event there. He was badly injured. Troy's phone rang again\u2026 he was approached by the Ducati factory in Italy to replace the injured \u201cKing Carl\u201d. As Troy said, \u201cI get a call from Ducati asking if I was interested in the ride. I didn\u2019t need asking twice!\u201d\n\nTroy crossed the Atlantic again to replace the injured Carl Fogarty and soon astounded the public with a series of spectacular performances. He and the Ducati Infostrada team would only have to wait a few races before he chalked up his first race win at World Championship level.\nThe win, at the incredibly fast Hockenheim circuit in Germany, was followed by another win in front of a supportive British crowd around the very technical Brands Hatch circuit. Troy was now proving himself convincingly.\nTroy\u2019s first ever visit to Assen in Holland left fans in no doubt that he is one of the most spectacular riders in the world. Through awful weather conditions, his battle with the Japanese rider Noriyuki Haga had TV viewers gasping. On a track that was dry on one side of the circuit and wet on the other, the two riders swapped the lead corner after corner until Troy slid off of his Ducati and walked back to the pit garage.\nIt was a walk that had become a common sight during 2000 but everyone around Troy realised that his ability to push the limits is the trademark of a future World Champion.\nDespite missing six races in the 2000 season he had finished 6th in the World Superbike Championship. Troy\u2019s rise to the top has been meteoric but now he faced his biggest step in motorcycle racing: The final step to becoming the Superbike World Champion.\nCombining talent, determination and consistency is what is needed to win the World Superbike Championship. And that was exactly what Troy did.\nThe 2001 season was a fresh start for Troy. From the very start, he put himself on the podium and continued to stay there race after race. And it wasn\u2019t long before he started putting himself at the very top of the podium. By the end of the season, Troy had logged an impressive six wins and nine other podium finishes. In 2001 Troy was crowned World Superbike Champion !\nDespite his dominant riding, however, the title was not as easy as it looked for Troy. In the first race of the 11th round at Oschersleben, he experienced his only technical problem of the year and had to withdraw from the race. This allowed his nearest rival to climb back up in points and threaten Troy\u2019s championship hopes. This disturbing change of events might have pressurised other riders, but it didn\u2019t bother the Aussie. Instead, Troy put the incident behind him and proceeded to get back on the podium in the second race. This race day highlighted what is best about Troy: His ability to take each race as it comes. No other rider comes close to keeping the focus on the moment the way Troy does.\nTroy helped Ducati back to the very top in 2001. He scored their 100th pole position, helped them win their 10th Manufacturers\u2019 Title and won their 9th Riders\u2019 Title\nAs World Champion, 2002 wouldn\u2019t be any different for Troy. It would be another year made up of individual races. It would be another year in which he was determined to succeed.\nThe reigning World Champion started 2002 on an incredible note with six 1st place finishes, putting him into the record books with the most consecutive wins at the start of any season.\nEven after his streak was brought to a halt at Sugo - probably the toughest track to win at for non-locals - Troy resumed his double-winning form at Monza and then again at Lausitzring and Misano. He tallied an incredible six double-wins, with 14 wins overall in the season.\nTroy showed his characteristic grit when he crashed at Brands Hatch and damaged his back and ribs. In spite of the severe beating, he got back on his bike and rode through the pain to 3rd and 2nd place finishes. Not even the crash at Assen, which allowed his nearest rival to slip ahead in the standings by one point, would cause the Aussie\u2019s confidence to waver: \u201cNow I\u2019ve got to go out and do it all at Imola.\u201d\nImola will be forever remembered. Racing fans around the world saw one of the most spectacular races in history at this \u201cwinner takes all\u201d event. Troy Bayliss and Colin Edwards fought two incredible battles, swapping the lead and sometimes their paint too! In the end there could only be one winner and on that day it was Edwards.\nTroy finished the championship second overall, but no one will forget the grace in which he conceded his title: There was still a big smile for all his fans as he stepped up to the podium after this final race of the season. Troy\u2019s tremendous efforts throughout the year had, however, helped Ducati win their 11th Manufacturers\u2019 Title.\n2003 was to be a big year for both Troy and Ducati as they moved into MotoGP together. The effort invested in the new Ducati MotoGP Team had been massive and pre-season tests were encouraging. Troy was to have to deal with the pressures of being at the sharp end of a project in which both the press and fans now expected so much. Few doubted that Troy would carry his characteristic \u201cnever say die\u201d attitude with him, but apart from it being the first year for the Desmosedici machine, most realised that few riders actually make the transfer from Superbike to Grand Prix successfully. They should not have counted Troy in that number! Few were disappointed when the lights finally turned to green on Troy\u2019s first MotoGP season. It may have been a different championship but it was the same old Troy.\nTwo front row positions, three podium places and 6th in the World Championship was an incredible start in MotoGP. Just two points in the series stole 5th position away from Troy and the \u201cRookie of the Year\u201d award but if the world of Grand Prix had never heard of Troy Bayliss before they certainly knew him now. In just the second GP of the year and at a circuit he\u2019d never seen before, Troy took the lead in the South African GP at Welkom from the third row of the grid and held it until one-third distance. He fought tooth and nail with reigning World Champion Valentino Rossi at half race distance and eventually brought the Ducati home in 4th position.\nBy the next race in Jerez, Troy Bayliss was not only on the podium but also on the lips of every race fan around the world. This 34-year-old family man, who had been given the chance to rocket to fame in World Superbike, was now doing the same in MotoGP seemingly oblivious to the fact that he was now rubbing shoulders with the fastest riders on the planet. To Troy, it was just another bike and just another race and his \u201cjust get on with the job\u201d attitude continued to win him fans from all around the world.\nIn 2004 Troy lined up with his team-mate Loris Capirossi once again for the Ducati Moto GP team. Competing at this level will never be easy, and this was a tough season, particularly after a great rookie year, the expectations were high.\nThe end of this season will see Troy leave Ducati after many successful years with the Italian brand.\nAdmittedly Troy had a season below expectations but he finished in great style with a podium finish at Valencia. After the race Troy commented: \"You probably haven't seen me smile like this for a while ... It's been a tough year for me and everyone at Ducati but the bike has come good in the second half of the season. And after we tested some new stuff at Phillip Island it's felt like a new bike for me. \"\n\"I really wanted to have a go at Max (Biaggi) but in the end I thought third was better than putting it in the dirt. I've had some great years with Ducati, with some great times together, so it's nice to leave on a happy note. I wish them all the best for the future, I know they're going to have a strong bike in 2005.\"\nTroy finished 14th in the championship.\nThe 2005 season will see former World Superbike champion Troy Bayliss break his long time Ducati links with a move to the satellite Camel Honda Team, joining veteran Brazilian GP rider Alex Barros for the 2005 MotoGP World Championship.\n\"For me the switch from Ducati to Honda is a bigger change than coming from Superbikes to MotoGP,\" commented Troy. \" But it is a challenge which I am ready to take on and it gives me a lot of motivation\".\nFull of challenges and never at home on his new ride, the season unfolded as a very difficult one for Troy. After an average first half season, news got worst when Troy injured his wrist while training on his motocross bike in Australia. Troy will then miss Motegui , his home race Phillip Island and eventually the rest of the season's races.\nTroy Finished overall in 12th position in the championship.\nThe 2006 season will see Troy bring back his aggressive and spectacular riding style to World Superbikes.\nTroy Bayliss is, to put it simply, a legend for Ducati and the 36-year-old from Taree in Australia now returns to the championship where he made his name. The Ducati Xerox Team rider will surely be one of the protagonists in this year's series.\n\u201cThe biggest thing is that it feels like I\u2019m coming home ... and I don\u2019t mean to Australia!\u201d commented Bayliss. \u201cEven though the bike has changed quite a lot, the engine is still very similar and has been much improved since I\u2019ve been away so it\u2019s a built-in package already waiting there for me. It reminds me of the bike I rode in 2002, especially after the couple of changes we made during the recent tests in Qatar. I think I\u2019m pretty much there, it just needs a little bit of fine-tuning because we\u2019re already at the level we expected to be. The championship is looking strong now, all the manufacturers are back and it\u2019s going to be great to be there with Ducati and challenge all the other guys for the title.\u201d\n2007 always SBK Ducati Xerox and 2008 he won his 3 World SBK Title and he wrote THE END on his carrier in WSBK Championship.\nNow he is Ducati collaudator and instructor and world ducati image man.","birthday":"03\/30\/1969","category":"Athlete","is_published":true,"personal_info":"Management \/ Manager\nSponsorships and events \/ Sponsorizzazioni ed eventi\n\nSilvia Mangione silvia\u0040sgagency.it\nSilvia Borella silvia.borella\u0040sgagency.it","personal_interests":"Bike","talking_about_count":8242,"username":"Troy.Bayliss.21","website":"http:\/\/www.troybayliss.com ","were_here_count":0,"id":"19531332694","name":"Troy Bayliss","link":"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/Troy.Bayliss.21","likes":215950,"cover":{"cover_id":"10151262541422695","source":"http:\/\/scontent-a.xx.fbcdn.net\/hphotos-ash2\/s720x720\/424418_10151262541422695_1209177247_n.jpg","offset_y":0,"offset_x":0}}

{"category":"Athlete","description":"Pilavullakandi Thekkeparambil Usha , popularly known as P. T. Usha, is an Indian track and field athlete from the state of Kerala. P. T. Usha has been associated with Indian athletics since 1979. She is regarded as one of the greatest athletes India has ever produced and is often called the \"queen of Indian track and field\". She is nicknamed the Payyoli Express. Currently she runs the Usha School of Athletics at Koyilandy in Kerala. P. T. Usha was born in the village of Payyoli, Kozhikode District, Kerala. In 1976 the Kerala State Government started a Sports School for women, and Usha was chosen to represent her district.CareerIn 1979 P. T. Usha participated in the National School Games, where she was noticed by O. M. Nambiar, who coached her throughout her career. Her debut in the 1980 Moscow Olympics proved lacklustre. In the 1982 New Delhi Asiad, she got the silver medal in the 100m and the 200m, but at the Asian Track and Field Championship in Kuwait a year later, Usha took the gold in the 400m with a new Asian record . From 1983-89, Usha garnered 13 golds at ATF meets.At the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, she finished first in the semi-finals of the 400 metres hurdles, but narrowly missed a medal in the finals, reminiscent of Milkha Singh's 1960 defeat. There was a nail-biting photo finish for the third place. Usha lost the bronze by 1\/100th of a second. She became the first Indian woman (and the fifth Indian) to reach the final of an Olympic event by winning her 400m hurdles semi-final.","is_community_page":true,"is_published":true,"talking_about_count":312,"website":"http:\/\/www.indianathletics.in\/records\/Records\u002520seniors\u002520(As\u002520on\u00252031.12.2011).pdf","were_here_count":0,"id":"113041012044041","name":"P. {"category":"Athlete","description":"Shane Edward Bond is a former New Zealand cricketer and present bowling coach of the New Zealand national team, described as \"New Zealand's best fast bowler since Sir Richard Hadlee\". He has represented New Zealand in Test, ODI and Twenty20 International cricket as well as playing for Canterbury in New Zealand domestic cricket and Warwickshire in English domestic cricket. Bond is a right-arm fast bowler. His fastest recorded delivery was clocked at 156.4 km\/h against India in the 2003 World Cup.Bond's career was plagued with injuries, chiefly recurring stress fractures of the back. He had surgery in 2004 to try to prevent further injury, but it was only partially successful. In recent years he has suffered back problems, knee injuries and an abdominal tear. These problems, in conjunction with a late start to his fully professional cricket career, have limited his appearances in both international and domestic cricket.
